No real tastes that I can tell other than a little bitter. Reminds me of the generic type bock beer my grandparents served every once in a while.

Appearance: Cloudy dark amberish with a fine off white head.Aroma: Dark malty, fruity and some spices.Palate: Full body. Mild bitterness and a balanced mild sweetness. Rich to average carbonation. Oily texture.Taste: Round sweet dark fruity, vanilla, some spices and mild malty.Overall impression: Really complex stuff. Lovely balanced. What is there to say about this beer that is not said before. Pure class.Personal stats: Bottle from a trade with rlgk.

12-oz. bottle. Pours a clear copper. Aroma of caramel, maple syrup, baked apple, and some brown sugar. A syrup caramel flavor pops up first followed by dark plum and a sharp apple vinegar bite, which helps temper the somewhat cloying sweetness. Mellow body; little carbonation. Good, but I expected something better.

Bottle, paired with a bowl of jujubes (jk). Pours dark brown with small off-white head. Nose of plum, alcohol, molasses. Flavour is plum, toffee, nutty malt, licorice. Main difference from 12 for me is less coffee flavour.
12oz bottle cap "10/9/13" almost the 5 year mark. I havent had 1 fresh but this tasted amazing. Big bready caramel and banana taste. Great beer
Caramel and chocolate is dominating in taste. Perhaps to cold when I drank it, so not so much aroma but one still notice the malts. Great beer and what an aftertaste.

Bullzeye sent me this for free (thanks) and I shared it with my buddy Mike. Mike tells me 12 is way better. I havent cracked that one yet. This beer is delicious. That killer aroma. Rich caramel and yeast. Smooth and awesome.

Bottle thanks to RobertDale ! Pours a nice mahogany umber color with a finger of eggshell bubbles. The nose is soft caramel, dried fruit and a bit of warm spice. The palate follows with a nice upfront soft sweetness of dark brown sugar, raisin a bit of licorice and a dark cocoa and bitter grass finish. Nice carbonation draws the finish out and cleans it up a bit.

(bottle - 330 ml) Rating #3000. Unsure of the vintage but Ive personally had it for over 5 years. Deep chestnut brown pour with a thin and creamy tan head. Dark fruits and some bready malts in the aroma. Flavor is sweet and malty with a nice yeast spice and a lot of dark fruits and wine notes. Smooth as silk and incredibly easy to drink.
Det först som slog mig var att den kändes alldeles för försiktig för att vara en öl på 8%. Balansen var otroligt fin och smaken bar toner av choklad, malt och farinsocker.
Bättre än 6:an! Men kom igen? Vad är det som är så speciellt. Visst fin jäst och bra balans. Sen är det inte mycket mer.
Smak och doft av malt, karamell, russin, plommon, farinsocker med toner av apelsin, choklad och vanilj. Lagom söt och välbalanserad, brett smakregister. Gott.

Flaska från demolenshop, drucken med ölföreningen. Lätt doft av jäst, söta äpplen, gula russin, vanilj och choklad. Kraftig, knäck, vanilj, torkad frukt och aningen nejlika. Lätt beska, perfekt balans.

Deep brown pour with a red tinge when held to light. Aroma is red fruits, nuts, graham cracker. Flavour brings out some spicey yeast, charred malts, toffee, some fruit. Alcohol is a little hot. Great complexity and mouth feel.

330ml bottle shared with Ashton McCobb, via De Struise. Pours dark brown, thin white head which lasts. Aromas of plums, toffee, almonds, higher alcohols. Tastes light bitter, medium sweet, then the bitterness comes back to clean everything up, ready for another! A very well-made beer.

33cl bottle thanks to allmyvinyl. 
Appearance - dark brown going into black. Theres a small head but it does stick around. 
Nose - toffee, slight almonds, plums, then an earthy note on the end. 
Taste - fruit and nut bar - prunes into praline. 
Palate - full bodied with a big rich but elegant body and a creamy finish that is sweet but still clean enough to make you want some more. Theres just enough bitterness to take away the sweetness.
Overall - a lovely elegant beer.

Bottle to celebrate my 1st anniversary of joining RB. Pours cloudy dark teddy bear brown with airy light beige head. Clear aroma of fruit, caramel, malt and alcohol in the long nose. Sweet aroma of malt and caramel with fruity notes and a warming alcohol presence. Sweet and slightly sourish finish. Not as rich as XII, but still good.

Bottle - thanks Brian! Pours cloudy brown with a small beige head and some lacing. Aroma is caramel, spices, dried fruits, toffee. Flavor is the same, medium sweet and lightly astringent. Medium body, quite carbonated. Both the aroma and flavor of this beer improve considerably as it warms, but it doesnt hold a candle to the 12.

33cl bottle at home, shared with Mathieu87. Best Before 23/02/2014.
Tasted blind
APPEARANCE: clear amber beer, nice stable off white head.
NOSE: hoppy, little fruity.
TASTE: grains, little bitter, not much here in my opinion...
Westvleteren 8 has a very strange taste to it, dont really like that though...

Bottle pour deep brown with minimal tan head. Aromas of chocolate, prune, brown sugar. Taste is molasses, with almost an espresso finish with son alcohol warmth. Amazing beer! So glad I got to enjoy this one

Bottle @ Bjarne. Pours dark brown with a light brown head. Aroma of malt, yeast, candy sugar, dark fruits, plums, raisins. Flavor is malt, yeasty, dark fruits, candy sugar, little chocolate. Medium body, smooth silky mouthfeel, soft carbonation, little warming alcohol. 310813
Bottle best before 2012. Gusher. Taste is yeasty, with plums, raisins and some wheat(?). Tasty. Lost 40% of it to the carpet, tho - bummer.

Dark mahogany tinge to a dark almost black appearance, medium long lasting head. Smells.. Roasted fruits.. Plums, raisins, bready/biscuity malts.
Tastes.. Roasted fruits, plums, raisins some candy and yeast, caramel bread malts..so smooth and rounded and balanced. Delicious Belgian.

Mycket kul att testa tillslut. Isabel slänger upp en flaska nyligen hemkommen från Belgien som får avsluta kvällen. Lite belgiskt estrig i doften. Betydligt mer tilltalande belgotoner än w12. Härliga kolasmaker i maltbasen. Precis lagom kropp. Kan vara den bästa dubbel jag testat. Övriga (vilket är Lenner och Isabel) är inte så imponerade av den här. Isabel pratar nästan om vasken. Dåligt kräsen säger jag, för det här är bra dubbel. 

Edit: tydligen går den som belgisk strong. Vem hade trott? Strunt samma, får stå kvar så.

33cl bottle, BB 11/2015. Poured in 15cl Westvl. sampler glass. The red glare in the murky brown mass is a sign of tastes and aromas to come. Lasting beige adhesive head. Fairly contained, but apertly fresh nose of caramel, flowers and marmite. What follows in taste is a slowly blossoming symphony of upfront red berries (blue grapes, currants, spicy dried cranberries), milk chocolate, the usual trappist suspects (date, dried figs, caramel), rounded off in the aftertaste with an unexpected spicy Poperinge hop kick. Smooth, creamy and at the same time with a perfectly attenuated dry mf under lively carbonation; vinuous without being barrel-aged, fresh as coriander seasoning in Asian dishes; with the spirit overtones of a liqueur and leaving a long, lingering aftertaste of all that, coating the palate with the retrospect of sensory overload, like an unexpected shagging leaves behind the body. Not sure if my senses were geared to duly accomodate & record this richness when I first had this 4-5 years ago, as this subtle masterpiece takes time to expand in mouth and mind.

How: Bottle.
Where: In de Vrede, Westvleteren.
Appearance: Brown colour with a large beige head.
Aroma: Caramel, chocolate, coffee, some alcohol.
Body: Full bodied with a good carbonation.
Flavour: Berries, raisin, dried fruit, some chocolate, alcohol.
Comment: Expected it to be good and it lived up to the expectation. Not as flavourful as the Westvleteren 12, but very good.

Reddish-brown beer with a rather thin foam , 
Aromas of freshly dried dark fruit. Spicy yeast with a little anise. Light berries and slight amount of wine gum. 
Taste has moderately sweet maltiness with hints of anis and licorice cough medicine. Fruity, sugary sweetness and a trace of liqueur. The hops at the end are delicate drying, but no bitter aftertaste. 
Mouthfeel is fairly full-bodied. Drinkability is actually surprisingly good on such diverse beer. 
Westvleteren Extra 8 is clearly an elegant and sophisticated beer.

Bottle. Dark brown. Spicy dark brown malty, ryeish dry bread with some woody and candi tones. chocolate and leather, dry well malty. Body medium. Tasty, complex. Lots of flavours, like going to a spice store; you could probably find a million things here. They sure know how to handle their yeast.-- bb/wp8

Bottle. Pours a dark and vaguely hazy brown with a small creamy head. Aroma is roasted malts with notes of bread and toffee. Creamy body with soft carbonation. Flavour is quite sweet with burned malts and sugar, as well as nuts, kandi, molassess and prunes, raisins and lots of dark fruity notes in the finish. Even though its decent enough, its still a bit of a disappointment.

Bottle 33cl. Pours a small off-white head that doesnt shrink at all, it just stays there! Amazing! Very dark copper/brown appearance, extremely hazy. Complex and deep aroma, malts, chocolate, plum, melon peel and other dark fruits. Taste is even better, again malts, plum and other dark fruits but also melon(!) yeast and dusty wood. Very full and wide mouth feel and a very oily, sticky palate. Bottle from 25-10-2010. And the head is STILL THERE. What kind of sorcery is this? Is this the power of God?
If young not so good. too malty syrup. but if you season it comes out really nice! complex!

Poured a deep reddish brown with a dense off white head. Aroma of roast malt, dark alcohol soaked fruit and some candy sweetness. Medium body, vanilla smooth, flavour of light cherry, red berries, very easy to drink with a pleasantly alcoholic buzz in the aftertaste.
UPDATED: JUL 28, 2016 Hazy brown pour with an offwhite head. Taste is roasted malts, dark fruit, caramel, raisins, honey, wood and nuts, licorice and spices.

At home in a trappist glass. Yes this is possibly as good as it gets. Ive had the 12 at the abbey as well and there are no real differences between them. Now all I need to do is wait for the bottles to age some to see if it gets better.

bottle cap dated 8/02/11through trade. Pour has an earthy brown color with a coating of tan head and steady visible carbonation. Great excuse to break out the chalice glass! Aroma has dark brown malt, clean yeast, dark fruit, raisin, and light sweetness. Gentle but rich and deep. Mouth feel is medium with medium carbonation. Flavor brings on nice brown malt, caramel sweetness, raisin, brown sugar, dark dried fruit, clean spicy yeast, and some earth. Nicely toned down from the 12 with a center on lighter malts and the dark fruit being much more muted. Exceptional beer with great balance.

Had some of sips from a friends glass at In de Vrede. I was the lucky designated driver. Poured dark brown with decent dark tan lacing. Nose included malt and a hint of wort at first (it was, surprisingly, served a bit too cold). Aroma, as it got bit warmer: Cherry, a small amount of coffee, a hint of belgian style yeast, other dark fruits. Frizzy carbonation, which I like in this kind of beer. Sweet. A very, very good beer.
Bottle 0.33l at William K Annankatu, Helsinki. Colour is brown with very small white head. Aromas and flavours: Dark fruits, plums, raisins, sweetness and malts. Very soft and gentle.
Dark, golden brown, offwhite head. Wort nose, hint of coffee. Dark chocolate, coffee, leather taste, hint of wort, present alcohol. Taste is long lasting.

glass at the Abbey. Poured a rich dark brown with a very thick tan head that lingered until the last mouthful. aroma is of nuts, malts and yeast. tastes excellent. lingering, rich, full mouth feel. thick velvety texture and again, quite nutty. perfect balance of bitterness and sweetness.

Bottle from Voldby Koebmandsgaard. This great beer pours mahogany colour with a thick light beige head. Very nice malty and fruity taste. Nice warming alcohol and notes of nuts/caramel. An excellent beer.
surely one of the 10 best beers in the world. aroma, taste, appearance are 10 and praise, shame about the high price (15euros), but probably because of the rarity uà. odyssey for it

Bottle. Cap says "25 04 11," so I believe that makes it a bit over five years old. Gushed on me in spite of being stored at 55 degrees since I acquired it a few years ago. Pours dark brown with off-white head. Plenty of floaties in here that detract from the appearance. Aroma is very bright and fruity. Not quite as full of dark fruit as Rochefort 10, which I had recently so is my only decent, recent comparison, in spite of the style difference. I actually prefer this based on aroma alone. Taste brings caramel and raisins after an initial burst of acidity from the carbonation. This burst becomes less prominent as the beer warms, which is a plus in my book. Palate is full in spite of the spritziness from the carbonation. Finish brings a light astringency to go along with the dark malt flavors. I will say this beer is super drinkable, which for beers of this heft typically fall into the double IPA category for me these days. The flavor profile here reminds me of my favorite BSAs, Abbaye de Rocs Brune (also full of floaties) and Pannepot, but falls a little short. The carbonation and the astringent finish knock it down from that pantheon for me. Still, this is a great beer and one Id drink for the Belgian price all the time. Need to see how this tastes when fresher.
A very nice beer. Definitely see why this beer is so highly rated. Ticks all the right boxes, so well put together. IMO better than the 12.

UPDATED: JUN 29, 2014 Westvleteren 12?s little brother, for ever doomed to stand in it?s shadow. But there is no shame in standing in such a tasty shadow. The 8 is only a little different from the 12, which makes it an outstanding beer.
thick brown, with small chunks, may be from overaging. strong carbonation, and smell. silky smooth flavor lasts on palate.

Sampled at my buddy Jon Upsons 30th birthday bottle share. Thanks to his brother Mike for bringing this one. Pours a brownish-red color with a thin layer of beige foam. Aroma of nice caramel and toffee, dark sticky fruit, and lesser notes of vanilla and pipe tobacco. Flavor has more dark fruit, lovely caramel, and brown sugar. The spritzy carbonation is a bit surprising but really adds to the flavor experience. Alcohol completely hidden. Very nice prelude to the XII which followed at our tasting. (1568, 797)

Bière brune, opaque, avec de minces reflets cuivrés. La mousse est abondante, mais éphémère; leffervescence est soutenue. Le nez apparaît sec et sucré (fruité) avec un peu de gomme baloune en superficie. En bouche, la complexité bat son plein : caramel, fruits rouges, sucre dorge, grains fumés, épices, alcool  le tout soutenu par un pétillement délicat ainsi quune finale sèche et raffinée . Étant donné que cest toujours un honneur de boire une Westvleteren, on ne peut faire autrement quapprécier et célébrer!
Very pleasant bread malt aroma. Good sweet-bitter balance in taste. Full body; long somewhat bitter finish.
The head is ok, body brown and yeasty. It smells belgian yeasty, a bit fruity, alcoholic, dry. Taste is Alcoholic-dry, a lot of CO2, yeasty, interesting. Good. 12/12/11/12/11/12

Bottle ordered from internet opened on 4th of July Appt in Buffalo. Pours a dark deep copper with chunks of yeast floating amid dark orange/red hues like a lava lamp (or a yeast lamp) leaving a creamy head to top it off. Amazing aromas of sweet cherry, plum, Belgian yeast, caramel, toffee, and overall dark fruits. Flavors of big plumb, fig, dark cherry, dark fruits overall, caramel, slight mellowed spice of coriander, just a faint hint of alcohol in the nose and aftertaste. Light to medium sweet. Light to medium bitter finish. Not much of an aftertaste overall. For what this beer stands for and what you might imagine, I think it just meets those expectations. After having many from this style and beers overall, I think many come close to match in flavor and complexity. Not quite my favorite but I would say top 10. The fragrant aromas are my favorite part. I think the aromas are the best Ive found in this style and for almost any beer overall. Beautifully made from men Ill bet, admire what they do and above all Love God.

Bottle to glass. Pours a hazy nut brown color with a thick creamy tan head. Aroma is a roasty nutty yeasty character with a faint hint of alcohol. Taste is a moderate nutty sweetness that lasts long into the finish with a medium body. Upon first try, I prefer it to the 12, but I will likely re-rate after trying each of them again.

These were brought back from Sweden by a friend, not sure how long they had been in Sweden though. A solid brown beer with reddish hues, and a generous tan head dominate the visual experience. The aroma is yeast, sugar, plums, molasses and bread. The flavour is very malty, very much dark fruits. An excellent beer to end the evening with.
To hard to buy, but so good. I drink it with trapist cheese great !!!

Bottle that I found somewhere in Europe. Pours a dark, viscous brown with a small tan head. Aroma: rich and malty, red grapes stand out although theyre the most prominent fruit aspect. Flavour: really nice dark malt/fruit combo that blends well with nothing taking the lead, red grapes again with some dry yeast in the finish and lingering sourdough notes. It feels quite big in terms of a thicker, oily feel that is interesting. The booze is definitely present although it doesnt bother me. Very good and Im sure its masterfully crafted but it really didnt blow me away, especially for how much I paid and had to go through to find it.

bottle shared by fred82, thanks! end of life bottle. pours almost clear copper with a decent light beige head, some retention. minty caramel, spices, funk and cherries, pepper, some coconut. bright to average carbonation, light body and lightly boozy. obviously infected and very few remaining sugars.. still quite nice and really enjoyable but would like to taste it again for an accurate rating.

Cafe in de Vrede, April 2013, fresh comparison of all three Westvleteren. Hazy brown with a lasting tan head. Aroma of caramel, dark sugar, chocolate and dried fruit, plum and prunes, and a touch of spice. Sweet malty flavour with caramel, toffee and nuts, along with a spicy touch. Well balanced flavour
Veel van verwacht, niet uiterst speciaal, voor mij gewoon als ieder ander dubbel bier.

Head: beige, medium, frothy, avg. retention. Colour: dirty dark brown, cloudy. 

Aroma: dried fruit, raisins, sourish berries, almond. Taste: moderate sweetness, dried fruit, light roasty bitterness, warming alcohol, spicy. The body is medium (and lighter than expected).

A nice rich beer, but a bit overrated.

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2015 Color: dark caramel beer with small brown head and no carbonation. Smell: caramel, malt, wheat and rye bread. Taste: strong caramel and malt aroma, with spices, easy to drink and really floral. Aftertaste: wheat, malt and bread.

Bottle at home. Had many bottles before but this is my first rate. Hazy but brown copper colour thin whispy cream head. Aroma of bubblegum raisin with toasty notes. Flavour is rich and deep raisin bread caramel . some apples. Crisp really dry finish. Nice Belgian yeast profile. Yum.

My favourite Westvleteren beer. Intensely rich in flavour, aroma and palate with a pleasant lingering taste. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

bottled. A precious and kind gift from Cuso for my thirsty-five b(eer)-day. Thank you so much! This is Belgian beer perfection! Not so sweet as Rochefort beers which my wife is drinking now parallel to me so I can compare a bit. Overall this beer is utterly fantastic!
Strong fruit flavor.  Great mouthfeel.  Expert blend of sweetness and bitterness.  Goes down smooth.

Pours deep mahogany brown with a thin cream colored head. Nose of pitted fruit, light pepper. Taste adds vanilla. Body is big but ultra silky. As my wife puts it... I cant believe I ticked 3 from the monks of westvlertern.

15 CL glass at Trappist- en Kaasproeverij Hamont-Achel at  18-05-2013, Dark beer with a sweet aroma, taste was good, Actually prefer this better than the 12. But, there are better beers out there.
light brown head that disappears quickly without lacing. brown colour. sweet aroma, esters, yeast and melon. slight sweet taste, followed by bitterness and estery, malts!
As first strikes me the delicious freshness of this beer. Next to the freshness there is a good balance off spiciness. Taste of maturity and just the right bitterness.

Bottle.
Appearance: Dark brown body, thin tan head.
Aroma: Apples, lots of fruit.
Taste: Apples on the intro, really fruity into a sweet caramel that just drops off to a dry airy finish with sugar lingering, beautiful.
Palate: Full bodied to light and fizzy.
Overall: Best dubbel Ive ever had, next level shit.

Bottle from Belgium in a Box; hazy brown pour with beige velvety head, fruity aroma with big alcohol aroma, very pleasing taste dried fruits prune and dates superbly balanced with malts alcohol is present in abundance but very pleasant.
Bottle from Kingcecil, thanks buddy. Hazy mud brown with a medium offwhite head. Aroma is yeast, toffee, fruit, darkfruit. Flavor is raisins, dark fruit, yeast, tart, alcohol notes. Smooth.

33cl bottle. Hazy brown with medium, ivory grey head. Nose : toffee, cooked cherries and multitude of other fruits like apples for example, tart, yeast. Sip : oily and smooth. Good carbonation. The sip is warming. It's sweet and fruity. It has fruity and spicy background. I understand the fuss about it and for some reasons I might even say I prefer this one then the 12. Great beer.

UPDATED: AUG 17, 2014 BBE 17.08.15, quite new bottle. A dark brown beer with a medium and beige head. Aroma starts with dark fruit and some green and sour apples, spices, some sweetness, with yeast also some bananas. Taste is quite dry, dark fruits, lots of spices and herbs, earthyness and some apple like sourness. Medium bodied, high carbonation, still nice and smooth to drink. A very good beer, but not the climax. Orvals nuancees, dark fruits with some apples sourness and mystic of Trappist. Edit at 17.8.2014, BBE 05.03.16, points 40 -> 41.

330 ml bottle - tasted at numerous occasions. A bit more complex than the 12, more balanced sour-sweet complexity. Aromas and taste of malts, caramel, earthy notes are more complex than the 12. But there are better beers. Overhyped, but not as much as the 12 :-).

Dark, chocolate colored beer, but ruby-like red hold against the light. Sweet aroma of sugar and alcohol. It tastes sweet and like licorice. Slightly bitter aftertaste. 

Donker, chocoladekleurig bier, maar robijnrood in het licht. Vrij zoet aroma van suiker en alcohol De smaak is eveneens zoet en dropachtig, met een bittere nasmaak

330 ml bottle received as a bonus when shopping @ beerplanet.be. Pours very hazy chestnut brown with a frothy creamy beige head that is rather quick to dissipate while leaving some thick lacing on the glass. Smell is sweet and malty with crackers, oatmeal cookies, cereal, raisins, figs, sweet dark bread, golden syrup, bilberry jam and hints of alcohol. Taste is sweet, very tiny bitter, tiny fruity and malty witch crackers, cereal, oatmeal cookies, sweet dark bread, golden syrup, biscuits, pureed prunes, raisins, figs, pancakes with bilberry jam, honey and hints of alcohol. Mouthfeel is smooth, soft, round and medium to full bodied. Finish is sweet, tiny bitter, very tiny tart, fruity and malty with crackers, cereal, oatmeal cookies, biscuits, prunes, raisins, lemon zest, wood, figs and alcohol. Expertly crafted incredibly balanced beer but there always seems to be something I find myself missing when trying the Westvleteren beers. Perhaps its just the legendary hype that is hard to live up to.

light brown head that disappears quickly without lacing. brown colour. sweet aroma, esters, yeast and melon. slight sweet taste, followed by bitterness and ester, melon.  bottle 33 cl / notes from backlog
dark brown, hazy, quickly disappearing head. aroma more fruity than the wv 12, citrus. feels sharper on your tongue, sweet taste, bittersweet finish.
From bottle at In De Vrede in Westvleteren. Poured dark brown with a tan head. Aromas with sweet fruity notes, caramel, brown sugar, roasted malts and yeast. Great balance and truly an amazing beer.

Pours a nice brown beer with a good white head. It smells a bit like droves. Dark fruits. A bit vanilla.  
The taste is medium sweet abd light bitter. Not a very common taste. A bit to sweet. The palate is awesome.  Good carbo and a nice medium body. Bit sticky texture. I like the blond more but still this is a good one.

2010 bottle, 04/12/2013. Pours dark amber, ruby highlights, fizzy off-white head, dense lacing around the glass, active carbonation. Aroma of dried fruits, earthy honey and nutty chocolate, yeast and spice. Taste is dark fruity malts, apple, light honey yeast notes, certain chocolate and herbal bitterness to round things out. Medium palate, fluffy carbonation. Nice and refined, but not quite the complexity and depth of 12.
Bottle off the shelf. Who knew it was possible?  Looks and smells like amazing Belgique.  Sweet and fruity.
30/3/13 In de vrede: dark red color with ivory creamy head. Red fruit, malt and alchol aroma. Sweet with caramel flavour.

Bottle 330ml.
Pours brown with low beige head. Good lacing. Aroma is of plums, fruits, figs, raisins, alcohol, caramel, yeast. Taste is of plums, figs, raisins, alcohol, bread, spices, yeast. Palate: Medium-full bodied. Somewhat sticky. Overall: Very good. Nice fruits. A nice, serious and classy beer.

zwart, met schuimig bruine kraag
aroma: moutig, zoet, chocolade, rozijnen, wijn, donker fruit
smaken: kandij suiker, hopbittertje, donkere fruiten, banaan, rozijn, karamel, drop, chocolade
volle body, normale co2
prima bier
At In de Vrede.  A bit more subdued than the XII, with dominating prune/raisin in the taste.  This could use some time, too.  Has a lot of potential, though!

Bottle (330 ml). Clear ruby brown with a small fully lasting off-white head and decent lacing. Aroma is extremely complex and full of plums, figs, raisins, dark fruits, caramel and slight spices notes. Taste is moderately sweet with, again, plums, figs, raisins, dark fruits, caramel and slight spices. Its less intense than aroma though. Medium body. Slight alcohol/spices warming. Great complexity here. Very good Belgian Strong Ale. I would love to drink this on a regular basis.

Bottle. Chestnut brown with a thick bubbly good lacing beige head. Aroma is plums, prunes, dates, brown sugar, light dark chocolate, some light berries in the background; blackcurrant, cherry. Taste is medium sweet and light+ bitter. Medium+ body, soft oily texture, medium carbonation. Some light warming alcohol. Light bitter fruity finish.

Smaller than expected aroma and dark amber pour with an easy drinking, smooth taste and comfortable, barely there mouthfeel

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: JUL 6, 2015 March 2013 - Room temp bottle BBE 08/15. Small head that endures. Makes a crackling sound like Rice Crispies. Dark brown with a little redness when held to light. Mild carbonation. Smells yeasty. Mid to full body, and foamy in mouth. Taste is very mild, malty and slightly sweet, raisin, cardboard.  (3.7)
June 2015 - 2010 vintage, bottle share thanks to Paul.  Taste has a little mint and spice, apple, paper, dust, talc. (3.7)
June 2015 -2010 vintage, bottle share thanks to Fergus.  Taste is malty, dusty.  Mellow, semisweet and drinkable.  The extra sweetness just lifted this one a bit.  (3.8)

330ml bottle courtesy of MrHangover. Thanks Johan! Pours a murky off dark brown color with light brown head. Aroma of dark fruit is prevalent here with sweet malts and some caramel. Taste is also dark fruit, sweet malts, and a sourness at the end thats not overpowering.

Uploading old ratings that were missing comments. Nice and dark. Bready with hints of dark fruit. Almost prefer this to the 12 because the alcohol is a little more under control. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

The aroma is fruity and hoppy the beer colour is dark with a creamy foam head. The higher alcohols are not so pertinent present as in the 12 version.
The beer has a dry hoppy aftertaste that is present for a long time on the palet.  

---Rated By the Belleketels
Very dark with little head. Hints of caramel and dark fruits in this beer as well as a certain breadiness. Somewhat comparable to the 12.

Extremely well balanced. Good after taste. We are fortunate we could get our hands on a few bottles. Cheers! 
Pretty lable btw ;-)

1979 Vintage (I believe brewed at Bernardus) enjoyed in a taster at Kulminator

A -  Clear dark brown. No head. Completely Flat

S - Loads of raisins and figs. Very sweet and fruity wow. Smells amazing 

T -  Very oxidized. Caramel cardboard. Peaches and kiwi. Tropical fruits. Lots of honey and lovely recycled paper. 

M - Totally flat. Not a lot going on

O - Despite the oxidation, this is a very enjoyable beer.

Bottle (notes from tasting session). Very distinctive aroma of rye bread and  yeast. Flavors are rich and smooth: candi sugar, caramel, and mild coffee -- and they carriy on to the final. Very long aftertaste. Really an exceptional brew.

Pours murky brown with a small white head. Nose is raisins, cinammon, cloves, banana and hay. The taste is sweet with a little bitter. The mouthfeel is crisp and clean, medium body an a long finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

33cL bottle, from bigtomz.. belgian strong ale that is so silky smooth and drinkable its really hard to put fingers on the flavors as they are so well melded together. but this leads to a somewhat nuanced beer with no major flavor sticking out to me.
Dark brown colored beer with a very small beige head. Spicy herbal aroma. Herbal sweet taste. Some caramel and dark fruits. Medium sweet spicy aftertaste.

Got a zip from a bottle, which was awesome.
The beer is quite leathery and astringent but in a nice way. The color  and palate is overwhelming. Everything is perfect with this brew.
What a coinciden to get this rare Belgian beer, here in the US

2013/02/01 - Pours a typical Trappist hazy dark brown/red with a foamy tan head that disappears quickly. Aroma is toffee, nuts and dark fruits (mainly grapes). Taste is similar to smell, with lots of carbonation and a smooth finish. Very nice. Prefer the XII. Need to compare to Rochefort 8...

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2013 I just had this beer and i have to accept its absolutely one of the best beers I ever tasted. Only the Sint Bernardus 12 seems to be close. The taste is very full and has a kind of wooden taste. The Westvleteren 8 is absolutely more fruity, but less exceptionnal. I absolutely recommend the beer and the website that helped me to get the beer for a good price (even if i dont know if this is allowed in my review: http://www.westvleterenshop.com ) Enjoye

Bottle at North Bar, Leeds. Pours a deep, murky brown with q small head from that silly yet enigmatic bottle. Aroma is dark/red fruits, dark malt, Belgian yeast and esters. Taste is classic quad - caramel and malts up front with a nice balancing bitterness, dark fruits in the middle and a long, bitter finish. Medium bodied. Its good, but not on a Rochefort 10/Westy 12 sort of level.

One of many different beers shared with a good friend over Christmas. Pours a dark brown with red notes shining through. The aroma is deep and in my opinion with more variations than the XII, toffee notes, fruity, malty, to put it in one word lovely. Aroma, taste and carbonation come together and you instantly get the impression that this (and of course the big brother XII) is something special.

Bought in decembre 2 cases, today i drunk it for the first time, i live 10 km from westmalle and will drive next time again 200 km to vleteren.
The beer is amazing and well balanced

Beer bought at In de Vrede café by the brewery. Pours dark mahogany with sone red tints. The beer gives a good frothy head that settles into a noce layer throughout the session. The aroma is slightly discrete, as the 12, but provides more content. Roasted notes, some dried fruit and chocolate?  The taste is malty and roasted, bitterness is combining with some dried fruit to balance it. In this sense it reminds a lot of the 12, which also balances sweetness and bitterness superbly. The bitterness turns into licorice in the aftertaste. The palate is soft, not overly effevescent, medium bodied. The 8 was tasted side-by-side with a 12, and it shares so many things I think it is brewed more or less by the same recipe, but just 2% lower in alcohol. Its a great beer, underrated next to the 12, but defintely not far from it. It is a little more bitter, a little less tastier, and doesnt reach as far as the 12. But it is a great beer, rustic but better than the Rochefort 8 and the Westmalle Dubbel.
Bottle. Pours slightly cloudy brown with thin tan head. Aroma is fruits, licorice, spices, nuts, malt. Flavor is malt, overripe fruits, yeast, spices.

Bottle courtesy of totoropanda.  Thanks Daniel.  Pours a dark amber with small tan head that has decent retention and leaves a good amount of lacing on the glass.  The aroma is fruity with raisin and plum, some caramel, and some light oxidation.  The taste is mildly sweet with raisin plum, and a bit of caramel.  The finish is slightly dry with a light bitterness. Medium body.  Medium-low carbonation.  Good.  Like a slightly toned down version of Westy 12.
Buenisima cerveza belga, totalmente a la altura de su hermana mayor. Es un delito quedarse solo en la 12. Personalmente encuentro cosas parecidas entre las dos.
UPDATED: FEB 16, 2014 Aroma of belgium sugars. Taste is the same with malt and raisin. Lots of dark fruits and berry flavours as it warms. Like a more refined Chimay Blue.

Bottle from Beer Mania (Brussels, Belgium)

Thick head, though it recedes quickly. Color is dark brown, a bit hazy. Taste is sweet; hints of caramel and nuts. Very sweet. I prefer this over the 12.

Redelijk grote lichtbruine schuimkop die uiteindelijk verdwijnt op een romig bruin bier met een rode gloed. Zweven veel gistresten in het glas. Aroma van friszure appels, perzik, rozijnen, laurier en vanille. Smaak start fris door het koolzuur. Vervolgens rozijnen, banaan, toffee en wat drop/laurier. Alcohol zeker aanwezig, maar niet vervelend. Zeer lekker bier en goed complex.

Aldus Huubs.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Dark browne with small light brown foam head. Aroma is strong bittersweet, caramel. Taste is nice bitter with just enough sweet caramel. Long dry small bitter aftertaste. (Velp 201301)
Poured from 11oz bottle.  Pours cola brown with a bit of beige head.  Aroma is vanilla, dried apples and belgian yeast.  Taste follows with lots of vanilla and dried fruit.  Good stuff.
bottle, 33cl @ home. Pours dark reddish brown, medium head. Yeast, toffee in the aroma, Caramel, spices licorice in the flavor. Quite high carbonation.

Bottle 33 cl. Pours reddish brown in color with a thin off-white head. Dark bready malty, dough, dark dried sweet fruits and some yeasty notes in aroma. Sweet maltyness with hints of some dark fruitiness of dadels in taste at first. Dark bready notes as well as some marzipan in taste also. Has a long-lasting dark bready, even slightly bitter and malty aftertaste. Smooth and delicious.

Deep, cloudy burgundy pour with flecks of yeast and sediment bouncing around the glass. Aroma: huge, complex set of aromas. Caramel, redcurrant, oak, vinous, hops, malt, banana and apple.
Taste: slightly dry with a decent alcohol warmth.  Toffee, hops, creamy malt, banana, apple, red grapes.

Superb

23.11.12. Bottle. Cream-colored, pretty thick foam. The beer is a bit hazy and brown. Aroma malty, some banana, sweetish; very nice. Flavors include marzipan, some alcohol, candy pear, a bit of yeast. Not as sweet as I expected based on the aroma. Smooth mouthfeel, hardly any carbonation. Aftertaste is a bit dry bitter and sweet, and even a bit sour.Overall, definitely a great beer, but I prefer sweeter in this style.

Bottle, fresh from abbey that day. Aroma is toffee notes, banana, other esters, touch of apple, grapes, slightly alcoholic but not as much as the 12. Appearance has a nice fawn head, beautiful deep brown colour, almost clear, touch of lace. Taste is a touch too alcoholic - could really do with some ageing, but still very nice young, I get grape, toffee, caramel and banana and apple, much like the nose. Palate is nice pleasant mild bitterness around mouth which perfectly complements the tastes. Overall, great, for me though, would be nicer than the 12 with a few months in the cellar to take the edge of the alcohol notes.

not exactly the be all and end all. carbonation was quite high would have preferred less bubbles, tasted very nice slightly reminiscent of dandelion and burdock . nice beer but perhaps not quite to my palate

UPDATED: APR 6, 2014 
33 cl bottle. BBE 30.09.2012.
Lots and lots of ripe fruits burst out as the bottle is opened. Still quite lively and a bit fizzy. Caramel malts and toffee on the nose as well. Sourish malts and ripe fruits still on the flavor front, not as spicy though. Licorice is not really present anymore. Some complexity and flavors lost, somewhat better when a bit more fresh. Very tasty anyway.
Rating: 8-5-8-4-17 = 42

33 cl bottle. BBE 12.05.2013.
Originally rated on 20091227. (9-5-9-4-18)
Pours clear (without the yeast) mahogany red color with a medium-sized head, leaves some lacing. Lots of barnyard elements on the nose, sourish malts, yeast, a bit of toffee, sweet caramel and lots of ripe fruits. Some licorice and spices on the background also.
Flavor of caramel malts, spices, yeast, licorice, ripe and somewhat dried fruits and some subtle grassy notes. Very smooth palate with a sourish finish. Very complex and refined brew which seems to be at almost perfect age. Top notch.
5348

33cl bottle from Kurt,Belgiuminabox.This bottle was aged  for well over 3 years and tasted better than the young 12 which i drank on the same night (no patience,just had to try it but if improvement is the same after 3 years with the 12 as with this one it wll be superb).
This poured a dark brown and sported a thick beige head which only lasted briefly.Roast malt was apparent immediately on the nose with chocolate and fruit also well represented.A lovely port like aroma was also in there making a lovely mixture.Roast malt was there in the taste along with coffee and nuts giving a nice bitterness which was balanced by a plum like fruitiness.Figs and alcohol were also well in the mix and made for a superby rounded and well balanced lovely tasting beer.
Plum and clove nose, not strong. Cloudy rust, thick yellow head good retention. Plum and tobacco flavor. Smooth and flavorful.

Smaller than expected aroma and dark amber pour with an easy drinking, smooth taste and comfortable, barely there mouthfeel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

[Thanks to fonefan]. Dark brown colour with a initial good formation of an off-white head, but quickly diminishing. Aroma has red fruits notes, slightly toasty with some citrus traces, yeasty and ripe fruit. Flavor has almonds and nuts notes, yeasty, brown sugar, sweet, raisins with notes of plumbcake. On palate results smooth, moderate dense and creamy. The final is fruity and slightly dry. Carbonation is low to medium. Body is high. Texture is oily.

11.2oz bottle from richdorchak, thanks Rich! 06.04.14 stamped on the cap (bottled on April 6, 2011). Pours a cloudy, rich and glowing, dark brown-amber colored body with a finger-width, dense, rocky, creamy and frothy, tannish beige head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is raisins, dried prunes, sour dough bread, banana, yeast spice, alcohol notes, deep caramels, touches of chocolate, cherry, some bitter and herbal hops, and plums with a hint of tartness. Flavor is similar. Spicy yeast with lots of dried prunes, raisins, sour dough bread, deep caramels, and light alcohol notes. A few banana hints, touches of plums and cherries, a light layer of chocolate, and a very light touch of tobacco. Finishes smooth, lightly dry and bitter, somewhat spicy, and lightly sweetened with a bunch of dried dark fruits. Lengthy aftertaste following a medium-full body and a soft, somewhat lively carbonation. Overall, a pretty excellent beer that is complex, smooth, dry, and somewhat bitter while maintaining a perfect balance with a rich dried fruit and sour dough bready malt backing. Fantastic.
Shared from a bottle at home.  Vintage 2010.  Pours a dark  reddish brown with an off white head.  Aroma of raisins and cola.  Sweet candy sugar, dark fruits and toffee.  Beautiful.

Duft af blommer, abrikos, rosiner og rapadura. Lys brun uden skum med sedimenter. Smager fremragende af tørrede frugter og er meget sød.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
This a great beer with a perfect balance. It tastes sweet and one can sence aroma of sugar and brown sugar.

Classic trappist - dark dried fruits and some apple, kandis, brown and no foam, rich taste of the before mentioned, alc.
Good beer
This is a Great beer! Has the taste of mostly brown things and overall it just grows and grows.
Classic belgian ale. I must-drink for any beer enthusiast. Full bodied and brown aromas with dried fruits and leather notes.
Dont have so much aroma but tastes of lovely dark fruites. Sparkling but do still have a good body. Great beer
Yo no sé que le echan los monjes de este monasterio a sus brebajes, pero la hermana pequeña de la impresionante Westvleteren 12 es una cerveza espectacular.

Purchased at de Bier Tempel in Brussels, BE; enjoyed on my last night in Europe on an extended work trip.  This is the last of the 3 Westvleteren brews Ive had on this trip.  Appearance is a dark, murky cola brown with a rich and billowy off white head that laces to the glass.  Aroma of licorice, dark plums, chocolate, cocoa, tropical fruits, raisins, Ive seen marzipan in another rating and I agree.  I dont know what these monks have thrown into this, but it smells like its from another world.  Taste is very surprising, I dont know what to make of it.  Theres an obvious dark fruit impact with a light burn from the alcohol, and its pretty thick, with a raisin tone and high carbonation.  Theres so much going on that I cant really pinpoint any one ingredient, and its like a big mash of different ingredients.  Pretty damn good stuff, the 12 is still my fav.

Pours dark cola brown with a small off white.  Aromas of rye bread and dried fruit.  Yum.  Some barnyard fun flavours.  Earthy, some herbs, grass and hey.....Hay!  Great mouthfeel and nice concentration.
Bottle. Pours murky brown. Taste and aroma are both dried fruit hop and some old leather I like this over 12
liquoricey, dark dried fruit, spice, caramel-mellow, balanced, too drinkable!

not much scent or even taste. bit sweer, sugar, warmth ( alcohol?? ) 
drank westy 12, drank westy 8... why the hell is evryone so much into this? rochefort is like a thousand times better....
Trying to avoid the cliché, but this really is like a lighter version of a 12. The palate is thinner, the liquorice and fruit notes lack the intensity. Very very good, but not as good as the 12.

330ml bottle. 19.10.11. This one pours a murky gold with a huge head. It is also a gusher upon opening. It smells like brett, not sure if it is supposed to be this way. Very much like an Orval. The flavor is not so bretty. It is a easy-drinking blond ale. The yeast is pretty prevalent though. Overall it is a shadow of the 12 and even Orval, but it is still a great beer.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ One finger beige foam. Brown haze. Caramalty notes. Sour dry spicy taste. Great balance. Thought it would be more complex. Will rerate later with less of a cold.

First had this beer at the abbey in 2010 and loved it almost as much as the W12. Purchased bottles at the abbey yesterday on return visit. Only allowed one 6-pack of W12 and one of W8. Poured from bottle into signature glass. Medium-tan head on a deep brown beer. Head is of fine bubbles and doesnt stick for long. Aroma is very pleasing and equally subtle. Palate is incredibly soft. Having drank a few glasses of W12 yesterday (and from what I remember about having these before), the W8 is really very similar to the W12, just with everything dialed back a notch. Really fantastic beer: balanced and smooth.

Bottle as gift, purchased at bierkoning Amsterdam. Pours unclear brown with short lasting head. Aroma is very nice, fruitier than 12, dried fruit, raisins, marzipan. Taste has yeast, leather, marzipan, plum, sultana. Light sweetness with a clan finish. Very nice and quite unique. Preferred to 12

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a Trappist glass. Pours a dark brown with a creamy, khaki colored head of foam. The aroma has a nice herbal, earthy, somewhat floral mint note to it on top of the heavy roasty and caramel notes. Taste is interestingly minty. I like that. I can safely say I did not expect this beer to be quite what it turned out to be, but I find that I enjoy it very much.

Partiamo col dire che è una branda di birra. Se la vedete, dovete comprarla. Trovarla al supermercato mi stupi non poco e rimasi in trance per circa un quarto dora a fissarla finchè non la comprai, tornando tutto baldanzoso e contento a casa. Aprendo la bottiglia fuoriesce un aroma potentissimo in grado di far riscrescere i capelli a un calvo o di far passare un raffreddore a un influenzato. Al naso comunque si presentano noti alcoliche, di lieviti con effluvi tannici e con una nota finale di frutti di bosco (soprattutto more e lamponi). Presenta un colore mogano con riflessi rubino.Lingresso in bocca è meraviglioso complessissimo e carbonato. Il gusto è fruttato: di nuovo frutti di bosco e prugne con un leggero sentore di brandy. Vira verso una note speziate nel finale con una leggera luppolatura che pulisce il tutto. Complessissima e indescrivibile: fate prima ad assaggiarla voi stessi. Grazie monaci trappisti, siete bellissimi.

Dark amber/brown color; Medium creamy body; Aroma of sweet malt, yeast, dark fruit, caramel, & spice; Flavor of sweet malt, yeast, dark fruit (notably plums), rich caramel, raisons, spice, and some chocolate, Slight alcohol at the finish; Nicely balanced and complex; Awesome brew - I enjoyed it.

Bottle at home. Courtasy of Beer Planet, Brussels. Pours a pretty hazy reddish dark brown head, with a medium beige and very carbonated head that fades fast. Sweet and malty aroma with wort, dried fruits, bread, biscuits, blackberries, leather and some alcohol and oranges. Rich flavours with more wood, oak, nuts, dried fruits and alcohol. Soft and slick mouthfeel, and a just below medium bitterness. Rich and surprisingly easy-drinking, and more bitter than expected. Fantastic, balanced and complex!

Super excited to find this at a small store in Amsterdam.  Essentially a slightly lighter 12; phenomenally drinkable and flavorful.  Pours semi translucent purple very little head.  Smells great, sweet apple and plum with some yeast.  Palate is also very fruity quite drinkable and finishes dry.  Super tasty.

(33 cl bottle from Belgisk Bryg, one year old) Pours dark brown with frothy, tan head. Good retention and impressive lacework. Aroma is malty with notes of crayon, chalk and hints of caramel. Oily texture, soft carbonation, full body and a lingering caramel finish. Taste is balsamic and sweet. I prefer the corresponding Rochefort by great lengths.

Appearance was cloudy deep orangish brown with diminishing creamy tannish 1 finger head, spotty lacing. Aromas are heaven in a bottle. Honey, spices, cherry, peach, fig, caramel malt, no alcohol present. Taste is liquid gold with honey, caramel malty backbone, then the deep fruity yeasts shine through with fig, peach, cherry softly. Palate was soft smooth CO2 with balanced body, then average lasting glorious fruity malty finish. A masterpiece...
Bottle best before jan 2015.  Complex flavor in a nice well rounded beer.  What can I say, its perfect.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Ariels place. Thanks Lee. Best before 11/19/13. 2 years old. Pours orange to brown with a thick beige head, aroma is sourish with cherries, wheat, vanilla and wood, flavor is sweet and spicy with chocolate, cherries and some spices, dried fruits, medium to full bodied 7/4/7/4/14[3.6]

Re-rate 9/8/12: Bottle sample at a tasting at Ariels place. Thanks Lee. Best before 9/22/10. 5 years old. Pours an hazy brown with a nice head, aroma of honey, dry fruits, cognac, vanilla and nuts, flavor of chcolate, dried fruits, honey, cognac, light spices, medium to full bodied 8/3/7/4/14[3.6]
Aroma of apples and peaches, same dark brown color as the 12, but smooth and fruity. No alcoohol burn to be noticed. Acompanied with the apple tart...a mix made in heaven!

Bouteille de 33 cl. Merci beaucoup à Dany et Marie-France. Arômes très complexes de fruits confis, de pruneaux, de raisins secs et de caramel. Robe rubis et plutôt limpide, belle mousse et effervescence assez active. Très fruitée en bouche, on retrouve en avant-plan la contribution du sucre candi, tout en fruits confis et en raisins secs. Belle présence de caramel brûlé et quelques notes chocolatées. Très belle texture en bouche. Finale relativement sèche et maltée. Excellente, je préfère personnellement cette 8 à la Westvleteren 12.

Bottle (330ml) into Trappist glass. Murky brown appearance with stable cream-white head providing a decent lace. I get candy sugar, caramel, alcohol, cherries, plums and figs on the nose. The palate is medium bodied with a gorgeous velvety smooth mouthfeel and a moderately sweet flavour profile. Finishes with a subtle spicy hop bitterness and a hint of alcohol.
Matches the hype associated with this brewery.

Bottiglia 33 cl.
Appena sotto alla sorella maggiore...marrone scuro con schiuma beige poco persistente.
Al naso è molto intensa, persistente e complessa: prugna e fichi secchi, tamarindo, datteri, spezie.
Quasi secca in bocca, corpo medio, grande corrispondenza retrolfattiva e lunga persistenza.....Ottima!

Dark look, clear brown with gold-to-clear highlights,, flavors suggest cola and sasparilla, cherries, has a delicious fruit-spice balance. Sweetness offset by some steely dry hops. Stone-cellar minerality, and it shows a bit of brie-like mushroom in the nose., shows on palate as well. Winey and complete with a surprisingly (Burgundian?) med-light feel, perhaps a touch dilute, and the moderately sweet finish winding down with a burlappy dry hop signature. Actually refreshes while it nourishes my hot yoga-worked body. Aroma also some wild barnyard.

UPDATED: APR 10, 2014 On bottle at Cafekee,Madrid and related with bottle from Vinmonopolet Vika 2013.
Dark golden color, lots of sediments- good foam.
Malt, dry fruits, raisins in aroma, also some red berries and   yeast influence 
Full body & high complexity.
Some sweetness and balancing bitterness.
Long aftertaste.
Very enjoyable
Bottle (in NZ). For me, better than the 12. More spice from the yeast, and almost sourness. Very tasty indeed.

Poured from that distinctive Westy bottle into a Westvleteren chalice.

Westvleteren 8 pours a dense walnut brown color with a slight cranberry tint.  A creamy tan head forms gently on top with the initial pour.  There was a lot of sediment in the bottom of the bottle, to the point where it was difficult not to pour it in.

Caramel malt, figs, dates, overripe red apples, brandy, and cinnamon gust up my nose.

The flavor is more of the same.  The flavor is not as sweet as I would expect, though.  There is a bit of caramel up front providing a slightly sweet base, but the fig, date, red apple, cinnamon, and all spice do not provide enough sweetness to overcome the boozy brandy that comes through.  There is great integration of the flavors - a sign of long-perfected brewing processes.

The mouthfeel is pretty much perfect, for the style or otherwise.  The body is on the full side of medium, representing the 8% ABV quite accurately.  Each sip has a foamy, creamy carbonation with just a bit of a crisp, tingly bite to it to help ease the flavors down the tongue to reset after each sip.  Very smooth.

This is a wonderfully balanced and drinkable beer.  I am glad I finally cracked my bottle.

Pours a dark brown copper colour with a big creamy off white head with great retention. Strong aroma of dried fruit mostly plum also a bit of caramel  and tobacco notes. flavour is very smooth low carbonation light dried fruit with a nice sweetness and well balanced bitterness. also the alcohol is  barely noticeable. excellent beer look forward to trying the 12.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Ariels place. Thanks Lee. exp. 11/2013. Pours cloudy brown, off-white head. Spice, bergamot, tea, berries. Tastes sweet, deep and velvety. Smooth texture, hardly any carbonation, sleek, with a sweet finish.

33cl. Bottled, obviously. Great dark beer with smooth aroma of caramel and candy. Taste is smooth but still powerful. Roast fruits and slight carbonation, extremely well balanced, maybe the best balanced beer Ive ever tried, with a bitter aftertaste and slight remains of alcohol on the finish.
Wonderful !

330ml bottle. Pours out dark ruby with the classic fluffy head. Aroma is a bit weaker than expected but packs in caramel, cherries, peat, liquorice and burnt toast. Taste is very similar, and its creamy and well carbonated as expected. I just wish the flavours stood out a little more. Im detecting the right elements but they seem quite lethargic and dont grab me in the way that those of Westmalle Dubbel or St. Bernadus 8 did. This might be one I return to at a later date in case I missed something here.

Bottle dated 09.10.06, so a good 8 years aged and served at room temperature goblet (drank Jan 12) to a dark rich chestnut brown with almost a finger of white head, which soon thinned out.

Dark fruits, brown sugar, toffee, figs/dates on the nose.

Similar tastes to the smell, very noticeable is molasses. Getting hints of a whole menagerie of dried fruits ... prunes/apricot/figs/dates, burnt sugars, only ever so slightly in the burnt sense!

Mouthfeel is great, not too chewy at all. 
Plenty of lacing with the remnants of the head clinging to the glass.

Full of depth and character.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text:
01.03.15...making it a 03/01/2012 vintage. Split a bottle at a bar, poured into a tall tulip glass. Quick phone notes.

A - Dark brown body, pour yields a nice one finger tan head. Solid lacing.

S - Lots of spice, Belgian yeast, brown sugar, figs, and toffee. A bit nutty and sweet.

T - Spice and dark fruits lead into a cola syrup flavor. Notes of brown sugar, liquorice, molasses, toasted nuts, and spicy yeast as it warms up. Ample carbonation with a silky and chewy medium mouth feel.

O - Not quite as complex or intricate as the quad, but this is certainly the best dubbel I have tried. Very tasty, even being this fresh.

330ml bottle 
9.1% ABV (as written on bottle) 
I tried this beer on July 26, 2012 at "Bar Volo" in Toronto, Ontario, Canada.  The beer poured a translucent deep mahogany colour with a generous, long lived, tan coloured head.  Plenty of effervescence to keep the head alive.  Aroma is dark malt, sugar, plums, and licorice.  Definitely a very sweet nose. The mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with plenty of carbonation.  The flavour is sweet malt, dark fruit, yeast (and lots of it), some anise, and a bit of peppery spice.  Not as good as the 12, but an outstanding beer all the same.
Good but after all the hype, I preferred the St Bernardus abt 8 because that is readily available and tastes very similar.

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2016 Rebate on 02/09/2016. Bottle aged for 3 years in my cellar, because I was underwhelmed by the Westv series overall, and wanted to see what some age would do to these. The aroma now is datk fruit, candi sugar, sweet   The appearance is murky deep red brown, sediment  fluffy head  the flavor is sweet, fruity dark fruit,  belgian yeast, light chalk   The finish is spicy, fruiy  medium in body, lighty thick nice  slightly improved by aging  i guess thats a key to this beer  but i would really say this doesny stand up to Rochefort at all, despite the hype   End  Via trade with Dtmets84.  The aroma is dark fruit, candi sugar, spicy, some funk, some farmhouse.  The appearance is translucent brown/red, off-white head.  As I got toward the bottom of the bottle, the beer was hazier.  The flavor is fruity, pepper, some farmhouse/hay like flavors.  The finish is sweet, then spicy peppery.  Medium to medium/thick in body.  Lots of carbonation.  Nice beer.  Thanks Dave.

Bottle......at In de Vrede...at the monastery......It pours clear dark brown with a medium tan long lasting head....The aroma is malts, Belgian yeast, spices and lots of dark fruit......The flavor is malt, Belgian yeast, dark fruit, hops, spicy with a alcoholic finish...... very nice beer.......

Date: July 19, 2012 Mode: Bottle Source: Todd Description: Pour into my La Trappe glass was muddy brown with floating sediment, some head that lasted and lacing.  Aroma was dark fruit, caramel, and some alcohol.  Taste was consistent with aroma, plus had some spice and belgian yeast.  Palate was smooth but yet had some carbonation and medium bodied.  2011 vintage and this is my 800th rating!

Big thanks to randjuke for sending this one! Poured from generic Trappist bottle to brandy snifter - best by date of 18.08.13:

Pours a murky ruby brown stuffed with slow, steady beading. A few fingers of khaki head swell to create some fantastic lacing. A perfect looking beer in every way.

Mmm... overripe figs, red wine bits, some Belgian yeast far and away, a mellow blanket of tartness sort of ties everything together. Certainly not as in-your-face as its bigger brother, but it achieves a better sense of balance I think.

Leathery wood notes, dates and figs, super smooth. Its got that tobacco presence thing that bothers me in the Westy 12 but here it is more in balance with the rest of the beer. Subtle lingonberry as well.

The mouthfeel and appearance are the real highlights of this one. Super creamy with a relatively thick body.

A fantastic dubbel.

Bottle pour. Deep dark brown. Head thins down and remains as a light milky sheet. Lots of yeast and brown sugar in the nose. More of that in the taste with a strong rum raisin character. Unbelievably well balanced. Easily the best trappist ale Ive had to date.

"really fn good" says my tasting partner.
Amazing taste and palate-  milky smooth, with great tastes.
Dont want to spoil it with too many words...
brown with small head. fruity with lots of malt. very well balanced. alcohol well hidden. very good.
better balance on the 8 over the 12. Figs, slight phenol & ester yeast profile, a bit alcohol heat. Malty, caramelized, refreshing.

Near opaque dark brown with reddish highlight, deep tan two finger head that stays aloft for ever. The smell is rich fruit, yeast, rich malt as well. Taste is dark fruit, some cocoa, yeast with a touch of alcohol. Really nice and the carbonation is medium but with fine, beautiful carbonation. Overall a real treat.

Bottle, enjoyed at Bier Markt in Toronto-- my 4500th rating! Cloudy dark brown pour with a medium tan head that reduces to a clingy persistent ring. Aroma is sweet and yeasty, dark fruits and sugars. Palate is equally malty and yeasty, dates, sultanas, other dried fruits, brown sugar, dusty cocoa, light musty wood. Very soft mouthfeel, low bitterness. Very nice indeed, but for me not a religious experience. A very well balanced dubbel that was a great pleasure, even if it failed to live up to the hype.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text:
Bottle pours cloudy dark brown with one finger persistent beige head and great lacing.  Aroma flawless for the style with dark fruits, sugars and yeast.  Taste sweet toffee and caramel, dark fruits, Belgian yeast and spices.  Palate full with some carbonation, maybe a touch thin.  Finish very mild bitterness and spices.  Alcohol slightly apparent.
Invariably you compare this to the 12.  I gave them both the same score but the 12 is a wee bit better.  Still a wonderful beer.
Got a sixpack from ebay. Brown redish color. Thin to medium brownish head. Medium carbonation. Low to medium sweetness and bitterness. Malt, alcohol, herbs aroma. Absolutely wonderful.

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2012 Bottle shared with drabmuh at my place recently. Review from notes.

Bottle cap dated 01.04.13

A: This trappist ale appears a dark brown color with a substantial head and generous amount of lacing on the glass. Looks very nice.

S: This beer begins to distance itself from other dubbels right away. The aroma is simply fantastic. The Belgian yeast component alone is one of the most inviting and delectable scents I have yet found in a beer.

T: The flavor is incredible. Toffee and caramels amongst the best Belgian yeast strain on the planet. I cant imagine a single way that this beer could possibly improve. So many flavors constantly developing on the palate, all flowing seamlessly together in a work of art, this is a sublime elixir. The conclusion of every drink begs for the onset of another.

M: The feel is yet another flawless aspect of this beer. Its so smooth, it feels like water, yet coats the palate with a myriad of wonderful flavors that evolve from the moment your nose initially detects the beer.

D: I could, and would, drink this beer very regularly, if only that were possible. This is a truly special beer and absolutely worthy of any and all praises.

Small bottle, a nice special found at the wonderful De Bierkoning in Amsterdam. Hazy brown, yeasty malt. Crisp unique nose, sweet, musty, earthy. Blood, coppery. Very rustic, rare steak. Special, unique, ruddy awesome. unique beers from Westvleteren always have something special that I cant quite put my finger on. will have to try many more I guess.l, and this brew is the same

Bottle with Simon, this might have been the best bottle of belgian beer i had. 2005 bottle drank in 2010. Poured a plum brown color, insanely murky with thin head, tiny lacing. Aromas are the most ripe and perfectly tasting dark fruits with figs, plums, grapes, bready malts. Taste is a silked out dried fruit explosion with sugars, vinous, and roasty cocoa subtle notes at play. The most balanced beer there is. Unbelievable.
Best beer ever tasted up to date ! The aroma is both strong and complex, taste is really delightful
Lots of dark fruit aromas/taste in a very delicious beer. Maybe a bit overrated but still very good
Full malty beer. Nice creamy head which is retained. Beautiful nutty finish after taste. Good beer, but maybe a bit over rated.
Some dried fruit (plums, raisins, etc) and tasty yeast, but it is too easy to compare it to 12, which obviously is better..

03/06/2012 La Tana, 330ml bottle (Vintage 2009) shared by Valeriotto. Bruna, riflessi color coca cola, non molto densa, schiuma bianco sporca leggera e poco persistente. Al naso aroma di mela matura, Calvados, cioccolato, zucchero di canna, note ossidate. In bocca è molto complessa, malto, caramello, zucchero di canna, finale amarognolo, secca e pulitissima. Lalcol è appena percettibile, la carbonazione quasi assente, ha perso parecchio corpo nellinvecchiamento. Splendida bevuta.

Pours dark murky brown with a finger of light tan head, quick dissipation. Pretty well carbonated and yeast chunks floating. Smell is deep, figgy, plum, raisin, bit of chocolate. Very rich and earthy. Taste is caramel and bread, plum, a bit of belgium yeast. Very smooth drinking. Strong mouthfeel leaves mouth coated, long lasting flavor.

After letting it warm up for a bit, the smell is much more fruity, apple, fig, and plum. Taste is richer, more chocolate comes out, darker fruit and earthy. Almost a champagne style finish. This is an amazing beer and a great experience. Hope the 12 holds up.
i find that the 8 has more taste of beer and less alcohol taste than the 12, the 12 is also good. i prefer the 8

O tempora , O mores. En ce jour de Pentecôte le ciel est descendu sur la terre...
Nous sommes dans le rayon des bières divines, et pour les siècles des siècles
(secula seculorum). Une divine parmi les divines, quil faut déguster avec le plus
grand respect qui soit.
Et cela commence par la prise en charge de la bouteille en cave. On va chercher
cette bière comme les très grands vins, avec des précautions importantes pour ne
pas la remuer, et faire une transition douce avec le repos quelle vient de connaître 
dans le noir. Personnellement je la passe pendant quelques heures dans un régime
de pénombre pour lui permettre de retrouver le monde des hommes quelle avait 
quitté depuis sa mise en sommeil.
Regarder cette bouteille sans étiquette est un plaisir profond, quand on connaît
son contenu ô combien mystérieux. Et labsence de commentaire, ou dimage
commerciale ajoute fortement à ce mystère. En dautres mots, la publicité par la non
publicité. Nous entrons donc non seulement en religion, mais dans le monde magique 
de Lewis Caroll au pays des merveilles.
La capsule sobre nous annonce une trappiste à 8 %abv, le titre phare pour une 
trappiste, qui nous permet de tester toutes les saveurs de labbaye cistercienne en
question et de constituer une valeur de base. Elle affiche aussi le blason de labbaye.
La bouteille présente une collerette en verre qui précise quil sagit dune bière trappiste.
Rappelons que cette appellation est strictement protégée.
Nous versons le précieux breuvage dans un verre calice, exclusivement. Tout autre
verre constitue un sacrilège par rapport à cette bière. Cela reviendrait par exemple
à verser un Château Margaux dans un verre à Coca.... Do you understand ?
Une couleur sombre superbe, de vraie trappiste brune, avec une mousse beige encore
plus superbe.
Des arômes de brassin en foudre de bois, avec des fruits mûrs de la plus belle origine.
Des dattes, des figues, des prunes, des amandes, des noisettes. Mais aussi de la belle
céréale, une pointe de houblon et de la levure de première classe. Bref, arôme total de
vraie bière de haute fermentation refermentée en bouteille.
Prise en bouche de velours, comme les plus grands velours du Moyen-Age chez les
grands seigneurs.
1er goût sur les céréales et les fruits mûrs, mais avec cette indescriptible pointe de porto
vintage.. On rêve déjà et on a presque peur de la suite.
2ème nez sur le fût de Cognac de la grande champagne (la meilleure région), et aussi 
avec une touche de fruits exotiques splendide, comme sils étaient préparés dans un
restaurant 3 étoiles avec une touche de Chantilly...
2ème bouche sur le plus grand Armagnac que jaie bu du Bas Armagnac, et cétait un
cru de plus de 35 ans, distillé à lancienne... On trouve aussi la nuance des grands
single malts du Speyside, qui ne sont vieillis quen fût de chêne.. Suivez mon regard !
Vous ne trouvez pas ? Mais oui bien sûr, du Macallan...
3ème nez sur du pain grillé, des noix du Périgord et un je-ne-sais-quoi que je mettrais
dans le domaine de la pomme de terre en primeur. En tout cas, ce nest pas triste...
3ème bouche toujours aussi soyeuse, sur un petit côté sous-bois, et aussi écorce 
darbres fruitiers. Une touche de noisette, damande. Lorge de la meilleure qualité,
qui sapparente au malt que lon fait avec du Golden Promise. Et tout cela est lié par
une levure exceptionnelle. Nous sommes donc à un point déquilibre transcendant...
La longueur se révèle divine, très douce, comme doit lêtre le paradis...
On garde constamment cette nuance suave de velouté. Lesprit du divin, sans doute !
Quelle beauté, quelle grâce, quelle onctuosité, quelle saveur, quelle grandeur.
La levure incluse à merveille dans ce breuvage est purement trappiste, de souche
multipliée entre abbayes. Elle se révèle à la fois douce et avec une petite nuance de 
piment. Que dire ? Juste sincliner, comme devant Dieu le Père.
La finale est absolument inimaginable, comme Alice a pensé au-delà du miroir, nous
sommes ici dans lAu-Delà absolu, dans le supraterrestre.. Jen passe et des meilleures !
En bref, si lon peut dire, cest lEsprit Saint descendu sur terre, qui en fait 10 fois le tour
à la vitesse de la lumière, et qui se demande après ce qui lui arrive.
Pour rester sur le plan des chiffres, je rejoins donc la grande communauté des notes
maximales pour me joindre à elle, avec la petite différence que ma note nest pas un 5, 
mais un 666 sur 100. Ce qui entre nous est bien peu pour un breuvage quAlice a 
dégusté au pays des Merveilles. 
Et Spiritus Sanctus. Amen.

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2015 @ "In de Vrede".Dark brown, with tan head, lacing. Sweet and fruit aromas. Taste is smooth, sweet, raisins, developing a moerate bitter and astrigent finish. Warming. Really enjoyable.

A - pours dark mahogany with very high long lasting fluffy tab head. Strong clinging. Bubbly like a champagne. Yeast floaties. S - strong Belgian yeast/ bubble gum aromas. Notes of honeysuckle and astringent. Hints of clover and hay. M - strong full bodied beer. Nice full lasting tastes. Bubbly and lively. Lasting malty goodness. T - candied fruit, dark fruits, molasses up front. Astringent oak and dark malts on the palate. Lingering hay and clover, caramel malts, and fall spices. Cloves, ginger and bananas. O - very good dark Belgian ale. 8-/8

Bottle from the Bierkonig in Amsterdam. Pour a dark rich mahogoney with nice medium size bubbled head. Nose is sweet, malty roasted notes with yeasty ketones and some esters. first sip is huge malt with caramel, molasses, brown sugar, dried cherries and dates. finish is sweet with yeasty qualities. great brew.
@gambrinus udine. Great great beer, dark color with a huge white top. Great aroma well balanced,  not too sweet and not too bitter. My first westvleteren and I already love it!!

My first ever Westie!  Bottle poured into trappist glass at Cambrinus in Bruges.  At first, it was good but I wasnt blown away.  Very solid dubbel.  Nice, dark fruity nose with a good malty backbone with slight chocolate.  Taste was more of the same.  While I was slightly disappointed at first, this was served way too cold and really began to shine as it moved more towards room temp.  Wow...it opened up beautifully.  If only they had the 12 in stock...

Bottle at Scopeys Pre-CBC tune-up. Massive thanks to Scopey for generously breaking this out. The beer pours deep brown with a tiny tight tan head. The nose is full chocolate powder with light spicy nuts and black tea leaves. I also get notes of chutney and fruit jam. The taste is active prickly cola, leather and shoe polish. Theres a real earthiness to this beer, with plenty of notes of rotting fruit and spiced jam. The bodys full and smooth, the carbonation is active. Overall, this is a very nice, flavorful beer. It really stood out on the night.
Unaltra chicca dellabbazia di Westvleteren, si presenta con un colore rosso scuro. Al naso profumi di prugna, frutti scuri e luppolo. Mi fa impazzire...

Brown-reddish, cloudy with lots of sediments floating near the bottom. The aroma reminds me of chocolate and vainilla, while the flavour is pretty intense and complex. Brown sugar sweetness greatly balanced with roasted malts and a bitter, burning finish that left my palate with a "clean" aftertaste. Great.

Got this in a trade from "Scopey" inEngland. Pours a murky brown with a light brown foamy head. Aroma is huge and delicious. Heavy, rich malts with vanilla and dark sweet fruit. Sweet flavor that ends with light bitterness. Very drinkable for a high abv. Perfectly balanced throughout. All-around fantastic beer.
Its alright. Certainly better than the laughably rated 12. Had this with Harirsoni in the cafe-thingy attached to the abbey. A bit more fruity than the 12 and it kind of grew on me. ...a bit .

Tasted from a case I picked up around 8 months ago in Westvletern.  Deep brown color, full head. Fruity aroma, Smooth somewhat nutty taste, not too hoppy. Nice aftertaste.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Very dark brown colour. Creamy, lacy head. Served quite cold. The aroma and taste changes a lot as the chill goes off the beer. Strong malty aroma with some caramelised banana. Very smooth, rich texture. Great mouthfeel. Sweet flavour with some Galia melon sweetness. Later some caramel which becomes more bitter in the finish.

Bottle at a tasting at Maxs courtesy of Ryan for Sams visit.  Pours a deep mahogany with a medium sized tanned beige head.  Sweet malt on the nose, a touch of dusky yeast.  Malty, warm and toasty.  Lots of subtle dark fruit, malt and yeast.  Smooth and tasty.  Long warm malt.

Many thanks to Cuso for the trade. Pours an opaque dark cloudy brown. Aroma is as complex as you like. Sweet malt, berries and other fruits, spices and some yeast. Taste is also very complex. More sweet malt, dark fruits, spices and some yeast with even some chocolate and caramel notes all leading to a sweet fruity and lightly bitter finish. Although its 8%, you wouldnt even know it. Master work, if this is the 8, I cant wait to try the 12.

Dark amber cocacolaish with nice foamy head. Aroma quite thin, fruit, yeast, some hay, alcohol, Taste sweet malt, yeast, hay, some bitter hops, alcohol. Medium body. Finish bittersweet. Some strange hay barnyard taste and aroma? Should perhaps stay in the cellar a year for maturation.

fles 33cl
Kleur: bruin/rood. Met een (te) flinke beige schuimkraag
Geur: (rood)fruitig. Zoet.
Smaak: inderdaad fruitig en vrij zoet. Gevolgd door bitter en een warme nasmaak. Prikkelend, veel koolzuur.
Erg aangenaam in de mond

33cl bottle, from about 2010.
Pours brown, with an offwhite head.
Smells of brown sugar, dried red berries, belgian yeast.
Tastes of a heavy sweetness, mild bitter, some semi-tart fruitiness, caramel, and finishing with a tingly sweet but bitter raisin.
Medium bodied, soft carbonation, creamy texture.
I love this beer.

Part of a pack bought at the Abbey a couple of years back, decided to broach one of them at last.

Poured into the glass that came in the pack (a chalice): everything went in, the sediment arriving half way through the pour.

Deep auburn brown body with a rich looking creamy head sat above.

The nose is complex and delightful, huge fruit esters, both dried and fresh, malty goodness and walnut whips (for the Brits reading this) all seem to vie for position within the aromas.

The taste follows along the same lines, with the vanilla from the walnut whip asserting its self a little more, but not taking over in any way. What a lovely balanced Dubbel, certainly the best Ive ever had in my fairly long life. I can now see what all the fuss is about, later this evening Im having one of my Westy 12s really looking forward to that, what a night Im having.

Rich, deep and very, very enjoyable, my sweet tooth just loves this, I thought the Westmalle Dubbel was superb, but this knocks socks off it in all departments, a wonderful beer from start to finish.

Pours a chestnut brown with a little to no head. The nose has cinnamon, raise, grape juice, red fruit. Has a medium body. The Tastes starts with a strong raisin and red fruit. It is followed by a fig and hop bitterness. It finishes with a off dry sweetness. Overall a very complex beer. I think I prefer the 12. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

1985 bottle thanks to Dave. Pours uncarbonated with no head. Smells like sweet malt and perhaps some oxidation. Taste is watery, sweet with light malt, and subtle honey notes. Very light carbonation if any and light mouth feel. Nice for being so old, but a bit of an underwhelming experience.
UPDATED: MAR 15, 2013 Cerveza oscura de generoso giste aroma a malta y frutos maduros, sabor especiado, herbal y sobre todo maltoso, excelente, muy complejo. No muy diferente de la 12.
Pours fizzly brown with a high head. Aroma caramel, licorice. High in carbonation. A classic in its genre. Not Bad.

Poured into a snifter. 21.01.14 printed on cap.

3.5 A: Murky dark brown color. Three fingers of frothy beige head. Retention is average I suppose and a small amount of lacing is left.

3.5 S: The aroma is very subtle. Pepper is the strongest component. Raisin and plum underneath followed by clove. Clean with a light earthiness. 

4.0 T: Taste is more potent than the nose for sure. Big peppery spiciness with clove not too far behind. Plum, raisin, date, and fig fruitiness. Warming on finish. 

4.5 M: Lighter body. Good spritzy carbonation. Good creaminess and super smooth.

4.5 D: A couple categories could have been a touch higher, so 4.5 here. This is a lot like the 12. Super well integrated, subtle, and infinitely clean. But, unlike the 12, this is perhaps a bit too subtle and you really have to concentrate to enjoy it. Still, good beer.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-18-2012 22:00:34

Aroma: Sweet, caramel, malts. 
Appearance: Red brown with nice head. 
Taste: Little sweet, some bitters, caramal. 
Palate: full body, creamy, average carbonation. 
Overall: Good beer.

Bottle courtesy of Jesse.  Thanks!  Clear reddish, orangish brown with a fluffy off white head.  Cereal grain, molasses, caramel, citrus and bread aroma.  Creamy, silky palate.  Tangy apple, caramel taste up front, followed by cereal grain and molasses, and finishing with doughy flavors and notes of orange and chocolate.  Really nice complexity and damn good.
Grande birra rotonda morbida note di frutta matura e brandy.la sensazione di calore al momento della degluttizione è meravigliosa finale leggermente astringente

Bottle poured into Westvleteren glass.  Poured with a nice head but dissipated quickly, probably due to condensation in the glass (doh!).  A nice rich mahogany brown, with nice creamy head (while it lasted).  Aroma was not overly strong (compared to the 12).  Bulk of the flavour was a nice caramel/toffee, with smokey notes, and a hint of apple around the gums when swooshed around the mouth.  Hints of honey were apparent.  We sat on these for almost 30 mins and they warmed up very nicely.  Not as impressive as its big brother, but may have been down to the lack of sustained head (our glassware error) and possibly pouring too cold (about 6 degrees).  Alcohol kicked in nicely at the halfway point, and was a very nice beer to relax outside with (Australia).
Spiced marzipan aroma. Head lasts a little. Smooth texture, excellent flavour. Outstanding.
