Dark brown with red-orange tinges, tan head. Fruity-sweet nose with cola, liquorice, malt, grapes. Taste is complex, with the elements of the nose blending very well, with added bitterness-roastiness in the finish. Great brew.

I actually drank this years ago so my notes are a bit thin on content.  What I can recall very vivdly, however, is that this beer started out as a fairly significant disappointment.  I was expecting a ridiculously rich and concentrated dubbel, but instead I was met with a thinner, more vinuous beer.  However as I adjusted my expectations, the flass finished on a wonderful high note of stewed cherries, cola, and Belgian candi sugar sweetness.  Lovely stuff thats well worth seeking out.

aroma: ci metterei un anno a scrivere tutte le sfumature che percepisco. una caratteristica unica di questa birra che presenta un aroma molto molto complesso che la rende meravigliosa
apparenza: brown/black, cloudy, frothy
gusto: se laroma era complesso,il gusto è ancora meglio. Note di amaro molto basse,con predominanza di dolcezza. I sapori sono numerosissimi.
palato: birra dal corpo pieno, carbonazione media e finale lungo e dolce
di sicuro non ha nulla a che vedere con le altre trappiste(al massimo qualcosa con la rochefort 10),FANTASTICA!

Bought in Amsterdam july 2010. Poured a medium dark brown color with almost no head. 

Aromas of dark fruits and dark brown sugars strong notes of vanilla, banana, muscat, blueberries. Faint notes of caramel, grass, butterscotch, nuts. 

Taste: caramel, toffee, subtle dried fruits, and a distinctive yeast note. Palate is amazing on this beer, very soft and silky texture, nice, long finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

11.2oz bottle in a Trappist glass.  Pours very deep, cloudy brown with a thick, lacy, beige head.  Aroma of caramel and cereal malts, spicy yeast, dark fruits with some wine-like characteristics, and some floral hops.  Flavor about the same, with lots of malts, sugar, and yeast.  Smooth texture.  An incredible beer.

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2013 (05/02/2012) 15 cl. sample from 33 cl. bottle @ Bruges Beer Festival 2012: hazy very dark brown with a mocha head, smells like boozy plums, Belgian yeast & liquor cherries/bread malt, taste is boozy, plums, prunes & dates, lots of Belgian yeast, bready yeast, touch of jam, slight liquor cherries/bread malt, brown bread, dough & hint of earthliness, boozzzy, bready malt body but not quite full, messy but interesting, comparable to 12, better in quite a few ways than the 12 ////// Didnt rate but had a fresh bottle at home since, picked up from the brewery. Total mess, all over the place. Traded 3 from the 6 pack I bought there for random German locals. //// Drank several bottles from 1979 contract brewed by St. Bernardus, has aged extremely gracefully. One thing you can say for Wesy is that it ages very well, you get oxidation but never oxidation off-flavours which is what makes the 8 & 12 unique. They just never get as good as Rochefort 8 & 10 fresh but still very good stuff. ///// Opening my last 33 cl. bottle now. Last one of these I ever intend to pick up, there is just a lot more better beer available where I live than these guys. Bottled on 16.05.15. So 15 month & a touch old. Very dark amber, light copper, tanned head which is instantly gone. Nose is oxidation (good as said before), walnuts, candy sugar, raisins, prunes, faintest molasses & soy. Taste is thick brown sugar, some liquorish, touch bitter spices, good oxidation, oxidation caramel, bitter herbs, dark fruits, plums & raisins, touch boozy, carb. is rather high. Bit boozy. Not that different from the 12, this is a bit more raw but the 12 I had yesterday was 2 years older. This is also way better than the 12, going to give it 0.1 more than the 12. So 4.6
Brown color with a lacy fizzy tan head. Aroma is very complex: belgian yeast mixed with sour cherry and other berries.Oily body, taste is yeasty but pleasant thanks to some caramel note.
UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 Red/brown color with a big lasting beige head. Malty aroma. Good balanced sweet taste with long malty fullness..

Pour dark, deep almost opaque brown, with a large fluffy tan head. 
Aroma is quite complex, with a lot of bready yeast to it. Alot of dark fruits as dades, plums, raisins. Vanilla, caramel, bread, dough, earth. A lot is going on, but this isnt as balanced As the 12. 
Taste is quite sweet. 
Medium body, with a typical trappist fizzy carb.

UPDATED: OCT 19, 2012 First time tasting the notorious Westvleteren. A dear friend managed to bring  Extra 8 and 12 back home.
Pours light murky brown with low frizzy head.
Aromas full of belgian yeast, oranges, hints bananas and general murky tones. Palate starts mild with a creamy fine texture. It is smooth but could be richer. Westvleteren is hyped and my expectations were higher but it is still av very good beer.

Bottle shared with esp0r at Amundsen.
The famous Westys availible in our city, of course we had to! One 12 each, and an 8 for sharing, as we expected the little brother to a bit hyped. 
Dont get me wrong, its a really good beer, though I suspect the love-in is partly due its rather limited availibility.
Dark orange, near brown, medium beige head. Good complexity in both aroma and taste. Fruity, caramel nose, belfian style yeast notes, full bodies taste of more of the same, spices. 
A good one, though the bigger brother is the one to go for

Beautiful murky brown pour with healthy carbonation and head.  Aroma is clean, malty, and hints of grape.  Taste is incredibly smooth, malty sweet, hint of grape.  Very complex, but so well balanced.  A bit of a dry note helps to balance out the sweetness, but this is not a dry beer.  This beer stands up to the hype.  Excellent.  Get it if you can.
chocolate, herbs, leather, soy sauce, butterscotch, cooked vegetables, black, sparkling, rocky head, heavy cloying sweetness, very bitter, heavily sour, umami,
Murky brown with beige head. Its very much like the Westvleteren 12 in aroma and taste. So its good!

Pours a murky brown, ruby red edges with an off white creamy head.  The nose is lightly nutty up front, sweet caramel, lightly toasted, cherries, light sherry and very fruity in the back. The taste is sweet, sugary caramel, roasted nuts, berry fruits in the back with slighlty paper oxidation falling off a bit in the back.  Full body, syrupy feel, decent carbonation, thin in the back.

33 cl bottle @ home, BBE 05.12.2011
The beer started foaming immediately after opening. After two small pours there was still lots of foam coming out of the bottle.
Aroma is perfume-like with toffee and some dark sugar. Rather typical to an aged belgian dark ale. Flavour has toffee, dark fruits, plum, dark sugar and hints of pear esther. Some warming, non-disturbing alcohol in the finish. Foamy, but still somewhat creamy palate. Some grain and hay occur at the end of the glass. Perfect balance, one of the best belgian strong ales out there.
Gentile omaggio di Fausto, versione 2003; che dire, stiamo parlando di una ottima birra ma che con le sue sorelle blond e 12 esce massacrata. Sembra la versione allungata della 12..

[Rated 05/31/2010] Westvleteren 2/3. Pours caramel-dark colow with a thick white foam. Aroma is of yeast, raisins, and sour fruit. Tastes very sweet and warm. Flavor is complex with some hints of spiciness/hot, but this could be an artifact of the alcohol. Leaves a long finish. While not terribly special, I find its taste very complex and mysterious.

#1234
Mahagonyfarben, kaum Schaum. Fruchtig nach Pflaume und leicht schnapsig wie Armagnac. Sehr voller, leicht spritiger Antrunk. Geschmacklich ein Strauß voller Gewürze, passt gut in die kältere Jahreszeit. Wärmender Alkohol im Abgang. Kommt an den großen Bruder Westvleteren 12 nicht heran und ist merkwürdigerweise auch alkoholischer im Geschmack, obwohl er von der Papierform her leichter sein sollte. Dennoch sehr gut!

26.08.07- Pours a murky cloudy brown, nose and taste are of spice, malt, a bit of oxidation and a touch of funk. I am a bit surprised how well this beer has held up. Drinks very well even at age 5.  Big thanks to Watson1977 for hooking my up with my first Westvleteren beer ever.

(2011) bottle.  Dark pour with nice head but little retention.  Nose and taste are mainly dark fruit, caramel, and toasted malt.  A bit on the dry side but clean on the finish.  Very slightly metallic.  Very good beer but certainly not at the level as 12.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Subtle, nice bubbly mouthfeel and delicious. Caramel, and subtle despite being very complex.

So earlier in the day I had the Westvleteren 12, and decided to follow it up with the Extra 8. As with that one, I had been holding onto this one for a bit, waiting for the "right time" to consume it. The start of a new year is good enough as any Id say, so here we go. I was a bit hesitant to acquire this one, mostly because I do want to respect the monks and their wishes regarding consumption of this beverage.
This poured a medium dark brown color with virtually no head whatsoever. Aromas were similar to the 12, in that there were notable amounts of dark fruits and dark brown sugars. Flavor was complex and tasty. Enjoyed it a lot, but certainly lives in the shadow of its bigger, more sought out brother.

Cheers to Guillaume for the bottle. Appearance: Opaque brown, fine beige head. Some visible carbonation. Aroma: Complex, strong notes of vanilla, banana, muscat, blueberries. Faint notes of bubblegum, caramel, grass, butterscotch, nuts. Palate: Fizzy, smooth, slightly dry finish. Taste: Not as complex as Id expected, but still fantastic. Quite sweet. The muscat notes are very strong - reminds me a bit of really really good Darjeeling tea (which also has a strong muscat flavour). Alcohol is quite noticable.

Dark red brown beer with nice biege head and yeast.Smell alcohol,chocolate,bread,dust,berries,fig,pepper.Ta roasted bread,alcohol,coffee,wet wood,prunes,raisins,chocolate,plums.Nice mouthfeel,long lasting finish.A very drinkable beer.
Thank you Anastasia for this beer,i was thinking of you while i was enjoying this beer.

Bottle shared with Daje at Amundsen
Pours dark brown, thin tanned head. Smells of apples, caramel, some tartness and malts. Taste is quite malty with good sweetness. Also some tartness . Feel is smooth, but not the best carbonation. Nice bitter finish
For me this beer feels like Westy 12s little weaker brother. Everything this beer has, the 12 does alot better. I actually thinks this beer is hyped up alot. Absolutely a drinkable beer, but top 50 here on ratebeer? Come on

330 ml bottle. From Westvleteren, Belgium (2009). BB 13.08.12.
Dark brown colour with small light tan head.
Sweet syrupy caramel, dark fruits, mild dryness, malt and toffee in aroma.
Flavour is dark bready malt, dark chocolate, sweet caramel, toffee, mild bitterness, mild warming alcohol, dark fruits and mild yeast. 
Smooth and enjoyable. Not bad for the rating # 3 000.

Cola brown with a centimeter of velvety head made of the smallest bubbles.  Aroma is browned apples, coconut, and some mild solvent.  Taste is a bit like the browned flesh of a lightly toasted apple with some pie notes that echo back into the nose, and it finishes into a mildly solventy alcohol and hop bitterness, followed by caramel. 10 Euro (rating 1400 & first anniversary)

33cl Bottle.  Appearance is opaque, nutty brown color with soft, foamy, beige head.  Aroma is sweet and toasted malts, caramel, dark fruits, and yeast.  Taste is similar with toasted grains as a solid base overlaid with caramel, toffee, subtle dried fruits, and a distinctive yeast note.  Palate is amazing on this beer - very soft and silky texture, pillow-like carbonation, nice, long finish.  Exactly what youd expect from this Trappist brewery.

Bottle generously shared by Dallas and Bonnie 
Appearance: Hazy brown with a small beige head and spotty lacing 
Aroma: Toasted malts, dark fruit and woody 
Taste: Toasted malts, caramel, spices and dark fruit 
Great, glad I was able to try this.
Thanks to my wife, 11.2 Oz bottle. Plum, maple, dark fruits, malty, amazing. Gushed a little upon opening.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2012 A very different beer from its more famous and celebrated brother. Has a subtle citrus flavor and a deep cherry color. Tried with Paul in Adam (7/27/2011) Tried again at the Bruges bierfest in Februari 2012 with Jess and Dave.

Appearance: murky browns under a soft bready khaki head. Swirls creamy.

Nose: essence of age  old wood, old leather. Fig and date cake (think ala Fig Newton). Brown sugar pumpernickel underneath  dense. Wet wood. Twigs, dried brush.

Palate: rich and datey, cakey, and figgy. Sweetness than spice  chewy dark fruits than brown wintry spices. Chewy pumpernickel and whole grain breads. Leather and old earth. Nutmeg. Decidedly rich and humble at the same time.

Final Thoughts: Westvleteren is truly the white whale of the beer geek world; though I think its disservice to limit this fine Trappestry and their beer strictly to the beer geek world. Its a fine beverage, possible one of the finest in the world. I believe that of all the Westy beers and if youre truly ever lucky enough to find a bottle or glass in your hand, pour slowly and savor.

Original rating : april 2005 
Head: white, thin 
Colour: brown 
Smell: chocolat,malts, watery, yeasty, candy sirup 
Taste: start is malts, sweet, bit thin, some yeast, bit of rock candy, end is a bit dry, after is caramel, ok ....

Bottled 2008, drank Nov 2011.

AROMA: bread, caramel, woody, earthy, herbs, fruits, ...
APPEARANCE: red/brown with a small brown head, sparkling
TASTE: medium sweetness, lightly bitter
PALATE: medium body, creamy, average carbonation, long finish
OVERALL: excellent beer with many aromes blended to perfection, fantastic body.

Bottle courtesy of ernesto987.  Great complex aroma of dark fruits, spices, caramel, and bread.  Taste is medium sweetness with a very dry crisp finish.  I expected a sweet finish when I was taking my first sip and it was clean and wonderful. Great beer,.

Bottle. Amazing beer. Thick dirty brown pour with some sediment. Huge frothy light tan head. Nose of fig, raisin, caramel, and yeast, and it really opens up as it warms. Smooth full palate with some carbonation. Taste is dark fruits, a touch of caramel and toffee. Some chocolate as well as it warms. Beautiful beer.

Bottle [I believe this was 2010 vintage]...  Poured deep reddish, copper with a thick light tan head.  I really dug this, especially compared to the 12.  The body wasnt as intense and the alcohol burn wasnt present.  Therefore the toast caramelized malts and dark sugars, along with a fruity yeast esters and spices really shined.  Completely amazing.

Bottle courtesy of Sergio, has the elements of a sour without the actual tartness. The other sour nuances in there.  Very dry and malty flavors. Like a bernardus abt 12, less big. Mother fuckin home run
Bottle shared at Haggertys Fantasy Tasting. Clear dark amber with a thin brown head. Bright fruity dubbel aromas along with some licorice. Medium sweet malty flavor.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2012 Pitch dark brown body with a creamy off white head. Aroma is dominated by honey, also some chocolate, plum, caramel. Full, perfectly carbonated palate. Amazing flavour that is sweet and dry, with fruits, caramel, some chocolate and honey. Truly extraordinary. (8/5/9/5/19)
Dark brown body, creamy off white head. Sweet aroma with honey, chocolate, caramel and licorice. Full body, well carbonated palate. Really amazing flavour with chocolate, caramel, honey, dark fruits.

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2012 Bottle at Cambrinus in Bruges.  Hazy, mahogany pour with a moderate, light tan head that is dense and frothy.  Aroma of plums, dark cherries, and caramel.  Lightly rosy.  Pleasant, smooth flavors - lightly spicy with touches of clove, coriander, and cinnamon.  Pitted fruit sweetness and a dash of candy with some light alcohol.  Medium body has prickly, dancing carbonation.  Very light alcohol plays a contributing role.  Dry finish.  I was skeptical , but overall a super beer that lives up to the hype!

Bottle - 330ml. Hazy dark brown body with a thin beige foamy/creamy head. Wonderful, complex malty/hoppy aroma with plummy, chocolate, and woody hints. Alcohol is perfectly hidden. Taste is perfectly balanced. It carries vineous, yeasty, raisin, and some woody notes. Ends with a long, robust, warming finish. Awesome!
One of my favorite beers.  I actually prefer it more than the 12 which is outstanding in its own right.  Malty and flavorful and is excellent with Belgian cheese too.

Im not gonna lie, I just happened to pair this with a tube of Paprika-flavored Pringles. Dont judge. Poured from an un-aged bottle into a Westy glass, no head at all. Poured like coca-cola. Like the 12, the aroma is whats truly magical and I dont claim to have the palette to identify but its really wonderful. Darker than I expected, like a typical Belgian Dubbel with a slight cherry color especially held up to light. Definitely has a lively fizz to it. Overall great but not earth-shattering, although Im willing to accept that I dont know what Im talking about just yet. I will drink this again!

Found it at De Bierkoning in Amsterdam.

Rating # 2000! Bottle from a trade with zathrus13. Pours clear reddish brown color with tan head. Aromas of dark fruits and candi sugar. Flavors of figs and raisins with some candi sugar and doughy yeast. Medium body with soft carbonation. A really nice beer, but not nearly as good as the 12. Thanks Jeff. 

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6uE6XRHkc08&fea
UPDATED: NOV 4, 2011 This far from being the Westvleteren 12. The taste is good but there are some little imperfection in aroma. Good beer anyway.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2011 33 cL glass at In de Vrede.  Dark brown with a good caramel coloured head, though is disappears quite quickly.  Nice caramel/coffee aroma.  Spiced, meaty, dark malty, licorice.  A deep and rich beer.  Tasty and excellent.

Bottle at home bought at In de Vrede a couple of years ago. Dark brown with small beige head. Lots of aromas and flavours going on, caramel, chocolate apple and dried fruit aromas. Also bread/yeast. Taste is bready and fruity with a bit of booze. Very smooth and very nice.

2009 bottle, courtesy Travlr. Thanks buddy! Pour is deep hazy brown with an impressive tan head, good retention/lacing. Aroma is interesting: marshmellows, figs, light prune, raisins, some yeast funk, chocolate milk, and some stone hinting at impending dryness. Taste is really nice: light sweetness, but quite dry overall, with nice fig, raisin, caramel, and yeast notes. Palate is soft, creamy, long finish. Just outstanding.

Bottle thanks to Baker, thanks again!  Pour is a deep murky brown with medium off-white head.  Aroma is lightly roasted and caramel malt, deep rum-soaked dark fruit, a hint of champagne-like dryness, and light oatmeal raisin cookie.  Flavor is full deep caramel malt with light fruitiness and notes of crisp dryness.  Also hints of light spice and earthiness.  I think i could drink 10 of these.  This is so smooth, so tasty, and so drinkable. I love the silky palate. Just the right amount of carbonation. Really great stuff.

Bottle from De Molen beer shop. Dark orange brown color with huge frothy beige head. Fruity aroma with caramel, malt and yeast. Sweet taste with caramel, oranges, toffee, red fruit hints, spices.  Strong alcoholic finish, with some bitterness. Excellent.

Amazing. Deep amber color. Hazy with nice lingering off white head. Aroma is toasty, malty, and sweet. It has subtle minerally stone fruit esters mixed with spiciness and light alcohol. Flavor starts very sweet malt but quickly mellows to toast and caramel and finishes dry. Not cloying at all but caramel toast and bitter hops/malt astringency lingers on the back of the tongue. Light alcohol heat at the end. Huge carbonation but no gushing. Some chunky floaters even with careful pouring is the only complaint. This is a nearly perfect beer. Tastes like a Belgian Munich dunkles. Not quite as complex as the 12 but more enjoyable to me.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2015 Bottle shared with my mom and dad. Pours dark hazy brown with redish notes and a light brown head. Aroma is ripe plums, westvleteren belgian yeast, figs, prunes, raisins, ripe cherries, a very light funky note, caramel and a kind of port wine note. Taste has all of the ripe fruits from the aroma along with warming alcohol, weak hoppy notes, yeast, spice, caramel and light funkyness here aswell. Very gentle and well done.

Pours with a two inch soapy white head and legs that crawl all over the side of the chalice. The beer is burgundy in color with a hazey appearance. Highly carbonated with streams of bubbles throughout the glass. Chunks of yeast appear as you near the end of the bottle.

The nose is rich with dark fruit, pears, chocolate and candy sugar. The sweet smell of fruit is refreshing and not bitter. As the beer warms you can pick up the yeast aroma.

The flavor isnt as sweet as the nose would imply. Belgian yeast, malt, dark fruit, spices and hops.

The mouthfeel is soft and smooth with a medium body. Has plenty of carbonation without going overboard. Some earthy hops add some bitterness and dry feel to the finish.

Overall a pretty good beer. Im not sure if Ill continue to dish out the high dollars for it though. I know of one competitor that is just as good if not better and I can purchase it right off the shelf. Still a pleasure to have.

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2015 It pours an absolutely beautiful brown with a huge tan head that takes its own, sweet time to deflate. The aroma is complex and delicious, with a barrage of toffee, malty sugars, and dark fruity esters (raisins, prunes, currants at the forefront; dry red apples, banana, and a kiss of cherry in the background ), with only a whisper of hops to keep it all together. There are subtle herbal undertones, anise coming to mind. Unforgettable! The taste is an orchestra of flavors that combines sweet, tart, and subtle bitter. Its creamy and balanced and the best thing is that you get the full experience without the slightest alcohol spoilage. It also manages to not be cloying at all -- the only thing I felt after drinking the whole bottle was a sheer, physical necessity to have another one. The mouthfeel is perhaps (just perhaps) a bit watery but, regardless, this is wonderful. Mad thanks to Robert for this.

Fruchtiger Geruch nach Feige, Pflaumen. Gleichzeitig schokoladig und alkoholisch berührt. Fruchtig im Antrunk, erneut wie im Duft Pflaumen. Mitte malzig und toffeeartig mit beginnender Alkoholwirkung. Im Abschied dann röstmalzig und deutlich langes Rum-artiges Finish. 
Sehr charaktervolles Bier. Ausgewogen und nie übertrieben. In seiner Sorte wohl nur schwer zu toppen. Test vom 30.1.2009, Gebinde: Glasflasche

Bottle, sample at GBF 2011 cons 2011-09-02
AP: clody dark amber, wee beige head
AR: graps, fudge
F: grapes, a bit salty, plums , maderia

Bottle, pours a nice brown colour, the taste is very nice and complex, it has a really nice after taste, filled with dates and raisins. It lasts for a very long time and it is a wonder to try. the flavours are similar to westy 12 but the after taste comes out better in this

Bottle, sample, not sure of the vintage.
Amber with a porous tan head.
Aroma: vanilla, brandy.
Taste: very sweet, but balanced, lots of vanilla, apple juice, rhubarb pie.
Above medium-bodied with low carbonation.
Really nice, almost as good as the 12.
Bottle courtesy of James. Shared with Andy James and Streets. Pours a medium brown w light brown head. Spicy, tangy aroma and spicy, nutty palate with chewy mouthfeel. I liked this one.
Courtesy of James.  Plums, fig, and molasses... Sweet, fruity, and bready.  Extremely well balanced like the other westys.  Sessionable even for the alc content.

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2011 Botella de 330ml servida en Copa Cáliz Westmalle. Saboreada el 12 Jul´11
Brota turbia con un color ambar oscuro y reflejos rubí. La espuma beige es cremosa, cerrada y persistente. Las pequeñas y concentradas burbujas crean un increible lecho de encaje alrededor. Aromas de levadura de pan y malta caramelo, ciruelas pasas y sutil matiz de flores frescas seguidas de notas de anís. Amargor dulzón al primer trago. Un lígero toffee envuelve un cuerpo medio, especiado, pleno de sabores de pasas y melazas. Agradable carbonatación. El ABV está tan bien camuflado que sólo un gentíl sabor a brandy revela su presencia. Perfecto equilibrio de aromas y sabores. Asimilación excelente.
Comentario:Una de las mejores piezas en mis más de 35 años como cazador de cervezas. Maridaje: Nada. Para que enturbiar la experiencia de degustar una maravilla.  Sí tienes la suerte de tener más de una,combina como postre con pan tierno y plátano.
330ml bottle served in a Westmalle Chalice glass.Enjoyed on jul´11
Pours foggy,deep amber in color with rubi hues to the light.Creamy,close & lasting froth,beige in color.An incredible all around lacing bed created by small & concentraded bubbles. Bread yeast & caramel malt aromas, prune aromas.Subtle fresh flavor hints followed by anisette notes round nose feeling.Sweet bitter at fist sip. Slightly toffee flavor wraps a medium body.Palate is fulled up by raisin & molasses. Gentle carbonation.ABV is so well camouflated that only a kindly brandy flavor reveals alcohol presence. A perfect balanced beer. Excelent drinkability. Comments: One of the best prey I´ve catched in my more than 35 years as a beer hunter.Pairing:Nothing at all. An amazing experience should not be cloudy by anything.Nevertheless if you´re lucky enough to have more than one of this, fresh bread rolls & banana will match pretty well.
Bottle in Westvleteren glass. Dried fruit aroma. Dark reddish brown colour. Sweet fruit then dry hops. Excellent beverage.

Enormous head, That very slowly falls down it is lightly brown and the beer itself is redbrown. Nose is a little - not cardboard, more a bit medical, as well as mango and melon, chokolate. Actually oiled this nose better than that of the 12. Medium body and.good length - still quite heavy.long taste with light chockolate,  dry fruit, candis. Really good and I think in better ballance than the 12.

Bottle @ Sample 10 cl.Let hazy dark brown with a small off white head. Aroma of dark ripe fruit, alcohol, and plums. The taste is sweet dried fruit and malt and raisins. dry mouth feel and slightly bitter hops finich

Ohhh Yeah.... Ruby/Mahogany with brown notes, nice sustained tan head, slowly fades, laces nicely... Loads of dark fruits, spicy, peppery, a touch of creaminess, dark sugar... lively, fruity, loads of dark fruits, lightest tartness, warming, dark sugar... Extremely complex, tons of complex malts, sugars, and fruits... Toasty malts... somewhat dry finish.... Worthy of the reputation...

Few bitter malts, little bitter yeast, hints of fruits like plum, a touch of cinnamon and cloves. Acrid and slightly stiff. All in all not a very ouspoken beer, more of a beer with some of anything. Never too much of anything so you would never get bored. For every day ahead this beer, that would be no punishment at all.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2013 33 cL bottle: Appearance is pitch black with a light brown creamy, slow fading head. Aroma is of plum, cinnamon and candi sugar. Flavor is initially malty, followed by cinnamon, candi sugar, and other spices. Overall an outstanding beer thats very similar to the 12.

Bottle @ home. Poured out into original Westvleteren glass. Nice dark beer with a nice, creamy and tanned head. Copper brown colour with an incredible aroma of heavy yeast, dark, ripe fruits like blackberries and plums, with small hint of alcohol coming through. Flavour is really well balanced between the heavy, darker part of this beer and the tenderness and elegance on the other side. Starts of building towards a full bodied, aromatic experience with a nice alcoholic warming on the background, finished into a soft, sweet and gentle wrap. Really well balanced, as said before.. great beer.

33 cl bottle. Cloudy, dark brown liquid with small to medium off-white head. Aroma is malty with notes of malty, molasses, raw sugar, belgo esters and some malty notes (caramel, bread, biscuits). Taste is quite sweet with medium bitterness and light sourness. Lots of notes of candi sugars. Medium bodied with ok carbonation and sticky mouthfeel. Some warming alcohol. Very balanced and refined. One of the best belgian strong ales Ive ever had.

Bottle 33cl, kindly donated by J.C. in Belgium, thanks a lot. Bottle with limit date 20/06/11 so old bottle. Nose is intense on fresh honey, amazing smell. Aroma is malty, caramel like, honey, slightly oxygenated (maderisation), sweet, candy like, long caramel honey aftertaste. Off course a great beer, to be tasted more younger.

Dark brown, but clear in sense there is no yeast bits etc. Smells malty, alcoholic and I sense banana as well. First taste is caramel and bread. Hops come later with grass & spruce aromas. Theres a bit yeast aromas, leather and leaves perhaps. Body is full, texture is sticky and to my taste there is too much carbonation. Finish comes early. Amount of sweetness / dryness is absolutely perfect. Very good but is this really worth of 14.50 euros? Maybe once.

Pour dark brown nice pillowy beige head. Aroma dark cherries, spicy yeast characteristics, dark malt, dried fruit. Taste spicy, dark malt, cherries, bread, dried fruit, not overpowering and very balanced. MF full terrific mouth coating feel with a soft carb outstanding. Extremely well done easy to drink, ABV almost none existent, outrageously good MF and not a dark fruit/candy sugar bomb this is the real deal very well done.
Una delle signore Belgian Strong Ale, mi ha invitato una sera in una splendida taverna ed io da buon cavaliere, non ho rifiutato. Che dire splendida, meravigliosa, infinita...

Bottle at BarVolo in Toronto July 2011.

Delicious, Lovely raisiny aroma surprisingly mellow and well balanced maltiness.  The LCBO testing indicated the ABV was higher than that on the original label (over 9%).  It cost a pretty penny but was worth every one.

Well...what shall I say about this beer. Its not bad thats for sure. But I guess because its relatively easy to get for me, and I can have it pretty much when I want, to me its not extremely good. Very nice beer, good taste and body, but one of my best beers ever.

Bottle at Avery support group. Pours a cloudy milk chocolate brown with tan foam. Smelled of chocolate, licorice, and nutmeg. Tastes sweet with lots of flavor including bubblegum, tootsie rolls, raisons, and dates.

Beer crept from the bottle as soon as the cap was popped.  Chestnut brown pour, huge head.  The mouthfeel was silky smooth and definitely the highlight of the beer.  Candied apple and fig flavors with a pretty high level of spiciness.  Not sure what the spice was, but it was really prevalent...and quite enjoyable.  After finally getting my hands on a Westvleteren bottle, it wasnt a disappointment.

Two bottles (2011 and 2008) at the East Croydon Beer Tasting, thanks to Paul and Thomas, respectively. 2011: Pours hazy brown with a foamy, off-white head. Aroma has some dark malts and dry fruits. Sweet flavor, more dried fruits, some bread and yeast, bit of brown sugar. Medium bodied with fine to average carbonation and a soft, smooth mouthfeel. Finishes warm with further notes of dry, dark fruits, yeast and esters, fairly sweet. Super drinkable and delicious. Great stuff. 2008: Very similar to the fresh bottle but with a more pronouced sweetness overall. More dark fruit, like raisins, plums, prunes and figs, and just straight sugar. I would say better than the 2011. Sublime.

Pours very dark brown almost black colour with a frothy tan head. Malty aromas, yeast. Fresh and spicy but not so strong. Hints of toffee, raisins and sweet liquor aroma when the glass is half empty. Medium to high sweetness in the taste together with some spiced touch, notes of caramel. The alcohol makes itself present on the tongue and in the palate. Full body, creamy, soft carbonation, and a medium term caramel finish. A good strong ale.

Bottle from my dads June 2011 trip to Belgium.  Woke up as soon as I popped it open.  Poured into a trappist glass.  Dark amber with a touch of orange.  A somewhat spicy taste with the aroma of pitted fruits.  Burnt caramel and marshmallow of evident as well.  What a treat!

Had this bottle next to the Westvleteren 12 at Craigs. The beer pours a beautiful graduated red to orange. Lots of candy sugar and some spicy notes on the nose, plums? Tasts more yeasty than the 12 with lots of chewy caramel. The mouthfeel is juicy and the spice lingers nicely

Bottle split with mcberko. Pours dark solid brown colour with a small white head. Aroma of dark fruits, spices and brown sugar. Flavour of dark fruits like plum, cherry etc. Really smooth, beautifully carbonated, gorgeous mouth-watering sensation left behind. Pleasant warming effect. Awesome.

Bottle at cgarvieuks. Pour is orangey copper, dark but with prominent highlights. Almost no head save for a very slight bubbly film. Nose is muted toffee notes, with yeast and candied sugar. Some fig/raisin notes too. Juicy, medium-dry taste with a resinous, estery finish. Beautiful.

15 June 2011, bottle at one my last cgarvieuk tasting! ruby/hazelnut colour, tiny sediment, thin lacing. smells like a yeasty, slightly alcoholy blegian brune. some barnyardy notes behind sweet fig newtons. really smooth delectable belgian strong ale with some brown/purple fruit and some bitter, alcohol twinge in the finish. this is a super beer and the experience is definitely part of this. Hats off to Craig! Thanks for sharing!

UPDATED: DEC 2, 2014 Aroma: Bread, maple syrup, yeast, slightly acidic, candy, toffee, caramel, I could go on forever. Boozy too. Smells like a certain flower, but I cant recall which one. 

Appearance: Dark, turbid red color with a tinge of haze. Active carbonation. 

Taste: Roasty, malty, and syrupy sweet. Slight bitterness at the end. Its very well balanced. Much like St. Bernardus Prior 8 but this is...a little different.

Palate: Smooth, creamy, well balanced, dry and boozey finish. 

Overall: Good beer, but hard to get.

To put it short: Overrated. The Westvleteren myth seems to push the scores of this beer off the charts. When you taste it without paying attention to this, you will taste a very common beer. Its not bad at all, dont get me wrong, but its not as great or special as a lot of people say. Mouthfeel is great though.

11.2 oz. bottle, pours murky dark reddish brown with a beige head. Exquisite aroma of various spices, prunes, figs, dates and yeast. Flavour is quite yeasty, with the aforementioned dark dried fruits, candied sugar and a barrage of various spices. Very highly carbonated, though not detracting at all from the complexity of flavours. Most excellent - glad I got the chance to try this.

33cl bottle from ABCBeers, about 1 year old.
Dark amber ber.  Good white head.  Raisins the the aftertaste.  Complex beer.

330 ml bottle. BBE 21.1.2014.
Pours a dark reddish brown colour with a thick, beige head. Aroma of strong dark fruits, chocolate and smooth malts. Complex flavour of strong dark fruits, wood, chocolate, apple and mild nuts. Full bodied with a thick mouthfeel and a pleasant raisiny, syrupy, chocolatey finish. Awesome Belgian Strong Ale.

330ml bottle, thanks lusikkaBBE 21.1.2014 -

Pours dark brown with a foamy head. Strong aroma has hints of raisin, herbs and spices. Taste is quite complex with notes of apricose, raisin, spices and exotic fruits. Smooth finish, full bodied. Impressive.

33cl bottle from Brewery Creek. Pours a hazy brown with a voluminous tan head that took a good long while to settle down. Lots of floating particles from the bottle conditioning. Aroma of complex dark fruits, sweet malt, and Belgian yeast. Flavour is sweet malt, candi sugar, dark fruits, Belgian yeast, and spices. Full-bodied and smooth on the palate. Similar warming sensation as the 12 but a little less pronounced. Incredible beer overall.

Leicht fruchtiger Geruch, etwas süß, trocken. Hefig-süß, würzig, auch bei diesem Bier merkt man das Alter. Röstmalziger Nachgeschmack, süß, sehr würzig. 
Danke an den Doppelbock für die Teilung des Bieres. 	 
Test vom 21.4.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: 11,11,11,12,-,12 - 11,57

pours deep purpleish brown with a lasting creamy head and some lacing.  aroma is not huge, consisting of raisins, sugar and apples.  body is strong and so is the carbonation.  taste is rich with notes of overripe fruit and caramel but the hops are strong as well leaving less sweetness than the aroma led me to believe.  theres a creamyness to this beer as well.  the alcohol is well hidden at first but quickly becomes apparent.  the finish is full, long and bitter.  This is a beautiful beer, and everything a belgian ale should be.

Bottle at Kulminator.  Pours brown with small white head.  Aroma is malt, dark fruits and slight yeast.  Flavor matches aroma with cherries, raisins, leather and a caramel sweetness.  Beautifully balanced beer.

Had a round of various Westys at Bryans. Thanks. This one pours a dark brown with a slight reddish tint. Nose of brown sugar, caramel, and yeasty aromas. Has a tinge of cherries and other dark fruits. The flavor is loaded with a bready character. Raisins and  brown sugar dominate the creamy, sweet finish. Not as big as the 12, but a delicious brew just the same.

Dark copper brown colour, very fluffy off-white head. Aroma of candy sugar, yeast, malts, caramel, fruits, dark dried fruits, quite pronounced alcohol, and spices. Flavour rather sweet, very malty, yeast, prunes, spices, nuts, hops caramel and some dark chocolate. Full body, quite bitter hops finish. Nice one, more refreshing than the 12.
(Bottle @ In de Vrede)

Bottle 330ml @ home
Pours hazy brown with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel, raisin, alcohol and prunes. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

7/05/2011 33cl @ In De Vrede - (2011-194) 
Dark brown beer with a red glare, pretty cloudy. Light beige head, unstable, adhesive. It is clearly noticeable from the head that the beer is still very young. Aroma: caramel, roasted sweet malts, fruity, bit of hops. MF: good carbon, full body. Taste: caramel, dried fruits, bit of hops. Aftertaste: some citrus, still caramel. Nice dry hoppy finish, preventing the beer from getting cloying.
Bottle. Color dark brown with medium head. Aroma dark fruits, sweet, sugar, caramel. Taste dark fruits, caramel, herbal, chocolate.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown color with ruby red notes, and a frothy beige head. Aroma is slightly tart, with alot of dark fruit and sweet malts, along with some yeast funk, a breadiness, cherry, red apple, caramel and some brown sugar notes. Flavor is not as tart as the aroma indicates, though I do get a slight amount of tartness. Other than that there is alot of dark fruit like raisins and figs, some cherry, caramel, faint chocolate, red apple, breadiness, brown sugar, some funk and yeasty notes. The body is medium with a slightly dry and creamy mouthfeel. Overall a really nice well balanced Trappist Dubbel, yet not an outstanding brew as lot of hype indicates.

330 ml bottle from eBay something like 2 years ago. This is my last rating from DLD this year, I think, unless it turns out I actually had DL De Muerte and not Conquistador De Muerte again. Anyway, keep in mind I was feeling pretty good at this point so my notes are short and almost illegible. This baby pours a cloudy nut brown color with an off-white head. Notes of chocolate and caramel malts, Belgian yeast, nuts, brown sugar and candi sugar, and floral notes. Medium-bodied, with low carbonation and a sweet, malty mouthfeel. Guess my shorthand was good for something. Looking back, I gave Westy 12 a 4.4 so I guess I did like this a bit better. I was shitfaced and probably liked everything and need to try this again but my numbers and exclamation points indicate enthusiasm.

Upon being introduced to phaleslu & rapebeer I was almost immediately offered a little Westy 8, right on guys! Pours a brown color, mine was the final pour of the bottle so its pretty hazy, the head is nice and bit and white. The lacing that the beer leaves on the glass is very pretty. The aroma is intensely nutty with lots of chocolate and nice touches of mustiness. The bouquet is earthy and woody and just intoxicating all together. The flavor is chocolaty with a mild spiciness and a mild warming alcohol presence. The beer is as the aroma suggested very nutty and while sweet maintains a perfect balance and control of that sweetness. 
The beer is rich & round. It coats your mouth and the carbonation is lively but not really sharp.

I thought westy 12 was very good, but this stuff is out of the ballpark awesome. Seriously one of the highlights of my day.

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2012 Just an all around fantastic beer. Had it during a sampling, but picked up an extra bottle of this - simply head and shoulders abpve the other brews we tried (incl. Chimay Red, Westmalle Tripel etc). Wonderfully rich and complex, both in aroma and taste. And it looks great too!

33cL bottle from specialty shop in Brussels. Pours a dark cola brown with a cream-white head that dissipates relatively quickly (though not immediately). Smells of malt sweetness, brown sugar, maple syrup, alcohol, yeast, spice (almost like some cinnamon, though not quite -- perhaps a bit of nutmeg and vanilla) with a slight hop character and slight hints of pear and banana (though the banana is not distinct) -- very fresh! The aroma sort of wafts out upon the initial pour -- quite something to behold. The mouthfeel is very smooth with slight carbonation; it initially foams a bit in the mouth before smoothing out. Taste is a sweet malt with emerging layers of caramel, spice, pear, yeast, alcohol, and some slight hops. Somewhat dry in the finish. Simply exceptional.

Bottle at In de Vrede. It pours murky dark brown, with a thick fluffy beige head and soft carbonation. The nose is caramel, toffee, fig, date, liquorice, menthol and salt.  The taste is very smooth and full of dark fruit: fig, date, prune and plum. As well as: wood, caramel, vanilla, mint, bread, charcoal, toast, liquorice, toasted sesame and coffee, with a very long roasted-bitter finish. It tastes fresh, complex and is very well balanced, but still very drinkable. It deserves its place at the top.

Nose is cherry, sweet tobacco, rosewood, broad malt, weak yeast, feel is velvet and broad, carb is low, taste is sherry, rotten fruit galore, mellow, weak rose, wood, and vanilla. Finish is balanced sweet malt and red grape

bottle direct from abbey, nice very nice caramel , flowers and light citrus aroma, hazy, brown, rocky head, brown foam, medium to heavy sweetness, lightly bitter, full body, creamy, slick feel, lively, long finish, full mouth of this beer incredible awwsome..light taste of warm alcohol
user_location: Cambridge and Kladno(Czech Rep.), Cambridgeshire, ENGLAND

text: 2008 vintage courtesy of belgianbeergal, thanks a ton for this yummy treat Amy! First time ive had the 8, and im very pleased. pours a hazy nearly opaque brown with an ample khaki head that has a hint of orange to it. the aroma is very bready with some freshly dried dates and other dark pit fruits. the flavor and mouthfeel are one of a kind, very full flavor with a body thats very rich and thick, very nice and very unique. theres a sweetness, a very slight funky brightness to set off the thick sweet malts, very well balanced. interested to try a freshy now and compare.

I brought this beer back from St sixtus in Watou three weeks ago. Drank the first one last night. The aroma is very pleasant and is similar to other Trappist Doubles. The aroma grows stronger and more pleasant as you drink it (slowly), allowing it to warm. Malt is the primary aroma with no hop presence. No yeast evidence either as would be the case with a Tripel.

The looks like a cup of coffee. It is rich and dark with a beautiful 2.5 inch light brown head that lessens but lingers for the duration. The head coats the sides of the goblet.

The taste is surprisingly strong of alcohol early in the drink. More so than the Westy 12. This surprised me. This diminished fairly quickly. The flavors dance on the tongue and are equally enjoyed in the rear of the mouth. The flavor strengthens and gets even better throughout the drink. I hated to see it end. The texture was typical Trappist, smooth, creamy and full.

Overall I really like this. I resisted having a second as I brought home a limited supply. I also want to age a few bottles a bit and see what I get.

Bottle. Pours a clear and dark brown beer with an offwhite head. The aroma is malt, caramel and alcohol. The flavor follows the nose with some additional fruit. The palate is sweetness. Overall a good beer.

Pours very cloudy brownish with chunks floating around. Large frothy head. Malty aroma, yeast. Taste is magnificent, sweet and yeasty, hint of raisins. Mouthfeel is very unusual, its smooth, lively carbonation and very creamy on the palate!. Overall among the best beers made.

A privilege to get to taste this beer.  Bottle from June 07.

Pours a rich medium brown, remarkably opaque.  Beautiful looking beer.  A thick, dark elixir with about a finger of the only kind of Belgian lace Im interested in.  The head left a gorgeous lacing on my goblet, subsiding slowly and evenly.

The aroma is strong and complex.  The usual fruity esters from the Trappist yeast are detectable in a stunning variety.  I picked up everything from Clove and Cardamom to Bubble gum and dark fruits.  

A luxurious mouthfeel, accompanied by a taste so marvelous and complex it simply cannot be adequately described with any degree of brevity.  Strong esters balance perfectly with rich malt sugar, and the hops lend an edge that evens the whole thing out.

My first experience with Westy, and it was a grand one.  Anyone who crosses paths with this beer is sure to come away satisfied.  Its truly a step above the rest especially when aged as my bottle was.  Worthy of the cost, no matter how much you pay, because there simply is nothing that can compare to it available in the US.

Simply outstanding.  I was ready for a nice beer, and was expecting something along the lines of a Rochefort, which is perhaps my favorite readily available beer.  But this truly blew all three Rocheys out of the water.  It is a cut above.

33cl bottle, thanks to Paul, brought back from Belgium last summer. Pours a ruby cloudy brown with a biege lacing across the entire glass. Smells nice and yeasty, raisins, bread. Carbonation comes alive once its in your mouth, creamy and gorgeous, very yeasty, sweet, coats your mouth in deliciousness. Dries out the mouth a bit on the finish, leaves a great taste. Not quite as complex as the 12 but delicious nonetheless. Wish I could get more on a regular basis

3/25/11. Bottle courtesy joes! Hazy deep brown pour with a small fizzy tan head thats gone fast. Malty aroma with yeast, caramel, and a hint of mint. Reminds of me of a ligher version of 12... Grapey, yeasty, smooth, caramel, and loveliness. Nice!

Got a Westy 8. Served in a Chimay goblet (at least its a Trappist glass). Thick fine brown head. The head was great when I poured it and has lasted as I drink. The head leaves a nice lacing on the glass. The aroma is amazing. That great smell of Belgian yeast, like on the air. The carbonation is steady with tiny bubbles all over the outside of the glass. The mouthfeel is smooth, I could drink 10 of these in no time at all. The flavor is sweet and yeasty. It is a great example of a style that I am not usually thrilled with, dubbels. I really like this beer a lot. Its truly one of the great beers of the world.

Serving type: bottle

Bottle, BBF 2007. Pours a medium tan/brown, with a creamy, off-white head. Well developed nose, with lots of notes from ageing in the bottle - dried fruits, cane sugar, tobacco, nuts, liquorice, madeira, prunes, very fruity and malty, hints of yeast, almost no hops. Medium bodied, quite elegant, some sweetness, and a rather low bitterness. Lively carbonation makes it fresh on the palate. Almost everything from the nose returns on the palate - a very complex and developed beer. I think it has passed its peak, and should have been drunk a year or two earlier, but its still a magnificent brew. (2010-08-22)
Pours copper with a dense white head. Aroma is  caramel, heavy dark fruit and alcohol. Flavour is caramel, dark fruit and alcohol. Light bitter.
12 ounce bottle.  Brownish color with a beautiful head.  Very complex and malty.  Very well made.

Thanks to Drowland for hooking us up with these goodies, and in all honestly, I enjoyed this one a bit more than the 12, a bit less on the dark fruits and a bit more sweetness and complexity that comes out from the alcohol. This is a world class brew, and one that I could use a LOT more of.

Bottle dated Oct 2005 (plucked from my large stash of old Westies) which makes it about 10 years old now. Deep brown/red murky coloured pour with a great beige head on top. Aroma of dark fruit, banana, spice. Tastes of dark fruit, spice, port, banana, plum, Christmas pudding, bread like, brandy. Really smooth. Reminded me of an antique shop (dont know why). Top notch stuff, I really should drink more of my stash, any helpers out there?!

The beer pours medium to dark murky muddy brown with a big 3 finger light tan head. The heads lasts about 5 minutes then fades to soapy head covering finish. There is decent lacing. 

The aroma is really light, to light to pull much out. Its pretty matly with some bread and light toffee. 

The taste is good not great very complex like its big brother. Its also very matly.

The feel is good pretty drinkable.

Inköpt på De Molens bryggeributik i Bodegraven.
Mörk vätska med gräddigt skum.
Doften är ganska tjock och av mycket diskret belgisk karaktär.

Smaken känns lite het, besk och med en lite unken underton. Lite toner av kola känner jag, men annars är det inte mycket att skryta av.
Kommer i håg att jag inte var så jätte impad av 12 heller, men lite bättre var den nog.

Pours a nutty dark brown. Earth, yeast, nut and a little bit of purple fruit in the aroma. A touch of plum. Roasted malt with some pretty dominant chocolate characteristics hit you on first sip. That fades into a molasses and plum sort of flavor that takes you back a bit and hits in a way you are not expecting. Grassy hop profile that primarily works its way in the aroma and especially after it warms a bit. Getting a lot of chewy grains in the flavor now too. A nice baked bread sort of aspect going on. Really complex and a true outstanding drink. I guess thats what 400 years of practice gets you.

Bottle stamped 29.09.10. Im guessing that means this is an 07 vintage.

Pours a deep dark chestnut brown color which is completely opaque with a one finger off-white head that slowly fades into a thin lasting ring. Minimal spots of lacing left behind.

Spicy, estery aroma with lots of vinous dark fruit, zesty pepper and earthy hops. Complex nose with lots of plum, grape, raisin, fig, date and dark cherry. This is complimented by a nice roasted malt presence with hints of chocolate and caramel and subtle earthy pine. Peppery with coriander as well as hints of yeast/bread, sweet alcohol phenol and licorice.

Medium bodied with a prominent spicy and hoppy flavor that lingers over the roasted malt body and sweet dark fruit notes into a dry finish. Dry, earthy and slightly bitter with some piny hop flavor which is complimented by the zesty, peppery spice. This is countered mid palate by a slightly roasted chocolate malt backbone with hints of caramel, toffee, biscuit and licorice. Hints of slightly chalky, bready yeast add complexity and fullness to the body. Toward the end of the swallow there is a very prominent vinous dark fruit flavor with hints of fig, raisin, plum, grape and dark cherry. The hops have held up surprisingly well and are very prominent in the flavor profile. The malt and dark fruit notes are enhanced as it warms, balancing things out a bit. ABV is excellently masked with subtle alcohol sweetness but no heat whatsoever making this pretty quaffable.

Overall, this beer is one of the most interesting trappist beers Ive had. Its well balanced but much hoppier than any Belgian beer(in this style) that I have encountered. The malt and dark fruit notes really start to shine as it warms so I highly recommend drinking it at cellar temperature or letting it warm up considerably to enjoy it at its fullest potential. Not as complex, flavorful or easy to drink as the 12 but its still pretty good.
Dark brown, almost black. Very malty aroma. Taste is mostly malt and some dark chocolate in the aftertaste.
2000 vintage. Smells like caramel,yeast,plum and apple. Tastes similar to smell, sweet dark fruits, spicy, lot of malts and some well balanced bitterness in the end. Great beer

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2012 Dark brown and quickly dissolving tan head. Yeast, nuts, apple, rice and dough. A rich and complex aroma. Heavy on malts, balanced bitterness and sweetness. Very tasty but cant live up to the Westvleteren fame as the 12 and blond can.

UPDATED: JUL 26, 2011 Opaque brown, verging on black in color. Beautifulcappuccino-colored head. Floral aroma of dates, prunes, floral honey. The taste is also sweet but well balanced with bitter hops and spices, with a little caramel and anise in the complex symbiosis of taste and smell. It is spitzenklasse!

Today I celebrate my birthday with a nice beer!!! 
Bottle 33 cl. Dark brown, cloudy with a nice lively lightbrown head. The aroma are nice malty, spices with a fruity end. Nice complex taste, but still little brother to the big brother. Malty, spicy/acidic and light hoppy, lively in the mouth, nice one!

Pours a dark brown murky with a nice big head that thined quicker than expected. A glimmer of amber coming through in the light. Smells of dark fruits, apple, yeast and spices. Dark Fruit, malt and the zesty yeast combine to flavor the beer, it is rich and full bodied yet not heavy on the tongue. Could drink this all day, just a wonderful beer.

This bottle was bought in Brussels about a year ago and kept in my cellar.

Bottle. Cap has 2.05.13 on the cap, reviewed on 2/2/11. Poured into a tulip glass a clear, deep ruby red brown color with a large fluffy 3 finger light tan head that slowly recedes. Head leaves some nice lace as it settles. The aroma is pretty nice with a subtle dark fruit smell along with some banana. Medium/light mouthfeel with some good carbonation. First taste yields flavors of dark malt, dark fruit, and some alcohol notes. Some lingering bitterness as well. The taste is actually a little more subdued than I thought it would be. The carbonation seems a little high for me as well and detracts from the flavors. Overall, Im just ok on this beer, it isnt exactly what I thought it would be and isnt as good as I wanted.

Deep burgundy colour, somewhat hazy. Thick, creamy head. I found i difficult to get any aroma out of it ! Maybe some marzipan. Mouth-filling, sweet, malty flavour. Warming finish. No doubt that this is a good beer, but I expected more.

Hazy dark brown with a lasting beige head. Aroma is sweet, dark malts, dried fruit, yeast and spices. Rather sweet flavor and full bodied. Soft finish. This is a very well balanced and complex beer. 190111

Bottle. Had high expectation to his beer. First taste was disappointed, but the second taste was great. Brown colour with a lasting big beige head. Aroma and flavour of caramel, spice, yeast, dark dried fruit and hops.

Beer gifted to me by someone who purchased at the Abby. Pours a dark brown with very little head. Low carbonation and a light wispy head. Complex aromas of brandy, madeira ,plum, deep heat and caramel. In the mouth the beer is rich and full bodied with loads of smooth fortified wine notes, stonefruit and a long bitter finish. A beer that definitly lives up to the hype.

The Trappist monastery at Westvleteren is known for making "The Greatest Beer in the World" with their "12," but what about the other beers they brew? Beer nerds tend to gloss over the "8" - a dubbel brewed in the traditional Belgian style. While not quite as complex and robust as the 12, this beer is still very impressive for what its able to accomplish.APPEARANCE AND AROMAI poured a 2010 vintage 11.2oz bottle into an authentic Trappist chalice. This beer looks very traditionally Belgian with a dark burgundy color and an extremely hazy body. It forms a small, off-white, soapy head that dissipates quickly and leaves no lacing.The aroma is akin to a white wine, which is strange considering its dark appearance. There seems to be notes of green apple, red apple, cherry, and a bit of alcohol.TASTEEvery time Ive drank a Trappist beer, the first thing I notice is how similar these beers are to wine in taste and Westvleteren 8 is no exception. Up front I get a strong taste of red wine, followed by a sharp, sour red grape flavor. The finish and aftertaste is cherry, plum, and green apple. There also seems to be a slightly bready component to the palate, giving the beer a bit of a malty sweetness.Usually, beers like this tend to grow more complex and more robust as they warm, but I found this beer stayed about the same from beginning to end. While I did notice quite a few flavors, I was surprised by how little energy comes from this palate. This could be due to the sharp sourness, but once it mellowed out, this beer drank more like a juice. Still, it tasted very good even though its quite different from most beers of  the style Ive experienced.DRINKABILITYBottle-conditioned Trappist beers tend to have a mouthfeel not unlike Pop Rocks candy, but Westvleteren 8 was surprisingly calm. Its only a medium-bodied beer with the liquid feeling slightly thick, but the lack of carbonation and peppery  texture was odd. This should be a sipping beer, but it can be drank in bigger gulps easily.This beer weighs in at 8% ABV, which is actually seems a bit high. There is little alcohol in the nose and next to none in the taste, nor in the constitution. The palate, mouthfeel, and potency all combine for a highly drinkable beer. This would ordinarily be a good thing, but because this beer is so rare and expensive you have to force yourself to savor every sip.FINAL THOUGHTSIm never afraid to say the emperor has no clothes and I think, technically, thats true with Westvleteren 8. Its consistently rated among the best of the best on Rate Beer and Beer Advocate, but I think thats due more to hegemony than true quality. Im sure this beer ages wonderfully and I would definitely like to try an older vintage if I could.NOTE: Watch the video version of this review at:http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ww3P0acK_MA

Another excellent craft from the Westvleteren Monastery.


Really blows my mind just how many ratings a beer that is only supposed to be purchased on the property has...and Im definitely a culprit!

Bottle from tarheels86. Hazy deep mahogany with a thick, fizzy khaki head that quickly fades to a thin, dense film. Aroma of dark pit fruit, caramel, bread, earthy and woodsy yeast and even a faint spicy hop scent. The flavor is loads of bread and dried, dark fruit with light bitter and sour coming though in the finish. Medium to full body with a prickly carbonation and a smooth, clean mouth feel that makes the beer seam lighter than it is. Excellent beer, this is one that you just keep going back to after each sip.  Thanks again GT for this world class beer.

330 ml bottle in Germany with much thanks to Steptin. Pours slightly hazy brown with a massive beige head. Aroma of grape, brown sugar and malt. Taste is sweet--fruity, malt, spice, with a small amount of hops. Medium mouthfeel. Long finish. Very nice. There is way too much hipe about beers from Westvleteren, but this one unlike the Blond Weste is a very good beer. It still lacks enough and falls short of a superior rating, but that being said an excellent beer.

8th April 2007  Warning! Early amateur rating! The very nice people at Beers Of Europe gave me this complimentary when I purchased a shed load of beer at the store - Cheers Guys! Caramel, toffee, HP sauce! Balanced flavours - very nice!

Bottle By in Bryssels @ beermania: Clear red/brown colour, with a big creamy white head. Aroma is fruity, fruirs, caramelly,sugar,yeasty, and a nice complex mix of caramelly sugar and fruits. Flavor had a nice creamy mouthfeeling of caramelly, malts fruits,sugar and yeast. Boig body, and a long caramelly/citrus yeasty finish. Nice and complex beer this one!!

Generously opened by BucketBoy on 12.01.10. Bottled on date: 08.18.10.

A massive four finger head settles to a creamy, frothy head. Theres an island of foam in the form of a heart. Dark almond body.

Smells softly of concord grapes, brown sugar, toasted nuts, and raisins. Quite luscious. 
Caramel and toasty malts, Belgian candy sugar, and dark fruitiness. This is fairly young and the earthy hops are quite apparent, providing a nice contrast to the sugary, vinous sweetness. The yeast adds a nice spiciness, which comes through most clearly on the finish as clove. Theres the smallest amount of rich booziness. 

Medium and lush. Medium to medium-high carbonation, with a long, slightly dry finish.

Drinkability is killer. I drank my half of the bottle in around ten minutes. I think I was expecting a bit more overt complexity, but that was mere foolishness, and this was a bit of a (well-deserved) slap in the face. Masterfully balanced and nuanced; a reminder of what beer can and should be.
Bottle. Plums, raisins, caramel throughout the sip with minimal bitter or hops. Nice and easy to drink.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2012 Tasted from a 11.2 oz bottle.  Hazy medium dark brown appearance with a brown/cream head.  Delicious sweet brown sugar, Belgian yeasty, toasty/a touch roasty malty, caramel aroma.  Carbonated dark candy sugar, Belgian yeasty, toasted malty, rich caramel, light toffee/chocolate flavor .  The candy sugar in this beer is very tasty. Sweet finish. Very tasty beer though it is quite sweet.

This beer pours a deep cloudy brown, almost black with a medium white head,  The aromas are dates, figs, candied sugar,   The mouthfeel is sticky, slightly bittersweet and heavy with medium carbonation.  This was a great beer that I really want to have again!

Bottle courtesy Ryan - thank you!  Polished brown in the glass.  Delicate pour produces a thin layer of foam hugging the edges of the glass with steady carbonation.  Aroma is date, warm cinnamon bread, nutmeg and other unidentifiable spices, milky caramel, and sweet malt buried underneath.  Smells amazing - even better than the 12.  A perfect 10 for aroma.  Flavor starts with some bitterness up front and then opens into date, raisin, caramel, sweet malt, and a lingering milky sweetness tinged with alcohol.  Excellent beer.

Rating #400.  Tasted from a 330mL bottle obtained in a trade, the cap reads 10.11.09.  Pours very dark amber with still a decent amount of light allowed through, with a thick beige head that slowly settles into a thick and rocky lace coating.  The nose is sweet caramel malt with cola, some earthy yeast, and a fruity aroma that is somewhere between (or a combination of) citrus and red berry.  The flavor starts off the same as the nose with cola and caramel malts, but there is an added vanilla component along with some milk chocolate and very light nuttiness.  The fruitiness is still there, and still just as hard to describe.  There is some bitterness along with the earthy flavor, but they both take a while to come through on the finish.  This beer is super complex and delicious.  The body is medium with light-ish carbonation and a very long and very complex finish that combines all of the components previously mentioned.

A very bold almost red wine grape aroma with a hint of almond.  a dark brown apperance very inviting. It has a toasted oats flaver with brown sugger followed by a slight alcohol flaver. Very plesant on the palate a medium body with a creamy texture.  Carbonation is soft and finishes a little dry. This is a great hgh quality beer that is hard to come by. love it!

33cl bottle poured into a Chimay Trappist glass.  Dark brown with very little tan head.  Aroma is fruit, brown sugar, slight bread.  Flavor is toasted malt, brown sugar, vanilla, apple, slight alcohol.  Medium body, medium carbonation.  Medium lasting, dry finish.  Very nice.

Refrigerated bottle poured into a westvletern glass.  Pours a dark brown with light brown upper portion.  Head is big off white and dies down.  Not much aroma, lots of lacing, and medium carbonation.  Taste is complex doughy malt, earthy yeast, and dry slightly hoppy finish.

A: Pours a dark, chestnut brown with a very nice head and lacing throughout.

S: Lots going on here. Dark fruits are there, but the dominant scent seems to be that of fresh, sweet red/black grapes. Very nice and interesting. Quite a bit of Belgian yeast coming through.

T: Lots of red grapes, slightly-roasted doughy malt, yeast, dark fruits, a bit of earth, and some very nice all-around sweetness.

M: Complex and creamy, not too alcoholic. Perhaps a tad bit thin.

D: Amazing. Such a complex and wonderful beer. I actually think I like this better than the 12, at least while they are relatively fresh.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-03-2010

33 cl bottle. Brown body with a fizzy to creamy beige head. A small bit of the foam stays on the beer. Complex aroma of toasted malt, plums and hints of chocolate, caramel and tobacco. The taste is sweet toasted malt as well with a warm sweet aftertaste. Great beer.

A very smooth and silky beer. Looks wonderful when you pour it out!
The aroma is very sweet (like brown sugar). You can really taste the fruits (little hints of figs, banana,...) and the malt (roasted and chocolate). The taste is slightly bitter. Its a very balanced beer, still one of the best in the world.

33 cl bottle, pours dark brown with an ok head, aroma of dark fruits, vanilla, malt and brown sugar with a hint of diacetyl, fairly sweet taste consisting of the same notes as the aroma, very smooth mouthfeel, very subtle alcohol, great and very enjoyable beer overall.

Hazy brown pour light reddish hue ... creamy off white head decent lacing ... fruity dark aroma plums, figs ..... taste of plums, apples and figs fruity belgian yeast sweet malt and very smooth and creamy with a dry fruity finish... the westys are so smooth and velvety you can see why all three are so highly rated

Transcription of an old BA review from 01-11-2010, with scores adjusted to RB scale. Will re-rate...someday.

BB on cap is not perfectly readable, however both month & year of expiration are imprinted clearly enough, saying 02. 2011. Assuming that the beer has been bottled 3 years prior to declared expiration date as is the case with 12, it belongs to 2008 vintage and is roughly 2 yrs old by now. Pouring into Rochefort chalice produces tan head transforming itself into thin lacy cap that lasts. Dark coppery brown with dark floaties of yeast.
Almost palpable aromas of sour cherries, dark brown sugar reach on molasses and all kind of berries powdered with cocoa or grated milk chocolate. The flavor profile consists of milk chocolate ice cream with sour cherries & berries and subtle touch of hoppy bitterness that is prolonged into lingering mild bitter aftertaste. Silky smooth, medium bodied nectar with absolutely no alcohol detectable. The smoothest, silkiest beer Ive ever tasted. Perhaps less diversity in aroma/flavor profile than12, without evident vinous component and a bit more pronounced hoppiness, but nevertheless equally good as the big brother.

So time to crack one of these babes. Pours hazy dark ruby brown with small tanned head in my trappist glass. Full bodied sweet, heavy with malts, fresh bread, prunes, fidges, raisins and melassis aroma. So nice! Flavor is sooo soothing lean, slightly acidy with a crisp mouth feel . Sweet, fruity, raisins, fidges, alcohol, madeira wine, tart hoppy ... lean like velvet, just like the 12. Lean fruity alcohol tart palate feel. Finish is fruity sweet turning into  dry bitter hoppy aftertaste.

Very complex beer with so many aromas and flavors. Need to drink few more to understand the whole story I think. And the bitter tart aftertaste just hangs there in my mouth minute after minute, just amazing.

Tasted from a bottle brought back by a friend from a trip in belgium. The smell makes reminds me a little the Orval but less intense. As much the beer gets warm the more the smell and the taste become intense. It has a little taste of nuts and some banana flavour. The alcool is not so much present and it has a nice body. The problem is that the more you drink it the more you enjoy it... well it is not really a problem.

Very recomendable

MY 1500TH RATING!
Location: I got to try this wonderful beer at In de Vrede, August 2010


Aroma: Super complex nose of chocolate, dark fruits, coffee, berries, roasted malts, etc

Appearance: This one pours a really nice looking brown color with a slight red hue

Flavor: The taste is also rather complex, lots of rich malty flavors that are in a nice balance

Palate: It has a full bodied feel, but doesnt sacrifice drinkability, smooth and wonderful finish

Overall Impression: 
This is rating # 1500, so I needed a special one, and, this one obviously fits the bill!  I actually did the Westy 12 as my 1000th rating, but that was the first time I got to try it.  On this trip I got to drink the 8, 12, and Blond, and was able to procure (and bring back to the US with me) a few 12s and a Blond.  Unfortunately, I wasnt able to buy any 8s to go, so this will probably serve as my only sampling of this one for a while.  Anyway, awesome stuff.  It doesnt quite hit the level of the 12, but it is amazing in its own right.  Not much more I can say here, I hope I did this beer justice...

UPDATED: DEC 17, 2014 Bottle:
Best before: 30-11-2006
Small off white to light beige foamy head, disappears quick into lacing.
A dark reddish almost brown hazy beer.
Smell lots of fruit (prunes, berries), malt, (brown) sugars, honey and a hint of alcohol.
Taste is a bit port-a-like, fruits, malts, grass, meat, sugars and hops.
Light dry and bitter to more dry in the end. Hint of warmth of alcohol and a tiny teeny bit watery, but very well balanced.
Re rate 2014: decent drinker but had much better. Malty with some prunes and soap.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Bottle, 2006 vintage.  A light maple syrup brown color pour with a small off white head.  Good carbonation.  Absolutely no oxidation.  Smooth brown sugar, plums, raisins, figs, with just a hint of banana.  I think the complex nature of this beer has gelled to form a smooth easy sipping Belgian Ale...

Bottle via trade with phaleslu, thanks Peter. Pours dark brown with a tall, creamy, beige head that has excellent retention. Aroma is wow, fantastic, hard to describe effectively, rich, deep port drenched dark fruit, raisins, tart stone fruit, burnt sugar, dark caramel, a touch of chocolate, rich autumn earth and raw nuts. Flavor is dark fruit, cocoa, nutty toffee, yeasty, toasted, sweet white bread, lots of candi sugar, earth, hints of floral hops, spice and, I could go on and on about whatever note pops into my head, but I will just stop at saying this stuff is immensely complex and delicious. Palate is medium bodied, with a feel thats difficult to explain, sort of a neutral creaminess, with a moderate, smooth carbonation. What a delicious brew, seriously, this stuff is goddamn amazing.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2014 In  bottle; brought this back from Belgium (hard to find). Pours a dark brown with large cream color head. Taste of chocolate and plum, with mild spice and creamy notes. Very good beer .... wish I could get more. Very easy drinking beer

[330ml bottle that Lee bought back from Belgium - cheers mate!] Brown; large beige head; a disturbingly dark sediment rapidly accumulates in the bottom of the glass.  The aroma is of coffee, chocolate and strong alcohol.  These flavours continue into the flavour to be joined by dark brown sugar.  Fruity notes start to emerge - figs, raisins and maybe a bit of baked banana.  It could be too sweet, but theres just enough roasted malt bitterness to carry it off.  As to the mouthfeel, theres a light prickly fizz at first which soon gives way to a velvet-smooth creamy mouthfeel.  Although the alcohol and chocolate dominate, this is possibly a more balanced beer than the 12, and its a beautiful late evening sipping beer.

The plain, label-less bottle shows there is more to beer than advertising. Aroma is a mixture of fruit, candy, toffee. Pours a dark, murky brown with a thick head. Flavour is extremely complex, bubblegum, candy, toffee, hops, some roastiness. Spectacular palate. An amazing beer.
Bottle. Large off white foamy head over a hazy red-brown body. Good lacing. Aroma of spices and sweet chocolate. Taste of plums, sultanas with a long fruity bitter finish. Medium bodied.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2014 Pours a muddy brown with a light brown head. Theres something sort of magical about the Westy glass... Aroma is huge and delicious. Heavy, rich malts with vanilla and raisins. Sweet flavor that ends with light bitterness. Very drinkable for a high abv. Perfectly balanced throughout. All-around fantastic beer.

Pours a murky cola-color, with a  thick, frothy head. The aroma is intensely pleasing, with characteristics of freshly juiced grapes, plums, caramel, and yeast. The flavor is quite complex and fruity and at times it is almost tangy, but it is also light and not exceptionally sweet. The high carbonation masks some of the flavor but also the alcohol.

Bottle @ In De Vrede, Westvleteren. Ive had this beer before, but that was in my pre-RB days. Thus, its a pleasure to rate this beauty in its own "home". :-) Like all the beers consumed here this afternoon, Westvleteren 8 is served in proper glassware; a murky dark brown teak-colored body crowned with an elegant, creamy, inch-thick off-white head. Aroma is a classic "dubbel/strong abbey ale"-blend; raisins, figs, caramel malts and notes of dark candy sugar. The smooth and creamy texture brings out flavors of roasted malts, toffee and hints of bitter hops; particularly in the aftertaste. But, once again, it is not the mere taste of Westvleteren that has made its reputation. Rather, its the composition and mouthfeel - the sweet, symphonic mixture of otherwise known flavors, fused into a higher state of tactile bliss. The Extra 8 is yet another example of this art. Although not as high in caliber as its big brother, the fabled Westy 12, this is a thoroughly well-crafted brew that deserves all the hype bestowed upon its humble, label-less body. A great beer experience.

Bottle, no label @Olutkellari, Helsinki. Poured dark brown with a lasting brown head. Aroma is complex, dark fruits, roasted malt, toffee. Flavor is very nice, roasted malt, liquirice, fruit and spices. Smooth smooth palate.  In the finish alcohol pushes through a bit.  A masterpiece.

Bottle (33cl) from Ølbutikken, Copenhagen. Deep reddish chocolate colour. Large light beige head, settling down to a frothy film with nice lacing. Highly complex aroma; difficult to discern individual elements due to a mindbogglingly well balanced and harmonious blend. Its malty, fruity, vegetal, herbal and spicy. Medium to full body, average carbonation. Malty finish with yeast, caramel, prunes, licorice and cloves, and a lasting subdued bitterness.

Courtesy of my wifes trip to Belgium, I was able to obtain it!  Very happy to complete tasting all the trappistes.    This one was surprising in that I was expecting angels to come soaring out of the bottle based on the reviews on ratebeer and beer advocate --- and it was really similar to the other top shelf Belgian beers.  Ill give it a nod because of the coffee, date, and general maltiness that I wasnt really expecting.  Also, it wasnt as sweet as other abbey ales.   It had  a complext taste which Im finding difficult to describe.  The color was a translucent brown with a medium head that barely stuck to the glass.  Alcohol was present but tempered.   Overall, Ill give it a couple of bonus points for the sheer difficulty in finding it in the States -- hype counts, right?

Appearance:  dark chocolate brown, with lighter caramel notes at the edges; even one-finger creamy khaki head that shrinks but lasts; impressive lacing.  Aroma:  fresh-baked brown bread, molasses, figs/ dates/ raisins, cherry and prunes; undertones of port.  Taste:  toffee, gently roasted nuts and brown sugar; tangy and slightly sour herbal notes (clove) to balance; a little boozy.  Finish:  lingering slight bitterness, with an almost white wine-style dryness to balance the sweet malty flavors.  Notes:  5th anniversary present from my wife.  Simply incredible.  Perfectly balanced; the most balanced beer Ive ever had.  Lives up to the hype. Well-carbonated, yet velvety smooth.  LOVE IT.

Bottle. 12 oz, Split with James and Vin, Pours a firm, hazy sparkling brown with tons of fine sediment and a rich, lasting, velvety smooth beige head that rests on the surface through the whole session. Aroma of pure fresh baked bread, with sweet traces of barley and malts, grapes, plums, figs, and dried dates. Medium bodied with a full, rich, chewy palate. Finishes with a nice, filling, slightly warm touch. Excellent all around.

Bottle split with pat and vinny.  Pours a pitch brown body with a thick haze and what looks like some sediment, nice light brown lacing that lasts throughout. Aroma is doughy, buttered bread, sweet malt, raisins. Mouthfeel is smoothly and thick - delicious loaves of bread fill my mouth, raisins and malt with slight Belgian spices.
Bottle at Jimmacks invitational. Reddish brown with white head. Nose and taste of raisin, dates, dried fruits, yeasts, fig, coconut, nuts and all sorts of subtle complexities. Very smooth.

Bottle. Aroma of portwine, plums, malt and cane sugar.  Unclear dark brown colour with light brown head. Sweet and spicy flavour of plums, raisins, dates and roasted malt with a slightly bitter finish.

UPDATED: AUG 10, 2010 Bottle.

A - Dark garnet mahogany with a deep amber hue on the edge. Huge, fluffy, creamy, thick, frothy, off-white head with amazing retention finally settling into a very thick and creamy lace.

S - Good amount of sweet, caramel, and slightly bready malt base. Dark and golden fruit on top of that with a lot of spice (cinnamon, nutmeg, some clove and allspice, amongst others). Wonderfully balanced and strong and enjoyable fruitiness.

T - Similar to the nose with a rich, sweet caramel and bready malt taste being pretty strong. Also a good amount of molasses, brown sugar, and dark candi sugar along with the spices. Fair amount of dark fruit and a bit of golden fruit (particularly apple). A touch of nuttiness is also present.

M - Medium to full body with a good amount of carbonation. Very smooth and creamy.
