D - Very easy to drink. Flavors all work well and have a complex mixture. Extremely smooth and goes down easy. Alcohol is very well hidden.

Notes: Best before 30/09/12. Very good beer, and right at the same level as the 12. Very complex, malty beer. Very easy to drink, if only it was easier to get.

1.5 year old bottle, pours a brown with a medium creamy and lasting head. Aroma is sweet and caramel, some hops, dark fruit (plums), roast malts. Taste is bittersweet, with an acidic touch. Warm alcoholic touch in the aftertaste and very warming. Had alot of westvleteren 8, but the aged ones are the best!

Served from bottle into a McChouffe goblet.  Pours a dark brown with one finger off white head that contains a dusting of brown sediment on the top.  Maintains excellent lacing throughout.  The aroma is comprised of mat, fruit, alcohol, and citrus.  The flavor is of big fruit, alcohol, malt, and a smooth creamy followthrough.  It is medium on the palate with high carbonation.  Overall this brew is phenomenal.  I was expecting it to be good, but wow...  The aroma and flavor of this brew is beautiful.  Definitely the best of this style I have had to date.  Believe the hype people!

Bottle bought at bier tempel in Brussels. Lovely dark brown colour, with a touch of red. Nice beige head.  Fruity aroma, with raisins and dark fruits. Nice warm mouthfeel, and almost no alkohol taste. Kind of oaky touch on this one. Expensive, but it beats its reputation. Nice beer!
Bottle courtesy of Fata. This was an awesome beer.  Great  red color with taste of dried fruit and raisins.  There was a hint of sugary notes.   Nice carbination and just a great beer

33 cl bottle brought back from Brussels last year.  100th rating.  Pours a dark brown with a hint of red.  Aroma of sweet malt, fruit, caramel and toffee.  Tastes of raisins, cherries, figs with a hint of chocolate.  Each sip is better than the previous one.  Minimal alochol taste. Amazingly complex.  Simply wonderful.

330 ml bottle, bought at Voldby Købmandsgård, Denmark. ABV is 8%. Cloudy dark brown colour, huge and lasting beige head. Aroma of wood, dark fruits and spices, hints of leather. Outstanding flavour with oaky and vinous notes, also notes of dark candi sugar and dark dried fruits. Fairly sweet, moderate hops in the finish. Expensive, but worth it.

Bottle. Pours a deep brownish red with an beige head. Dark fruity aroma, with berries, caramel and some spices. Great soft mouthfeel. The flavor is very well balanced and complex, with sweet dark malty notes, dark fruits, spices, and a little bit of an earthy/peppery notes. Really damn good.

This beer (gasp) might be better than the 12, for me at least.  It just nails what an Abbey Dubbel is meant to be.

So smooth, great alcohol warmth.  Some spicy banana notes.  Raisiny, dark fruits, but not enough that you miss the hops which barely touch the taste.  Pours deep red/brown w/ offwhite/tan head.
Really liked this beer. Also im a huge fan of dubbel. An amazing beer. Especially its history, and the way to get it. Buy it, if you get the chance.

12 oz. bottle (courtesy of Brabander, who has been so generous to so MANY of us) into a chalice.
Pours a dark brown with a reddish tint where light penetrates. Head was massive on the pour but settled to a skim of frothy, eggshell white. Nose is, at first bombarded by sweetness with raisins, cherries, toffee, bready yeast, brown sugar, molasses. Taste is rum, raisins, grape, caramel. Tartness comes in and the finish is a complex interplay - sweet, sour, dry. There is a nice alcohol warming as well. This beer is highly carbonated at the start but calms as it warms. Mouthfeel is medium to heavy and almost chewy, coating the tongue but very pleasantly. I am not a huge fan of Dubbels, but this truly is an exemplary beer. If you can get it, you must.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 A: Dark, muddy brown body. Moderate, creamy off-white cap. Held for a bit before crashing. Spotty lacing.

S: Rich, dark fruits. Cherries, figs, raisins. Some caramel and toffee malts hide out in the background.

T: Deliciously dark. The cherries and raisins really stand out from a complex backbone of caramel and toffee. Just a hint of booze shines through. Some candi sugars make themselves known as well.

M: Medium to full bodied. Good carbonation levels carry the flavors to the tongue well. Nice lingering finish.

O: Superb. A very nice dubbel, perhaps the best? The combination of profound flavors, solid carbonation, and a good body makes this a very pleasant experience.

What a treat, many thanks to my friend Jason, who brought this back from his European travels. Aroma of brown sugar, candy apple, rum and sweet caramel. Appearance is ruddy brown with tan head. Flavor matches the nose. Palate is otherworldly bubbly and effervescent. I would love to try this and the "12" back to back one day.

Poured murky with deep ruby-brown color and a tan, lively head. Fruity aroma of raisin, plum, red grapes, tons of malts, not that much of hops. Medium dense body with huge amount of carbonation. Subtle sugary sweet taste, no taste of the alcohol. Complex, serious brew.
OK, so its my favorite beer hands down. Jealously guarding stash which I bought at the abbey. Lives up to the hype.

(12oz bottle).  8 years old.  Pours rub red with off-white head.  Aroma of alcohol, raisins, fig (port-like).  Taste is sweet with some light sourness.  Medium bodied and somewhat thin because of age.  No carbonation.  This is a great beer!

Wow, so pleasing to every sense starting with a homey sweet aroma. There is a bright dark amber color, creamy decent head, and good sediment floating around. Has similar raisin bread flavors as the Westy 12, so smooth and perfect on the palate.

11.2oz bottle, dated 22/9/10, courtesy of madmitch76. thanks, ken! pours a hazy, dark, rusty brown with a thick, creamy, off-white head leaving chunky lacing. aroma is fantastic with a delicate blend of herbs, spices, and fresh bread (almost like herbed focacia) with fruit notes of baked apples, figs, and cherry skins with hints of caramel cake, dry grass, and toasted nuts. flavor is absolutely wonderful with fruity notes of fresh apples, pears, and red plums up front backed by earthy, herbal hops, winter spices, and sweet raisins with sweet caramel, doughy belgian yeast, and a bit of smokey molasses on the swallow. palate is full bodied and creamy on the tongue with strong carbonation and a lingering fruity, biscuity finish. overall, a great belgian strong not that i expected anything less.

Appearance: Dark, murky brown - the typical dubbel color, but with exceptionally good head retention. 

Smell: Dry and spicy; plum, fig, black licorice and herbal hops. 

Taste: Bold, dry and slightly tart. The flavor notes at fig, licorice, apple and toasted nuts. Well-hopped in the finish, it ends bitter and dry. A subtle sweetness comes out as the beer warms. 

Mouthfeel: Extremely smooth on the tongue. Medium-bodied with gentle carbonation. 

Drinkability: The dryness really adds to the drinkability - if not for the rarity I could see myself drinking this often. 

Notes: Different but every bit as good as Westvleteren 12. This is probably the best dubbel Ive had, with St. Bernardus coming fairly close.

Bottle poured at room temperature into a trappist style glass. Poured cloudy brown with small, fizzy white head. Aromas of bread, herbs, earth, spices. Flavor was a little acidic and mildly sweet. It was fairly carbonated. Overall, it was absolutely fantastic. It has successfully lived up to its reputation.

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2015 Some folks like this better than the 12, including the missus.  I think both beers are excellent, the 8 probably as good as the 12.  I think some feel the 12 is too much and the 8 is a more pleasant toned down version.  Regardless of your preference this is still a great beer.  Serving: Bottle

2008 bottle from a moonlighting monk on e-bay (stored for the past 2 years, the bottle not the moonlighting monk).. Explosive dark brown pour with a beige head. Aromas of baked apple, fresh bread, some caramel, pear, peach, malts, quite nutty. Flavours of raisins, licorice, figs, dates, toffee. Slightly bitter. Has a fortified wine quality to it.  The flavours cascade into a sweet, malty and bitter finish. Great stuff, gets better on every sip. Very complex and well balanced brew.

Birra buonissima dal colore rosso scuro con una buona schiuma cremosa.Al naso viene subito messo in risalto il malto seguito dai sapori di frutta soprattutto prugna e frutti rossi.Al gusto si ha un attacco dolciastro ,equilibrato però dalle diverse spezie.Buon tenore alcolico ma comunque molto beverina......Ottima da assaggiare assolutamente

Bottle from my amazing wife. I had this in a taste-off with similarly strong Belgian ales by Chimay, Rochefort, and St. Bernardus (among others.) I found the Westy to have the most complex aroma and flavor profile, though certainly not the strongest of either. Thats not to say its a mild flavor, more that its very smooth, well balanced, and hits the taste buds with waves of different characteristics. After doing a similar taste-off with the West 12 and its rivals, I came away remembering the Westy 8 as my favorite of the bunch, the one Id buy the most if it that were financially possible.

Bottle shared by DuffmanSW. Poured a golden brown color with tiny fuzzy head. Aroma was toasted dark fruits and bread dough. Taste was raisins, plums and grains. Pallet was super carbonated and dry. Overall pretty tasty. Tastes like a Westy 12 Light.

Bottle.  Pours a dark Ruby brown, kinda chunky, with a thin beige head.  Aroma is very toast and bready with some molasses, grain, and a hint of sulphur.  Flavor is very grainy and slightly yeasty with a bit of dark dried fruit, yeasty bread dough.  Full bodied with generous carbonation.
01.09.10 Bottle shared with mspindler and joetheyounger....Brown pour with off white head...Aroma of caramel, figs, raisins...Flavor is raisins, dates, very balanced..super carbonated. Good

Sweet malty cherry aroma with a light amount of vanilla. Dark brown color with a small tan head. Sweet beginning mellowing in the finish. Light spots of bitterness but mostly completely smooth throughout. Moderately thick silky palate.  Complex balance of flavors with the spices,fruit and yeast.  This one seems to have been aged a bit.  Thanks for sharing JB.

Bought this January 2008 from Belgian Shop, finally getting around to drinking this, not sure how old it REALLY is.  Wow.  surprised, but I think this does give the 12 a run for its money.  Had heard that and doubted it.  Shared the bottle with Ron, a small bottle, but savored it slow and it seemed like a fine serving.  Swirly patterned head, dark murky brown, looked very appetizing.  Nice nose, heavy esters, wine, plums.  Palate is sugar, this might have been on the edge of turning as I thought there might be a bit of acidic vinegar.  Carbonation is nice, complex palate, sticky, tingly as you let it sit on your tongue.  Outstanding.

Bottle. Is it worth the hype? You better believe it. Ive had the 12 and thought it was good but not all that it was hyped to be. This one is way better in my opinion. Poured a dark brownish color with a small white head. Aroma raisian, plum, and figs. There were some floaters in the beer. Flavor was molasses, grapes, dried fruits,and a vanilla flavor..I wish I could get more of this beer. Better savor it when you can get it. I need the blonde to try the entire tri fecta. 12 was good but this blows the 12 away. Better balance and a lingering in the throat. Love it.

Pour is muddled brown.  aroma is yeasty, honey, dark sugar, grape soda.  Flavor is dark fruit, apricots and dates with tons of yeast character.  mouthfeel is medium to light.  tasty but certainly no 12.

Dark brown with a slight reddish haze. The aroma is bursting with dark fruit, cherries, brown sugar, caramel, and yeasty fruity spice-dough. Every dark fruit profile is covered, as is nearly every incarnation of dark sugar. The flavor loaded with dark fruit and yeast character. Raisin, plum, fig and date combine with biscuit and dough to create an epic concoction. The palate is rich, thick, creamy, and pillow with a sweet smacking finish. Anyone who says they like this more than the 12 is kidding themselves. A thinner, more yeast forward version of the 12, but delicious just the same.

Dark brown pour with a reddish tint and a small ivory colored head. Aroma holds awesome doughy yeast, dark Belgian spices, fig, caramel, raisin, and honey. Flavor is extremely yeasty, with tons of bread and grain, along with raisin, clove, cinnamon, and caramel. Palate is drinkable and tasty, but slightly more watery than Westys 12. A very good Belgian strong ale, but not as epic as I expected.

Notes from a tasting in 10/08

Bottle ordered and consumed at In De Vrede, the abbey cafe.

Pours a murky brown topped with a creamy and thin ivory head. Leaves sheeting lace on the glass. Smells strongly of dark fruit, vanilla, oak and rich bready malt. Rum-soaked raisins and some squishy-ripe currant in the aroma too.

Just a hint of alcohol in the mouth but a lot more of that raisin and sweet bready maltiness. Yeasty.Prunes and currant, toffee and rich malt.Big and sweet body but still there is a very detectable evidence of persistent herbal hops in the finish.

Its lovely and warming as you drink it. Just as good as its big brother, just enough character to distinguish it from being Westy 12, Jr.

33 cl bottle, Brussels, Belgium via Beer Mania. Deep brown colour, musty yeast aroma with a velvety smooth texture. A distinct breadiness with some earthy tones, some faint banana and a lingering alcohol finish.

Bottle.Dark brownish colour with off-beige head.Aroma of yeast and dark dried fruits,caramel and dark chocolate feels over powering but nice and has a round mouthfeels who stays and give a fruity powerful finish.

(Old BA rate - bottle)
Dark tawny brown color with a creamier looking, slightly off-white head. In the aroma, pruney/raisiny maltiness with a bit of alcohol peeking through. Several layers of sweetness involved with candied sugar and a bit of an herbal aroma. Maltiness dominates with the raisin and dark fruit flavors from the aroma really shining in the flavor. Sweek cakiness, toffee, and a little bit of lighter fruit flavors as well. Little touch of peppery alcohol. Medium MF, but I might have expected this to be a little heavier considering the look and overall complexity. It does coat and cover the palate really well, and provided a warming finish. Wonderfully drinkable with the numerous layers of flavor that hit the palate. Even though it is a rich brew, I had no trouble savoring every last bit of it. Overall, I have to say that this lives up to the hype.

2007 Bottle consumed today.

Appearance: Dark amber that gets more brown like as the glass is filled. Soft creamy 2 fingers of light mocha head with medium retention and some lacing. The head is more impressive than the body to me. So soft and lush looking.

Smell: Dark fruits, a touch of caramel, and a touch of toffee. Predominantly dark fruits though.

Taste: Spicy yeast and a mellowed sugar rush to the forefront with dark fruits following. A touch of hops and another touch of caramel come in the finish which is not very drawn out. Fairly clean and very appetizing. A delicious dubbel.

Mouthfeel: Lush carbonation and a well crafted effervescence create a world class mouthfeel. Probably my favorite characteristic of this brew.

Drinkability: One of the smoothest, easiest to drink, 8% ABV beverages that will touch your lips.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-28-2009

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2010 Pours a chocolate murky brown haze with an off white head.  Is less creamy and the alcohol comes through more than with its 12 brethren. Sweet up front.  Dark fruit throughout. Nice chocolate notes on the back end.  Dry sweet finish.

Pours a deep brown with a off white head.  Aroma is dark fruit, spices and breadyness.  Taste is sweet with a dry finish.  Mouthfeel is creamy and smooth.  Nice warming sensation on the back end. Thanks to chalsk for this one.

This little brother to 12 is almost as good. I had it once at In De Vrede and didnt care for it that much. I think this was due to having the Blonde and 12 right before it. After getting back home with a few cases of it I had to change my mind. Pours almost identical to the 12, less head and not the abundance of aromas as big brother has. But almost just as tasty. I know Ill run out of both one day, but until then I am enjoying these when I can.

Had this one in Belgium. Pours very dark red-brown. Head is begie and quite creamy big. There is yeast flaces floating around in this brew. Aroma does not convince me. Well there is quality with it´s malty sweetnes. Also dark fruits and spices. Also some yeast. When comming to taste it I really see the complex quality in this on. Loaded with different flavors. Sweets, malt, dark fruits, dark chocolate, ´brown sugar, pepper, yeast and a pleasent light bitter taste. Palate is round and smooth.

Amazing! Full, creamy, malty, slight chocolate.
The best beer i have ever had!!
The best dubble Ive had hands down. Sweet and complex with slight traces of hotness. Awesome

malt,portevin,vanilje Ud.:kastaniebrun, klar,bundfald,Skum hvidt, korthold rolig e.Smag:sød moderat, Bitter moderat Krop:medium For.:cremet Brus: flad 
(33cl f)[home]

A: The crack of the cap let loose a gusher all over my lap. Once I managed to get the beer into my goblet, the pour is a dark mahogany color with a fluffy tan head that sticks to the glass.

S: The nose is rich and fruity with notes of plums and raisins. There is plenty of malty and sugary sweetness and some Belgian yeast esters and a faints spice.

T: The flavor is chocolatey and sweet with hints of molasses and caramel. The raisins, plums, and figs provide fruitiness and along with the alcohol, a rum-like flavor.

M: The body is smooth and medium to full bodied with a creamy and smooth carbonation.

D: My first Westy didnt disappoint. Im not always the biggest fan of dubbels, but this was quite complex and flavorful. I understand why its so highly regarded.

Bottle cap date. 12.02.12. Consumed April 2010. A reddish-brown beer with a decent head. The aroma is somewhat bready, honey, nuts, some spice and reminds me of a lighter version of the 12. The taste had bread, raisins, brown sugar, with a little bit of dark fruits in there. There is a good amount of carbonation and either that or the yeast or alcohol prickles the tongue. Im thinking this is a smaller recipe of the 12.

Bottle, 02 vintage I believe. Brune pour with white head. Sweet fruity esters, candied sugar aroma. Plummy, sweet sugar, toffee and maybe even some chocolate, this flavor is meant to be savored. Would have like to do 8 vs 12 side by side, next time. Outstanding with some time, like the twelve.
33 cl bottle. Along with the Westvleteren 12 is the best beer ever tried. Simply wonderful.

Bottled. Beautiful tan/beige head atop a dark caramel brown with white sediment very present. Aroma is very fresh fruit, very rich dark toffee candy, light mango and white grape and maybe pear but not really (worth mentioning). Flavor is also very fruit oriented, variety in fashion, with sweet going delicately bitter with big hops to finish. Nice flavor hops coming through with fruits and lighter floral tastes. Really something but typical trappist but certainly the best of these Trappist Ive had yet.

"Shared by a very generous friend who received this via trade. Mottled brown body producing an enormous head that collapses over time. A thick coat of lacing and hazy body create for a great looking glass of beer. Unique aroma that contains some of the common fruity sweetness within this style, but theres also this inviting upfront scent of buttered cabbage and celery...I know it doesnt sound appealing but it was very nice when jumbled together with the caramel, anise, and licorice. Full bodied with a comforting warmth, drank fairly easy with a smooth finish. Dark fruits, a hint of clove, cooked veggies, molasses and many more discreet underlying flavors. An odd yet wonderful blend."

Pours deep purple brown from 2 year old bottle.  Aroma is figs, raisins, some light chocolate and a bit of apple.  Taste up front is some nice apple flavor leading into a bit of dark fruit with figs and raisins finishing with a bit of alcohol burn and some chocolate.  Might have had a bad bottle, didnt last like the rest said it would.  Still good, but would like to rerate.

(330ml bottle about 1 year old) murky brown pour with some floaters, nice lasting cream head. Nose of raisin, figs, Belgian yeast and alcohol. Taste of figs, rum raisins, alcohol heat, light chocolate and toasted fruits. Well carbonated, more alcohol heat and some bittering hops on the palate finish. Great beer and I may have enjoyed it more than the 12. Need to have the 12 again.
Nothing to add to what other 1160 people wrote. Its truly delicious. Surely my best beer till now. (not tried Westy 12..)

Bottle thanks to my son, Keith (Fata2683).  Ive had the 12 but I think this one is even better. Im pretty sure this was a 2008 vintage.  It was filled with beautiful, luscious floaters, tasted sweet, spicey, creamy, and the alcohol was definitely noticable but not obtrusive.  I could drink this all day, every day.  My highest rated beer to date.

Bottle. Pours hazy brown coloured with a nice creamy lasting and lacing light brown head. Aromas of dried fruit, caramel, yeast, nuts, brown sugar and roasted malt. Flavours of sweet malt, dried fruit, nuts, syrup/sugar, chocolate and spices. Great beer.

It took my wife 300 calls to get through on the beer phone. Drove from Kaiserslautern, Germany to the Abdij St. Sixtus and picked up the max 2 cases for 80 Euros. Shared this w/ SkyCop32. Pours a deep dark reddish brown color. Aromas of dark fruit, caramel, and some spice. Flavors are dark cherries, plums, and some spice. Alcohol is really hidden in the deep flavors. This stuff is head and shoulders above the 12.

Bottle shared by Ryan on his going away party from Hangar 24. Dark brown with a few floaties. Aroma (if I can remember) was a little dark fruits, dark caramel. Flavor was rich dark malt and quite incredible. (1161)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Im drinking a bottle of this with my wife (for breakfast!) on our 10th wedding anniversary. We picked this up in 2008 at Cafe In de Vrede after walking the 7km from Poperinge to get there! It was well worth it then, and its certainly not diminshed with age. What a delicious beer. Others have described the flavours so well that I see no need to add to them, instead Ill say what really stands out for me. The aroma is almost everything one could want in a beer of this style. It only misses out on a 10 for two reasons, both subjective. 1. I know the 12 is better and have a bottle of that still to have tomorrow, and 2. A 10/10 for me would need hops, and there are none here. It is still an aroma one can lose oneself in. Figgy, nutty, notes of fresh baked datebread waft around in my brandy snifter. The flavour is no letdown, losing marks only for a slightly chalky sensation  dont remember in the fresh sample on tap at In de Vrede. Still, what an achievement. Roll on tomorrow and the 12. Theres nothing "overhyped" about this beer, it really is worth it.

First tasted 2009-06-06 at In de Vrede at St. Sixtus Abbey, but this rating is based on a bottle I picked up at Bier Tempel in Brussels. 330 mL bottle, expiry 2010-11-22, served in a branded Trappist glass. Pours murky red-brown with a tall, frothy tan head and clumps of sediment. Head has great retention and great lace. Aromas of sweet roasted malt, molasses, chocolate, nuts, dark fruit, pepper and spice. Flavour is sweet roasted malts throughout. Against this backbone, a complex symphony of spice, coffee and chocolate blended with peppery alcohol emerges. As it warms, nuts and spice become more prominent. Finish is nutty, dry roasted malts and alcohol with some hot spice. Medium in body with a smooth, creamy texture and lively carbonation. SImply put, this beer is beautiful. Complex and subtle yet thoroughly drinkable. Perfect for a long winters evening spent by the fire, pondering the mysteries of human existence. 2010-03-29
Bottle. Murky brown body with off-white head. Flavour is malt, sweet, caramel, dark fruit and spices.

Bottle.

Dark brown with a thick, small slightly tan head. 

Fantastic aroma and taste of sweet malt, nuts, chocolate, spices plums,, toffee, and dark fruits. There were also something that was difficult to describe, strawberries and some banana maybe? Wonderful mouth feel, smooth and fine. Very long aftertaste. Really great, as good as number 12 if not better.

Prominent smell of honey. Sweet brown creamy beer. My god it is so sweet depsites the 8% abv ! Maybe the sweetest trappist beer. Massive Honey, floral and caramel notes, candy sugar on the (long) finish. I love this beer

A classic trappist beer to celebratae my 28th. Poured from bottle into the goblet Westvleteren glass. Lovely foamed head. Very creamy on the texture. The beer is dark brown. redding out at the bottom. The beer is prominent of caramel; rich dark malts, dried fruits, brown sugar and a touch leathery. A lovely beer. Drinkability is good for the abv. The mouth feel is well balanced and the finish is moderate with notes of caramel and spices. This is aged a little. I havent rated it yet so thought it would be an appropriate beer to continue with after Pannepot. Some good beers to go through today and this is just the start. A classic beer.

Rating #1700.  The cap is hard to read but I believe it is 23.3.10.  Pours a murky orangish brown with a thin tan head.  The nose is plums, dates, a touch of tobacco, cola and nuts.  The taste is dark fruits, brown sugar, chocolate, spice, bready yeast and spiked raisins in the finish.  Medium mouthfeel with prickly carbonation on the tip of the tongue.  Good beer.  Not the mind blowing experience I was hoping for, but then again what beer actually could live up to the hype this one and the 12 gets.

Bottle @ In de Vrede, served too cold. Deep brown pour with a thick tanned head. Aroma of citrus, yeast and spices. Flavour is bittersweet fruit and yeast. Very good beer but no rave. Coldness brought it down a bit I think.
Pours dark brown.  Fantastically smooth malt, dark fruit and spice.  Delicious and remarkably easy to drink.

UPDATED: AUG 17, 2010 Careful my friends it foam like a volcano. Softer than the Westy 12 it smells nature flower honey and malt. Almost creamy, full of sweet sugar. I am an atheist but I almost want to believe in God after having tasted this wonder

Pours a reddish brown with a thick off white head.  Aroma is dark fruit and some spice.  Similar to the 12 but with a little less alcohol kick.  Some woody notes and a good malt kick.  A bit tart/funky, but really nice.  Excellent beer.

Bottle. Pours medium brown with smallish tan coloured rocky head. Minimal lacing as the head falls away. Aromas initially show plenty of bread, this changes however with caramel taking over as the beer warms. Some vanilla, a little alcohol and some darkish furit also. Amazing aromas.Flavours are not quite as complex as the nose, but bloody amazing all the same. Some malt sweetness, more caramel, some toasted nuttiness and just a little alcohol. Mouthfeel is very creamy and sets off this beer amazingly. Superb

Driving 800 kilometers I was able to get two cases of Westvleteren 8 and I am already 3 bottles down. I know I make people jealous when I say that I still have 45 to go. The beer was bottled on January 13, so it has aged for only a month. But its already very good. Its hard not to try a bottle every other day. Has a beautiful dark  brown color and fruity aroma. Next effort will be getting the 12.

Tasted alongside the St. Bernardus Prior 8.  Totally different-this one had much more floral and herbal aroma.  It had been open for about 4 hours.  It had some barnyard funk at times, but not in a bad way-just a good brett.  Extremely balanced with the great Belgian yeast essences and noticeable banana.  After several hours of being open, but still slightly chilled I swear tasted something that reminded me of salmon sushi with wasabi and soy.  I know...hard to believe, but that is what I kept coming back to trying to figure out the flavor.  Sounds disgusting, but wasnt in the least.  Feel lucky to have tried this and would get more in a second if it was possible...
dark bread, rød/brown,medium bitterness, lightly sour, salty, medium body, creamy, average carbonation, bitter, nice beer.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2010 Got, finally, 2 bottles of this beer. This one has only 1 month aged, the other one I will try when its at least 6 months. The aromas are very nice balanced, just as the taste. Very spicey and a bit fruity, some banana. Dark orange-red-brown color, very nice head that holds a nice time. Without a doubt a great beer.

UPDATED: JUL 20, 2011 330mL at In De Vrede and some  courtesy of Travlr. Pours a translucent amber with a thin head. Aroma is bready, yeasty, lots of boozy caramel, brown sugar, dark fruits. The smell from the cap though is completely heavenly and divine. Yum. Flavor is sweet, lots of candi sugar, plums, figs, brown sugar. Pretty good but I would like to try a few more to really see why this beer is so hyped and sought after. 2/6/2010 8/4/8/4/14=3.8330mL 2007 ed  courtesy of Travlr. The pour is similar to Westy 12- almost the same SRM of very dark muddy sepia looking almost black in the glass. A towering, poofy, cinnamon tan head erupts with fierce retention and massive ice cream scoop formation. Never goes away. Nose is spicy, less calvados in the nose compared to the 12, with similar rich milk chocolate, apple butter, and spicy yeast similar to Charlevoix Dominus Vobiscum Double. Taste is sharp, spicy, and mildly tannic with an excellent, full, silky mouthfeel. Sharper and less forgiving in the palate versus the 12 but also extremely delicious. Spiced apple pie comes to mind. Delicious. 7/17/2011 8/5/8/4/16=4.1

Sweet aroma; candy sugar, spices and dry fruit (cherry?). Deep amber-brown with nice off white head; a thin layer remains long after the pour, nice lacing.  Moderately sweet and moderately roasty.  The roasted flavors pursist as the tastes transitions from sweet to lightly earthy-hoppy.  A nice bit of green apple approaching the finish.  Overall very smooth palate.  A pleasant beer, well described as a toned down version of the 12.

Notes: Tasted 24 Jan 10, bottle purched at In de Vrede

Bottle poured into a St. Bernardus goblet.   Pours dark, murky brown with a ruby tinge when held up to the light.  Large creamy frothy tan head, that sticks around for a long time, and leaves sticky lacing on the glass.  Aroma is heavily malty, with caramel, perfumy hops, doughy yeast, dark sweet fruits (raisins, plums, dates, pears), toffee, and alcohol.  Taste is moderately to heavily sweet, and lightly acidic.  Mouthfeel is creamy and smooth, with soft carbonation, with a slight alcohol burn at the end.  Overall, a delicious brew!

Bottle conditioned, 330ml, aged 5yrs. Dark brown to ruby with slight cream head. Beautifully smooth and light, right from the off for such a big beer, some port like notes, quite fruity with a soft berry character, blackberry and sweet cherry. Never overwhelming, just very pleasant easy drinking. Straight into my all time favourite list.

Bought in Amsterdam before Reach Belgium, we never knows what is wait for us and Murphy always shows up! Very dark amber color with a very nice Beige head that keeps a nice lacing until finish. Aroma is complex. dark fruits like plum, blueberry, some sweetness, toffee, malty, quite alcohol and I dont know what else is on it. Flavor looks like the same, but I felt the alcohol on it. Mouthfeel is long and totally dark fruity. Really good, the price compared to Brazil was amazing, since I paid ¢12.- euro and in Brazil at least cost some ¢40.- Euro.

[Bottle] traded to me by Dakine. Thanks for this treat! This bottle has been sitting undisturbed in my fridge for the last month and still gushed. Pours a murky brown with a medium sized head that lasts nicely. Aroma is similar to the 12 but more vibrant and bright. It doesnt have the peppery alcohol notes, which is neither good nor bad. I still get the vinous grape smell that comes off as the purple fruit snacks, but its still very enjoyable. Flavor is markedly thinner in mouthfeel than the 12, little alcohol presence, sweet malts, still fairly vinous, but it just doesnt have the body to really make it stand out. The carbonation is soft and the finish is pretty quick. Overall this is a bit of a letdown, but I had really high expectations to begin with, so that doesnt mean its a bad beer by any stretch of the imagination.
stupenda.poi bevuta sul posto è sicuramente migliore.era lagosto del 2007 quando ho sentito per la prima volta questi profumi di malto tostato carammello e frutti apolpa rossa. che dire....salute!!

Bottle. A cloudy dark brown beer with a large, frothy, creamy, mostly lasting and lacing light brown head. Outstanding aroma, richly malty, with some yeast and a hint of hops. There are notes of caramel, fruits (banana, plums, raisin), nuts, sugar, chocolate, some vinous hints. Wonderfully balanced nose and also powerful. The flavour is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. The toasted notes are more evident in the mouth, and again a wonderfully balanced flavour. Medium to full body, lively carbonation, long finish with light to medium bitterness, lightly alcoholic. Simply amazing, maybe I preder Westvleteren 12, but it gives me enough pleasure, joy, enjoyment and delight to give it the perfect rating.

Sampled at the DC Local Tasting.  Pours a translucent, purple amber with a thin, white head.  Aroma is bread, yeast, grains, a little sugary.  Smelling it, you know why the monks brewed this to help them through the winter months.  It smells hearty.  Flavor is sweet, sugary, candy, plums, red grapes, light brown sugar.  Finish is dry.  I liked the Westy 12 much more, but this was still very nice.

This all time blue capped belgian top of the pops have I never rated - today is the day. I have been away from classic belgian trappists for a very long time, but today I felt the itch and brought this one together with a Rochefort 8 and  10 back with me from Ølbutikken in Copenhagen. Pouring this in a trad. Westvleteren glass just like on the pic on this side. Damn when opcapped it sprayed half of the contains out....with my mouth to it I can proudly say that I just have had a Westvleteren Deep throat... damn. Well the last half of this quite expensive beer found luckely the glass. The body has a chest nutty colour topped with a golden creamy head. The nose has the clear trappist caractaristicas. The dark malty flavours combined with a strong alcohol profile. Spices, vanilla, caramel and cinnamon. The taste is so smooth and round and totaly ballanced with many of the same stuff as dominated the aroma - but here you can really sense the Westy yeast that has that unique citric and feeling to it.. The palate is creamy and nice with a sweet finish with an edge of alcohol.

Dark brown, but with a subtle red-orange tint.  Aroma of typical dark fruits and carmelized sugars typical of trappist strong ales.  Taste to match.  Where this stands apart from some of the others is in the incredible mouth feel and mellow, yet complex taste.  Small, tightly nit bubbles, perfectly carbonated.  Most like Rochefort 8 (or 10?) of the others Ive had.  A bit buttery, but not from diacetyl.  Toffee and plums.  Delicious!

Sweet malty cherry aroma with a light amount of vanilla oak. Dark brown color with a small tan head. Sweet beginning mellowing in the finish. Light spots of bitterness but mostly completely smooth throughout. Moderately thick silky palate.

Am I drinking the beer or the hype? The hype is unavoidable. I shared this on Christmas Day with my Dad. Its a murky brown colour but scores 3/5 for appearance because the little blue cap brings a little anticipated joy and its good to see. It has a great aroma, thats for sure; tea bread, sweetly yeasty, apple juice, dried fruit. Brown bread, caramel, fruit on the palate. Its a good beer. I need to try it fresh at the cafe, then Ill re-rate.

Ringing in the New Year with my favorite beer. Have had several times, but yet to rate. Beautiful deep dark brown body, thin tan head. Decadent aroma of yeast, baking bread, and lovely dark fruits. The flavor is supremely balanced and yet satisfyingly complex.  Lots of bread/biscuit flavors, but underneath a complexity of dark fruits, black cherries, sweet malts, with the slightest hint of bitterness on the finish. Very well hidden alcohol, and VERY drinkable.  It may not be the most radical, exciting, or complex beer in the world, but the sheer beauty of the flavors and the balance make it my favorite. Cant imagine loving any beer more. And for that reason, I give it a 5.

(New Years Eve tasting Flight (2 of 3 9:50p)) Westvleteren Extra 8 - As soon as I started to try and uncap this there was a slight hiss and foam started to slowly come out. Once uncapped fully was able to pour almost the entire bottle into glass, which I couldnt with the Westy Blonde. Darker tan head. Pretty rocky looking. Bready aroma. Sort of like Roman Meal bread if you know what that is. Sort of sweet wheat bread. Dark brown body. Wonderfully sweet flavors of raisins and brown sugar. Hops are just enough flavor to balance the sweetness. Body somethick thick, but not fully bodied. Mouth warming after drinking. Sweetness fades in aftertaste leaving hops to linger for a short amount of time.

An aroma of fruit, applecakes, applepies with some earthyness. Very deep and rich.
Big foamy uneven head and a beautiful sizzling sound. Ruby red appearance,
Taste is heavy with some sourness and bitterness. Not a very long finish.

I often wonder how beers like Westy 8 would do in a blind tasting.  Im not saying that everyones opinion is wrong (that would be stupid obviously).  But....I dunno.  I just had this about 6 hrs ago, looking at my notes and it was just an okay beer.  Sacrilege?  Yeah, perhaps.  But here it goes.

The beer pours out a cola colored dark brown with a off-white/light tan head.  Aroma is roasted malts, some light bubblegum kinda of fruityness, a bit of wet paper too.  Flavor had some dark fruits, a bit of earth, more wet paper, some alcohol...I dunno.  Nothing extraordinary at all.  Good?  Yeah, I suppose.  But nothing I cant go out and find much cheaper and better.

2 yr old bottle leftover from my bday case...thanks boys!!   pours a deep brown with a medium lt. tan head taht dissipates quickly but returns with agitation...nice lacing...some sediment throughout.  aroma is subtly sweet with hints of raisin, candy sugar...maybe some fig.  also has a touch of crisp, earthy and spicy hops.  flavor is more hoppy than the aroma suggests...balanced nicely and not too sweet at all.  definite candy sugar and raisin with crisp hops...slightly leathery...that dry out the finish nicely.  mouthfeel is medium and lively...finish lingers nicely.  very nice beer!

UPDATED: DEC 24, 2009 Bottle. Wow, a surprise from a friend. 3 way blind taste test alongside pannepot grand reserva 2006 and pannepot reserva 2006. Wild yeast aromas, quite barn like with lots of hay. Nice orval like taste, very wild and funky tons of fruit as well, cherries mainly. Some spice. Slightly sub par palate, kind of fizzy, but this beer was very young.

Bottle, thanks to a very generous friend.  12 is up next.  Very dark murky brown body with a descent lasting off-white head.  creamy.  The aroma is almost too hard for me to explain, cant really put my finger on it.  Sweet with dark fruity notes (plum, red grapes, raisins) and some candy sugar to back.  I have to admit that this style just isnt my thing really, but the flavor is pretty unbelievable.  Very fruity and sweet (but not thick and syrupy sweet like many lesser belgian beers).  No hint of alcohol.  Dangerously drinkable.  Medium body with fervent carbonation.  Overall: a great beer... coming from a belgian beer (excepting lambics) hater.

Pours a murky cloudy opaque medium dark brown with little head suffice the center and around the rims. The aroma is highly Cherry, plum, fig and other dark fruits along with maybe even a slight hint of chocolate and some bread. the flavor is also cherry, fig and dark fruits with a yeast/ bread presence. Not overly sweet extremely well balanced. The fruits come through even more as the beer warms. I may actually enjoy this over the 12 I will have to try it again.

Pours a beautiful amber to ruby red with a small foamy white head. Slightly faint but complex aroma of malt, fruits, some alcohol, and also a bit dusty. Somehow I expected more, given the ratings. But then after my first sip, the flavor hit me straight in the face. It has a lovely creamy texture that allows this beer to gently enter my mouth, after which a subtle bitter dryness kicks that tantalizingly manages to assault my senses. The best part comes actually after swallowing the goods. A lingering dry bitter finish that makes me wonder what just happened. The flavor is not very strong, just like the aroma, but really well balanced and very nice. But although I really like this beer, it still lacks something.. undefinable. Over here it is also way overpriced. But I can not really complain about that, as I could have visited Westvleteren myself.

This Belgian strong ale pours dark red/brown and is highly carbonated. You can tell that this brew re-ferments in the bottle because there is a lot of sediment floating in it, very interesting. Smell is full flavored of dark fruits, honey, and all kinds of malts. The taste is pretty much exactly as it smells and it doesnt skip on the smoothness. The Westvleteren 8 is by far the smoothest Ale ive ever had. Also it hides the taste of alcohol very well, and this is no weakling coming in at 8% either. Overall it has a very bold and strong flavor with a bitter sweet frothy aftertaste. Very good.
Bottle thanks Brett.  Pours cloudy brown with tan lasting head.  Bananna clove spice malt aroma Complex balance of flavors with spice, fruit, yeast.  Nice!

330 ml bottle shared with tasting group (approx. 10 year old bottle): Pours a slightly hazy deep amber color with some floaties and a beautiful large fluffy beige head.  The aroma on this is something to savor.  Big candy like sweetness, caramel, brown sugar, port, slightly oxidized but not in a bad way, and dark fruit.  I had to pause and take all of this in for a moment.  The flavor is first class as well.  There was some consensus with my tasting group that this was even better than the Westy 12 we had tasted earlier.  It has a very sugary caramel maltiness , vinous and port-like, multiple fruits: plum, dates, black cherry, all well integrated with each other.  The alcohol is non existent which makes this dangerous if I had more around.  Mouthfeel is medium full and silky smooth.  This was a real treat picked up in an early trade with alldaydrinker.

This poor little guy is often overshadowed by its big brother, but this beer is enough to carry its own torch.  Pours a dark brown with a thin lingering head.  Aroma of caramel, sweet malt, and a bit of alcohol.  Whereas the 12 stands with its aroma as its strong suit I feel this stands on its flavor.  Theres a delicate balance of roasted malt, brown sugar, sweetness, and caramel in this.  Very smooth, very drinkable, i dream of the day i can sit down and drink a few of these.  I hope that i get the opportunity.
bottle, muddy cola colored pour with a 1/2" of tan foam, aroma of cocoa, alcohol, fig, malty, flavors of cola, chocolate, bourbon, lighter finish

bottle thanks to bhensonb.  poured a murky brownish amber with an off white head.  aroma was grain, caramel, fruity, raisin, and plum.  flavor was complex with grain, caramel, fruity, raisin, plum, cinnamon, and alcohol.  body was medium with high carbonation.
Dark brown beer with a long lasting head. Taste is that of a regular dark beer, but wih a hint of a fruity freshness, remembering of melons. Awesomeness in a bottle.

Bottle from BelgianBeerGal - thanks Amy! Drank this one side-by-side with the 12, and let it warm up a bit before drinking. Pours like dark apple cider with a light tan head that had the tiniest, most dainty bubbles Ive ever seen on a beer. Smells sweet and bready, with some nice honey notes. Definitely not sugary sweet. Taste is the same sweetness with some nice breadiness, toffee, light spice up front, and a bit of vanilla. Finish is lightly hopped--just enough to balance out some of the sweetness. The mouthfeel was just ridiculous--smooth and chewy in the mouth, and the perfect amount of warmth as it goes down the throat. Rated this one identical to the 12. They were different beers certainly, but of the same quality. I wish I had a more refined palate that could pick out some of the flavors that lingered in this beer. Theres just a lot going on, and Id love to try it again!
Bottle. Yeast, floral and bread. Some sweet fruit flavors, but not overly sweet. Wonderful.

Dark brown with a medium sized off-white/pale brown head that dissipates slowly and leaves plenty of lacings.

The smell is of light fruity aromas and plenty of malts - very thick and robust. Notes of fudge and toffee mixed with earthy herbal aromas. Some spicy phenols and alcohol. Rather complex and well balanced, but its not as impressive or as powerful as I had expected.

In the taste, there is a similar balance between fruity aromas and malts as in the smell: cherries, slightly tart red currants rests upon a decent malty backbone. Fudge and caramel delivers much of the sweetness. Dark bread, a gentle note of wood and just a hint of blanket (which I find a bit odd). The finish is slightly phenolic and somewhat bitter with notes of sweet alcohol, herbs and minerals.

Full bodied, smooth texture. The finish is somewhat dry. A very pleasant mouthfeel.

A good beer, very good actually. Complex, well balanced and tasty. But one of the best beers in the world? Perhaps not, in my humble opinion.

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)

Aged bottle- not sure how long. I have had it for about 3-4 years- with D&V label.  Could be older.  Pours a nice woody amber brown with a nice softish head and some lace.  Aroma is toast, toffee, sweet malts, very low oxidation- some sherry, earthy phenolics and nice light fruity esters.  Good full malt flavors with a high carbonation, but is so soft, it makes the beer so smooth- phenolic, spicy, earth, dark malts, dark candi sugar, toast, molasses, nutty and slight burnt notes with good dark dried fruits.  Smooth and easy drinking.  Awesome.
Big thanks to eicandersnavy.  Brown pour with sediment.  Faint smell of grains, fruits, and a little yeast.  Tastes is dominated by dark fruits.

Bottle pours very dark brown with almost no light passing through.  A thick tan head forms on top and slowly fades.  It never really goes anywhere.  Its lasts as I drink it and laces beautifully.  Aroma is a wonderful mixture of dark fruit.  Plum, raisin, fig, some candi sugar and belgian yeast round out this gem.  Prickly mouthfeel from the high carbonation.  Flavors follow the nose and finish semi-dry.  Alcohol is hidden well.  This is a wonderful beer.

Pours a light brown with a off-white head into my Chimay goblet. Taste is sweet, but not overly so, which I prefer. Dark fruit (plums, cranberries, raisins, etc.) really sticks out on my palate along with some alcohol bitterness on the finish. Mouthfeel is good, light-medium in body, coats the mouth well. I prefer this Dubbel to the Quad and will drink again, for sure.

Aged bottle shared by Dickinsonbeer.  Dark brown with ring and lace.  Woody caramel sweet cherries and brown sugar aroma.  Mild roasted caramel brown sugar yeasty and sweet dark fruit with medium tobacco bitterness.  Soft fine palate.   Very complex.  Very good.  Will rerate when I get a fresh one.

Bottle with big thanks to ericandersnavy. Dark brown pour with loads of sediment in the pour. Very nice aroma of sweet plum and dark fruits. Some yeast but also well balanced. Darkly flavored. Heavy dark fruit with plum, raisin and grapefruit. Also has bitter flavors with a bit of Belgian taste. Solid with no doubt.
Very good looking brown beer with beautifull beige mousse. Aroma is caramel, spices and malts with honey. taste is very nice sweet and hoppy.

Pours a dark red brown color with a nice thick tan head.  Aroma of roasted malts, dry fruits and caramels.  Flavors of dry fruits, raisans and plums, liquorice, spices, a hint of cinnamon.  A great ballance flavors and a sweet bitter dry finish.  Good carbontion and a bit crispy.  Very complex with an evolution of taste as you drink.

A great looking warm brown beer with a fluffy creamy head on top. Nose is smooth and bready with a fantastic malty and honeyed character. The taste is round, cake like and has a fine hoppy bitterness about it. Aftertaste is so right, all components are right where they should be.A very nice classic.

Beer from Bottle. Aged +/- 2 years.
The beer pours a murky brown. I had expected a better look. Smell of hops, and a hint of tobacco (as with the blond, though less), burnt grain, raisins. Gives a reasonably good frothy off-white head that does not last however. The beer was a bit too cold when I took the first sips. Result: bitterness protruding that reminded me of the Orval. The taste gets better when the beer warms up. 
Nevertheless I found this one quite thin and watery as far as texture goes. Expected it to be much better. As for the taste nuances, theyre there but all somehow toned down and the beer is therefore lacking in complexity. In my opinion the Westvleteren 8 is definitely vastly overrated because of the hype and the scarce availability. This one should not be ranking this high and I personally would even choose the Westvleteren Blond over this one.

Nice consistent murky dark brown pour with a thick, dense offwhite head. Served at about 50F. malt, burnt sugar, spice, bready, a little bit of metallic and fruit notes. Extraordinary balance with well-integrated flavors. Finish goes on and on.

As it opens up: cherry, a bit of cinnamon/raisin bread. Just delicious.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2010 Bottle.  Dark amber with a nice creamy head.  Belgium yeast, banana, citrus, oat, bread, nuts, spice and more as it opened up.  Very smooth despite the full body, and a nice long finish. A very nice beer.

Bottle from trade.  Poured a really nice dark brown with a large off-white head.  Aroma of dark fruit - rasins & cherries, belgian spice, yeast.  Taste is really nice balance of dark fruit, spice, yeast, bready malt.  Really nice.  Body is well balanced and fairyl well carbonated.  Overall, a very enjoyable brew.

Very dark reddish brown pour. Small floaties everywhere. A thin, but persistent off-white head. Aroma of raisins, burnt sugar, wood. There is a definite alcohol presence in the flavor, but it isnt too offensive. Burnt malt, grapes, red wine, tobacco. Seems to be more bitter than other examples of the style. The mouthfeel is slightly prickly, which pairs nicely with the otherwise heavy nature of the beer. Also has a nice warming effect on this rainy Bruges evening. Very good beer.

bottle, dark brown colour with huge beige head. Very fruity smell. Taste: Chestnuts and woody, dark fruit, bitter, malty, grainy, sweet, dry, spicy, roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, caramel, coconuts, alcohol. I think my bottle was a bit too warm. (roomtemperature), but still a very good ale!

Aroma is must and dark fruit. Nose has all of this, but also fresh tobacco, basalmic and wine notes. Pours a brown with tan head. Flavor is sweet, but changes to dry right away. And finishes on a beautiful dry note. Would I rate this beer the greatest? Probably not. Is it the best Belgian style Beer? Probably not. Is it worth $30 a pop? No. But is it a good beer? Yes, very much so.

Terrific story of monks making beer out of necessity....
This beer is beer at its best in traditional sense without high-tec filtration techniques.  If I imagine monks making beer in Belgium back in the day, it is Westvleteren.  The beer is so complex with malts, spices, candies, and hops that it is sensory overload.  All of this great flavor is mixed with imperfections, such as floaties, clill haze, and Opaqueness.  This is beer people!!!  This is a great blend and I think the imperfections are a plus.

My birthday beer, courtesy of Garrett!  Poured into a Lost Abbey snifter, color is dark brown with a creamy, dense head.  Aroma of rich, lush dark fruit, especially dates and raisins.  Slight papery aroma noticeable, but not a detriment IMO.  Bready, malty, peaty.  Flavor is rich, warming, starting with milk chocolate, a hint of coffee, and dark fruit.  For some reason, I kept thinking, chocolate-covered strawberries.  Mid-palate is bready, but it is a sweet, creamy bread.  A little bit of oxidation present.  Finish is very dry, with chocolate, raisins and lingering sweetness.  A winning beer, and I am honored to have tried it!

Yes, I finally drank one of these too! On my trip to Europe, when we went to Belgium. Yes it too, like the 12, is as great as everyone says (actually better). I rank this #2 on my all time list of beers. Andechs Doppelbock #1.

Brought from Beer Temple in Brugge and brought back on plane to Australia. Tasted alongside 2 dubbels. Quite a dark cooking chocolate colour with tan head. Moderate Roasted Burnt malt aroma with Plenty of dried fruits, Plums, Prunes Date. Smells like a fruit cake. Can also pick up some smoke and cask wood/oakiness. The aroma changes and 10minutes in smells like fresh raisins and cough medicine. Very sweet with a syrupy like finish. A good beer, but far from what i was expecting.

[bottle--thanks, fonefan!]
Tangy herbal and spice aroma with plenty of dried fruit, banana, clove, brown sugar and faint walnuts. Slightly vinous as well in the nose--almost balsamic. Cloudy, dark reddish brown under an eternal, beige blanket. Sweet, complex flavour that includes figs and dates, raisins and tobacco, almonds and walnuts, coffee and bitter chocolate. The bitterness level is good an almost offsets the sweet flavour. Slightly sugary. Medium body, moderate carbonation, molasses plus slight bitter finish.

Bottle courtesy of a tade with BelgianBeerGal and cracked in honor of my 2 year mark on RateBeer. Cheers! Pours a dark thick brown, opaque in parts and a bit brighter, red, and with some decent light, a nice bigger light brown head that dies to a sufficient level, laces fairly well. Aromas are a deep fruitiness, apples and bananas dance with cherries, brown sugar, bread, caramel, toffee, a touch of spice, vanilla. The fruitiness is prominent, a bit deeper and darker overall, without too much sugar and spiciness, almost a winey aroma in some ways. Initial is a nice full mouthfeel, fruity banana, apple, pear, cherries and pit fruit (light plum and very light raisin), light caramel, brown sugar, vanilla, a bit of Belgian yeast spice on the tounge. A touch boozy, but pleasant enough. A fruity must almost, a decent bitterness on the backend with mellow fruity and malty flavors lingering. A pretty good beer, surprising at 8 ABV, and fairly light on the palate for what it is. Quite quaffable.

Bottle in de Vrede. Dark brown hazy body with lasting head. Aroma has some sweet and sour maltiness, breadlike. Fragile hoppiness. Flavor has some hoppy bitterness, but strong malt with some sour tastes. Leaves lasting aftertaste. Strong mouthfeel, cant say it better, bitter and overwhelming.

A nose of yeast, red wine, plums and a certain flouery character that reminds me of the yeasty smell of bread-dough. Taste is of red wine, vinegar, coffee, chocolate, liquorish and cassis. Finish is acidic, dry and with a little bit of bitterness and alcohol in the end.

I really thought this beer were overrated, due to Westvleterens legendary standing in the beer-community. However, it turns out it really is a elegant, complex and unique brew. Im glad I tried it. Believe the hype!

Aroma of dark over ripe fruit, grapes - rather vinous, fruit cake, light yeasty spice, figs, raisins, brown sugar, caramel. Pours brownish red with a great fizzy head and a cascading flush of carbonation suspending all the floaties throughout the drink. Looked wonderful actually. Lots of dark fruit - raisins, plums, figs, grape notes - vinous and a little winey, caramel and brown sugar, banana bread perhaps, light yeasty spice. Drinks wonderfully. Smooth with lively carbonation. I wish I was a monk and could live off beer like this and not eat....

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2010 Aroma of fermented fruit, yeast, prunes and red wine. Appearance is dark brown with big white/brown head. Flavor is sweet, unagressive and in many ways complete hints of coffee, chocolate, liquorish with a slightly bitter aftertaste. Overall one of the best beers Ive tasted, amazing!

Slight gush of opaque tannish-mahogany with a lightly-beige head. Nose is incredibly malty with tea, dates, brown sugar, nutty banana bread. Lots of depth, not quite 12-level. Heavy yeast and malt in the flavor, light pepper, date, raisin, and nut as a combination. Never too sweet, the palate is full and smooth, light carbonation giving the body some pomp while lasting on and on and on. It doesnt have the depth or sweet fruit of the 12, but its damn good. Comparing this to Rochefort 8 is a crime. Westvleteren is far and away king of abbey beers, case closed.

bottle thanks to jlindros from BA.  Pours a dark brown with a fabulous, off-white head.  Nice lacing.  Beautiful brew.  Nose is of vinous fruit and brown sugar.  Similar to Westy 12.  Taste is very nice fruit and brown sugar with some spice.  Mouthfeel is medium-thin and dry.  Very good brew.

From a bottle at the Belgian Beer Weekend in Brussels.  Lots of people were trying to get this so I had to go for it for an 11:00 am breakfast beer before it sold out. Malty and citrus aromas with a slight tartness. Dark reddish brown with a rich creamy head.  Flavors are tart dried fruits, bounces around in the mouth with flavor changes.  Dryish on the finish and bitter but with a light balancing sweetness.  Long duration wraps around the tongue.  I assume this was a fairly green bottle and will improve a lot with age.  Still, it was quite good and a great atmosphere to try it in the Grand Place in Brussels.

33 cl bottle at Den Tatoverede Enke, Copenhagen. Dark copper color, nice off-white head. Aroma is dried fruit, some spice, hints of alcohol and belgian yeast. Flavor is dried fruit, sweetness, spices, hints of alcohol, fine bitterness. Not as good as 12, but lovely in the mouth.

Bottle, many thanks to duff. 

Sweet fat and malty to the nose much like a non-alcoholic beer except for a slightly pungent spicy alcohol note underneath.  Huge puffy mouthfeel.  Tongue tingling and awfully exciting.  Clean yet stuffy, with hints of menthol and thick caramel.  Fruity and still with a massive depth.  Now my glass is empty so Ill leave it there until i get another one.

330 ml bottle - 2005 vintage; thanks after4ever!! light brown, slightly murky with quickly fading off-white head; very mild gusher; aromas of candy malt, prunes, dank fruit and sugar; like the Westy 12, you can basically smell the rich texture; not as strong or sweet as the Westy 12, and at first sip comes of as the Jr. version; apples, fizzy, a little spice and some dark, fruity sourness; intoxicating candy, caramel, fruit and yeasty nose; as expected it becomes much better as it warms; love the nose and texture, but flavor kind of a letdown again

12oz bottle thanks to Daknole for sharing these white whale beers with me. Pours a deep brown with a beige head thats very fluffy and full. Super yeasty aroma that reminds me of Bernardus. Big caramel covered raisin notes and brown sugar. Very well balanced and a touch dry with none of the cloying sweetness other belgians have. No hops but its oddly restrained in its sweetness. No alcohol felt and perfect carbonation. Really well made but it didnt wow me.

UPDATED: APR 22, 2015 (bottle) hazy deep ruby-brown colour with a frothy light-beige head. aroma of vanilla, coconut and speyside whisky, with big notes of chocolate icing, some hazelnuts and alcohol. flavour is mostly roasted malts, vanilla and bran flakes, slightly fruity, with a hint of pancake batter, cardboard, herbal hops and some more light alcohol in the semi-dry finish. medium-bodied with lively carbonation.

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2013 330mL Bottle. Exp Date 17.06.12. Flickr(http:[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Thanks so much Fran and Sylvia! Ive been waiting a long time to try this gem. Pours a vibrant cherry and ruby red, sienna-tinted and cloudy, with an uneven, rocky straw colored head. Beautiful. The aroma immediately gives away pilsener malt as a base, followed by a perfumy blend of plums, figs, and raisins. A very nice dark fruit complex. A touch sweet and sherry-like with a nice yeast contribution. Flavor develops quickly, with spiced bread pudding and fruitcake characters. The mineral-forward pils malt shows quickly and then slides off into a dappling of black cherry juice, allspice, and cooked plum flesh. Delicious. A very dry and carbonated presentation. Bottle-conditioning at its finest. I think whats most exciting and appealing about this beer is the raging fresh pilsener malt character that just oozes out of ever pore of this beer. The deeper fruit characters and the gentle yeast tones are fantastic, but the pils malt base really sets a stage for excellence. Wonderful. I much prefer this to the 12.
One of my favourites strong ales. Complicated, well balanced at all. No other comments needed. Is almost perfect, almost...
plum raisins and caramel, but without being too sweet, and showing up lots of spice as well.  splendid.

A bottle 0.33L tasted at Kaisla. Reddish brown colour. Pale beige head. Mild slightly spicey nose (too cold). Soft spicey taste with some hints of dark fruits. Some bread and some hints of raisins in the nose. Average hoppiness. Warming alcohol. Hmm...

Bottled June 3, 2009 - pretty fresh considering it had to travel all the way to Missouri!  Tasted alongside the Blonde and the 12, this was our final Westy of the day.

This 8 is everything that its big brother is and more, with some of the cloying sugary sweetness stripped out.  Murky reddish-brown with a nice head that the 12 didnt have (freshness might have come into play here).  Otherwise, aroma and flavors similar to the 12.  GREAT beer here, would love to get my hands on a few more!

Drank it next to the 12, which I shouldnt have done. To be frank: tastes like mineral water compared to the 12. However, it improved after a while. This is like a light version of the 12. Less alcohol, not as full-bodied, more bitterness and spiceyness.

11.5 oz bottle, courtesy of bret27.  Medium dark brown with off white head.  Wonderful nose of milk chocolate and fruits.  Very smooth with good mouthfeel.  Split between 6 of us, so I am eager to get one to myself.

Tasted this one next to the 12.  They are similar in appearance, but the 8 is just a little "thinner".  Ive read that the 8 is brewed from the second runnings of the 12, thatd make sense.  Cocoa and caramel, with a little more hop presence.

Bottle. 2008 I believe, maybe older, thanks RLB, he gave me this one since my first bottle was opened at madness 1.  Aroma of plum and raisins. Poured a murky brown.  Flavor of raisin and plum, brown sugar, chocolate.  Palate was full and lively, very clean.  Overall, a pleasure to enjoy with the wife.

Im going to attempt to not fawn over this beer in the review but let me just say wow. This is amazing stuff. 

Appearance is the weak point, and even here I am nitpicking. Pours a murky brown with creamy brown head. 

Smell.. Wait, did I open a lambic by mistake? Sweet and fruity, incredibly appetizing. 

Taste-I am blown away. In no way are these overrated. Hard to detect alcohol at all. 

Mouthfeel- just right amount of carbonation and a medium body.
This bottle was quite a few years old.  probably 8 years old or so.  Slight port aftertaste.  very smooth

UPDATED: JUN 7, 2011 330ml bottle at home. 1-2 years old.
Appearance : Deep brown with a HUGE foamy off-white head. Rocky fluffy head. Lots of lacing.

Aroma : Awesome spices with yeast. Great red fruits with light chocolate. Light herbal hops.

Taste : Great brown sugar with yeast and spices. Finish has nice red fruits with herbal hops. Light hints of chocolate. Light bitterness on the finish with a tiny alcohol bite. Carbonation is awesome. Really fluffy but smooth. Persistent spices and hops on the finish.

Overall : Wow this is very good. Ive been slightly disappointed by the last belgians strong Ive had and I was wondering if my palate had evolved away from the style but this one tells me otherwise. Nose is awesome. Amazing yeast with nice hops and light chocolate. Taste is equally good with a nice bitterness on the finish. Overall this is rather dry but with lot of body. Perfect carbonation. Highly drinkable for the style. Much better than Rochefort 10 if memory serves. Mind blowing. The end of this bottle makes me very sad...

Bottle at In de Vrede. Pours deep brown with a medium creamy brownish head. Still some awesome lacing (as with all the Westys) Aroma of red fruits, hops, plums, raisins, chocolate. Taste is spicy and fruity. Small bitterness, some hints of nuts, chocolate and raisins. Slight alcohol feeling but not much really. Head stays until the end. Quite drinkable, very well balanced. 090816 9,5,9,3,19; 4.5

Bottle.  Color is a very dark brown .  Carbonation is good with a big tan head.  Aroma is a spicy yeast scent with some mild malt notes.  Taste is sweet and a little spicy.  Starting with a medium body it goes down with a fizzy feel.  Finish is big with Belgian yeast, some dried fruits and a nice spicy feel.  After taste lets the fruity Belgian flavors come out with just a hint of bitterness from the spice.  This is just an amazing brew.

11.5 oz bottle 8/9/09 (Courtesy of ygtbsm94)-Pours a  very dark brown with a huge tan head. Aroma of fruit, toffee, caramel, and spices. Taste of fruit, toffee, raisins, and sweetness. This full bodied brew kicks ass in a major way. So smooth and drinkable. Great beer.

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2009 Turns out, this is a pretty damn good beer.  Not sure where to begin.  The nose on this one is a thing of beauty.  Ripe fruits, butterscotch, toffee, some other dark fruits, spices l- a bunch of stuff that fits perfectly together, who the hell knows. i want this recipe! Flavor is Musty  plum, and toffee.  FOr me, this beer just works.  The whole is greater than the some of its many parts.  This beer just makes me love beer.
As if you step into a old dark french cellar. Large and richt palette, musky, oats, fruityness, richtness, fattyness. Doesnt tire you out. Worth whatever your effort.

Bottle. I tasted this one several times and finally got around to rating it. The beer poured a deep red-brown with thick beige head. Nice notes of raisins, plums, caramel, hints of sour cherries, bitter finish.
nice bear bud i think i like te 12 more then this one good flavor bud not i good as the number 12

Bottle @ In de Vrede, Westvleteren. Pours a slightly hazy brown color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty slightly yeasty dark fruit aroma. Sweetish malty dark fruit, raisins, plums, figs flavor with some hints of caramel and some yeasty hints. Has a sweetish malty dark fruit finish with a slightly bitter hints in the aftertaste.

Bottle. Had in the cellar for awhile and even traded a few away.  Pour was dark, but not to brown.  Way to much head, took me 4-5 min to pour into glass. Palate was great, tons of fruit and not overpowering at all.  I liked the 12 aged a little more, but this is a very close second.

Bottle. Pours very muddy brown with a medium-thick pale tan head with lovely lacing. Nose is yeast, sour cherries, brett, chocolate, fruit, tomato ketchup. Palate runs from initially quite sweet to a very dry finish, more fruit and sourness. Very earthy and mushroomy, seemed infected or off-balance. Shame, I had really high hopes for this after the letdown that the 12 was.

Well, I have to say... Most disappointing brewery ever! The 12 was one of the weak links in a blind tasting I participated in recently. Now this. Infected bottle. Gusher. Pours a cloudy brown tons of yeast with a large head. Aroma is filled with brettanomyces. Sour cherries, oranges, musty basement and horse blanket. On the palate its not very complex, watery and sour. Nice mouth feel, saving this beer from being a disaster.

Bottle. Poured a murky brown. Nose was fig, plum, cherry, cardboard, sherry, sweet malt, some tart fruit. Flavor was a great medley of plum, raisin, fig, sweet caramel, toffee, candy sugar, tart cherry, oxidation, and musky basement. What a gem!

Bottle, 33cl, thanks to my brother-in-law for having a storage of 48 Westvleterens in his appartment :). A red to light brown coloured beer with a beige head, not lacing very well however. An aroma of malts, dark fruits, also light caramel and dried prunes. The taste goes very similar: it starts with light sugar candy, light caramel adn evolves over dried prunes and dark fruits to a malty taste. Also very well balanced beer, one taste flowing over in the other, that all with a full mouthfeel. It finishes dry with some light alcohol. Fantastic trappist beer, but not with the tints and shades of the Westvleten 12, wihch has an even bigger, more beautiful and more fantastic taste. But this Westlveteren 8 is also very worth drinking!
Had this bottled at Gollem in Amsterdam at 10 euros. Beer was great. More smooth than I had expected. Complex and harmonic taste. Top belgian beer.

From the Bottle at Toms Ultimate Glasgow Tasting, Blackfriars 01/12/2007
Fruit and malt aromas. Amber red coloured and fruity with some spiced flavour and dryness in a crisp finish.

Tried this at Gollem bar in Amsterdam as the 12 was all sold out. Complex flavor showing yeast, malt, caramel and more. I enjoyed it but not as much as the 12. Dont get me wrong its still an amazing beer.

Pours a deep brick red with a creamy, thin, tan head.  Aroma is very fruity.  Grapes, light berries, spicy yeast, sugary malts.  Im surprised at how refreshing this beer feels.  Nice fruity, yeast, spicy flavor.  Some grapes, caramel malt, candied malts, some raisin, and a faint alcohol burn at the end.  For an 8% Belgian Strong ale I was expecting a more full, powerful brew, but I honestly think this is better how it is.  A little thinner than expected and one of the more refreshing strong ales Ive had.  Good stuff.
bottle from a buddy, nice brownish color, with some beige head. nose is sweet like grape bubble gum, some caremel. flavor is sweet but balanced, with a bit of a dry finish. really intresting beer

Bottle, big thanks to TampaBrew for sharing.  Poured a dark copper color with a thick fizzy white head, very nice lacing on left on the glass.  Distinct aroma of malt, spicy Belgian yeast, and dark fruit, rasins or figs.  Full bodied with solid carbonation.  Taste is quite complex, starts with some sweet caramel notes and Belgian yeast spice, later some of those fig and rasin notes become apparent as does some mild alcohol notes.  Finishes mildly bitter.

18.01.11  Almost surreal.  Senses heightened.  Attention focused.  Rich cola nut aroma, reminds me of many other Belgian strong ales Ive had and while good, not shattering to my perceptions of beer.  Maybe its like standing next to the Pope at a urinal and realizing that hes still just a dude.  In the end this is still beer.  Dark murky brown, arrogant tan head receded on its own time while I wrote all of this and now some grape jelly comes out.  Light pencil shavings also.  I get too much alcohol here, some plum, more cola, and little of anything Id call divine.  I never want to be seen as that guy who revels in ripping on whatevers popular, but I just dont get this.  I have another bottle older than this one and Ill look deep into it when I crack it down the road.

Rating 400. Giant thanks to MrChopin for this one. Pours a deep, dark brown, with some ruby accents showing through, and an incredibly dense, light tan head. Were talking cappuccino froth. Dark fruits, caramel apples (like honeycrisp apples dipped in real caramel), milk chocolate and spices on the nose. I dont know how they make these brews so creamy while retaining so much carbonation. The palate may be one of the best parts - so silky smooth. Flavors line up with the nose, adding perhaps some grape must. The profile is akin to the 12 but without quite the knockout punch. My favorite part? The flavor lingers forever. Very full mouthfeel, quenching in the mouth, but finishes clean. The head lingers forever. This is superb.

This is an excellent beer.  Dark brown with a thin tan head.  Head dissapates quickly.  Lots of yeast on the second pour.  It has an amazing flavor.  Dark dried fruit, caramel, malty with a hint of earth.  The flavors are all subtle and well balanced.  Medium body, good carbonation, no trace of alcohol and it is very drinkable.  I was most impressed with the drinkability of this beer.  Most beers of this strength and flavor can be heavy, alcoholic or both.  Fantastic beer that was unable to live up to the hype or price tag.

AS good as it can get. I was a bit biased against this beer, due to the hype. Everybody has written how it looks. The taste is very complex and changing in the mouth. I could miss the sting of the alcohol from the nose and aroma.

Pours dark mahogny with a creamy creme white head. 

Chocolate, apples and date plum.

Chocolaty and fruity with a brittish bitter hop finish. 

Gets more buttery and sweet as the temperature increses. (drink while cooler)

It poured a dark liquid with some tones of red and brown and a small foam that left a little lacing. There was also some yeast in the liquid.

The aroma was strong with chocolate, red berries, coffey and spices. Complex and very nice.

The first sip was very fizzy. So fizzy in fact that I didnt sense any flavor at all. After waiting a bit and let the fizzyness reside a bit I started to get a better grasp of the beer and it improved allot. It had a spicey flavor with some chocolate, red berries, nuts, orange peels and dried fruit. It also had a bite to it that I actually enjoyed, normally that would have been a bad thing but in this beer it really worked.

Bottle. Ap: Nice mahogny color with a long lasting off white head. Ar: Date, chocolate, appe (fruity + sour alcohol thing, maybe cognac?) Fla: Vinous. Some kind of british hop bitterness. Lots of fruit and chocolate. Complex but yet easy to drink. Ov: As good as Westvleteren 12.

I was actually really disappointed here, I was hoping for a more drinkable version of the 12, and the aroma matched well with the nutty sweetness, however the flavor had a lot of breadiness to it, which isnt bad, but just doesnt match the same caramely sweet raisin notes that I get from the 12.

Sampled at the café across the abbey, served assumably at the "correct" temperature. Great taste and aroma, maybe a little too chilled to really bring out the right smells. Tastes great, smooth and good mouthfeel.
Dark nut brown with white head. Very filling and complex. Dark fruits- a bit sweetness. The finish is long lasting and pleasant. Compared to the 12, this needs the "last punch". Almost as good

First thing that popped into my mind when I smelled this: Bubble Yum...grape flavour. Had tasting notes of grape gum also. Hints of candied fruit, apples peel and raisins, Christmas cake, spiced figs, and...more grape. The mouthfeel was so balanced and quite smooth. I could not detect any alcohol on my tongue but could feel its fuzzy presence in my head once I had finished this. A truly complex brew that begged for me to drink it again so I could continue to dissect it and take it apart in my head. Lots of things happening here. Did I mention the finish? Too much to really get into but lets just say that the finish alone was a bit of a metaphysical experience. Monkdom beckons me.

2008 bottle via trade with ygtbsm94. Pours a murky dark brown color with a huge rocky khali head that had good retention and lacing. The aroma was moderate in strength with cola, apples, nuts and a bit of bread. The flavor is similar to the aroma with dark fruits and caramel taking center stage, followed by nuts and yeast. The mouthfeel is smooth and creamy. The finish is long with lingering raisins. Overall: The palate is awesome, only the good brothers at st sixtus can concoct this type of palate  and I love it. The taste of the 8 is a bit milder than the 12, but otherwise quite nice. Thanks brad, this rocks.

2008 Bottle - Thanks Sam! - Pours organy brown with a nice off white head...aroma is sweet fruity malt, some dough, grape must...flavour is similar, a little bit spicy, a little bitter, nice balance with a boozy finish, very nice!

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2014 Nice brown ruby color with a creamy head. Light carbonation.
The smell starts with hints of chocolate, caramel and sourwood. Touch of alcohol, leather and dark fruit. Catch some sweet-apple, peach there, even some banana but nothing overwhelms.
Well balanced flavour with a warm alcoholic bitterness. Delicious fizziness. The taste is a chocolate/coffee background with very subtle hints of fruit... surprisingly nothing much happens in the way of taste development.

Thanks again to Cirrhosis for selling his soul and crushing the monks most sacred of beer wishes. The beer: HOLY CHRIST! Look at the insane ammount of sediment! The colour is awsome and pretty much perfect - dark red/brown with an OK light tan cap that looks like melanoma thanks to the shovelful of sediment that cannonballed into the glass. Nice malts and sweet (another grape Hubba Bubba sighting) to the nose with interesting spices....here come the hops!! Very well balanced. Very appealing. Taste is really balanced as well. Raisins, soft warm hops, tasty malts. Its too bad that I just couldnt get more out of the taste. Then I drank a ton of sediment and dammit, it is freaking tasty. Smooth and medium to full bodied with a touch of alcohol and suprisingly little aftertaste. Excellent beer.

UPDATED: JUN 8, 2009 Wow. fruit. do you like fruit? If not, then this might not be the brew for you. I managed to get my hands on a few bottles of these (thanks TimE!). Expensive as.
