The nose is faint and weak with yeast and phosphorus. THe taste again is faint yeast, more salty and bitter as it warms. The body is dry and bull bitterness. Overall, pretty darn good because of its complexity. However, just not drinkable.

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2004 Re-rate. Wanted to compare to previous experience. I was distracted byt the power of the alcohol. Otherwise, a very good beer. Very dark, muddy color. Had a huge off-white head. Aroma was strong with peach, vanilla and caramel. The flavor had a hops bite that was tempered by vanilla and orange peel with a caramel finish. It gets sweeter as you go through the glass. I was very impressed. Now bring on the Abt 12.

2003 vintage sampled in 2004: Reddish brown ale, beige lasting head with some laces. Rich, complex flavour with sweetness (malts), dried fruit (and a bit banana?). Warming alcohol. A bit watery palate considering the ABV. Overall an extremely well balanced trappist.
UPDATED: APR 10, 2004 Another good offering from the monks.  A more milder not as potenet smaller brother to the 12.  Yet still very very good.  Drinkablity and fullness is amazing
Dark brown cola-like body with off-white head.  Dry mouthfeel.  Fruit (apples), alcohol, and semi sweet malt dominates the flavor.

This is as close to the holy grail of beers as I have yet to come, and I was quite excited to get ahold of this (although the price did diminish my excitement a little bit). Had out of the bottle in a tuplip glass. Pours a dark ruby reddish color with a large, thick, foamy tan head. Aroma is obviously belgian with candi sugar, cherries, caramel, nutty notes, dark fruits, peppery and spicey, alcohol notes throughout, a hint of chocolate, slightly bready. Flavor is smooth and malty, sweet, with dark fruits and sweet caramel evident, vanilla notes. Carbonation is a little obvious for me. Palate could be a bit thicker. But overall this is a truly fanstastic brew. I can't wait to try its big brother.

WOW, it's worth the $7.89 for an 11.2 fl oz bottle.  No stamp on the cap and i believe this one to be a little young due to it's lack of complexity.  It poured out reddish brown with good carbonation throughout.  The light thin head remained and aromas of wood, fruit, and spice smelled great.  sweet malt, candy sugar and fruit were present with a nice spice finish.  The hop bite was not noticed like in the west #12 and the body is easier to drink than the #12.  I believe westvleteren to be the only triple threat of beers in the world.  Yes, they're that damm good and no one should consider themself a beer connoiseur without trying each one.  These beer set the standards, enough said go out and buy one, no matter what the price.

Kind of a hefty price tag but it's worth it to finally have Westy available in my area. I tried the Westy 12 almost 2 years ago by trading and didn't really have the palate to appreciate it at the time. This being the 12's little sibling maybe I should have tried this one first. Pours a deep mahogany color with a very thick and creamy light beige head. The foam actually threatened to escape the bottle immediately after opening. The aroma is a nice bouquet of fruit, spice and sweet malt. Rich bodied and on the carbonated side, with a mild blend of dark fruit, malt, caramel, spice and a hint of sweet chocolate. None of the flavors really stands out, instead it is a nice harmony of flavors. The finish is very crisp and lively on the tongue. The flavor is a little more subdued in the finish, but this is still a well-rounded and exemplary Belgian.
A great quality beer.All round nice head,body and taste.Not as complete taste as the abv12 but just as enjoyable.It is a pity it is hard to get hold of because i would like to try it again.

Dark maroon,brown color thick, creamy long lasting light brown head. Aroma is bread dough, plums, candi sugar, brown sugar and all spice. Smooth and yeasty, doughy with a surprising amount of bitterness. Hints of cocoa and rasin, finishes off dry. Alcohol is very well hidden. Very nice
UPDATED: FEB 23, 2004 Complex but fruity. Mild beer in "balance". This beer is complete in every possible way

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2005 Caps says best before 12/9/06.Looks to be black in color when viewed in normal light, but when held up to a bright light its a deep red color.  Quite a nice sight, as my inscription in the bottom of my Chimay glass sends a winding, twisting column of bubbles towards the thick frothy head.  The head is the color of river foam and clings to the side of the glass like a meringue.  Dry woody aroma with some light chocolatey notes.  Wonderfully thick mouthfeel.  Burnt wood, sweet malt with hop bitterness in the dry finish.  I would have like more bold sweetness and less bitter woodiness (maybe Im asking for a Westvleteren 12).

8/25/05 notes - Figs, vanilla, oak and dark grape concentrate in the aroma.  Supremely well-blended flavor.  Figgy finish.

Settles a deep dark muddy brown color, pours out a softer brown with lots of brown wet dusties and chunks from off the bottom of the bottle falling into a super gorgeous tall head of cream colored girth thats thick, puffy and whipped smooth. Lacing appears in fast dripping sheets and leaves behind some larger ink blots. A very thick skim snugs the top during the entire glass. Aroma is a bit subdued but is layered with some nice subtleties with utmost positioning yeastiness thats creating some major fresh yet dried wood characteristics upfront mixed with dirt. Very dry overall with hints of dried, even roasty, lemon, pine, and sugars. Taste has quite a mixture of things within, mostly dryish with some moderate dry wood and dirt mostly. That levels off and intermingling nuances of dried fruits, chocolate notes, and light mild spices fill in adding interesting little delicately refined yeasty layers which all maintains one very incredible smoothness. There's just a small twinge of hops but never is it in control or ever present for long. Its squeezed in there with some of the woodish yeast tones. Overall the flavors are mellowing and mild with very subtle tones and really becomes a treat as it warms. After a while I didn't even realize I was drinking a beer, it seemed more like cold Japanese herbal tea. Smaller chocolate tones appear a wee bit more as it warms with a waffer cookie dryness. Outstanding... very smooth yet thick with a mellowing full mouthfeel and easy-on-the-palate dryness that has a nice carbonation thats not overly lively. One very well put together beer, it went from wood and earthy to slightly fruity and spicy to chocolatey and always stays dry. Quite a nice cup of a tea, I mean glass of beer.

One of the finest beers I have ever tasted.  Aroma was wonderful and the taste even better.  complexity on par with rocheforte 10 but lacking the powerful aftertaste.  Simply one of the greatest beers in the world.

A much darker hue than I was expecting with a nice creamy head.  The aroma has caramel and fresh country air in it.  The plum and cherry notes are also evident.  Sweet and complex with a nice finish that contains hop bitterness and alcohol.  Very nice.  Like most complex beers I'm liking it more and more as I work my way through the glass, picking up new and interesting flavors.  Nice mouthfeel with the right amount of carbonation and alcohol presence.

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2004 (Bottled, BBE 10/2007) Dark, hazy reddish brown color with a medium, foamy and tight, beige head. Quite mild, malty and cellary, licorice/anise aroma with a hint of alcohol. The flavor is salty, neutral and malty with lots of herbs and licorice. Smooth herb-liqueur finish. Extremely smooth, quite full-bodied and warming, very easily drinkable palate. Hides the ABV well. A very enjoyable, extremely well-balanced brew, which is malty without being sweet. The herbs fit in perfectly. Much lighter and more easily drinkable than what I remembered from last time.

Huge creamy tan head, very dark mahogany body.  Aroma a bit more assertive than the 12, with plum, raisin, and toffee.  There's so much going on in the flavor it's hard to describe.  It starts off ultra-smooth, malty with some candy sugar and ripened fruit.  This sensation gives way to a slighty bitter and dry taste, with some bite of carbonation kicking in.  There are hints of fig and oak.  Somewhat vinous.  Only in the finish is there an indication of the alcohol, which manifests itself in a satisfying warmness.  Outstanding; I prefer this to the 12 considerably.  Thanks TBG!

The most amazing aroma ever...almost beyond comprehension. Juicy, cherries bursting through the skins dripping over dark chocolate packed with hazelnuts with every ingredient at its pinnacle. Couldn't stop sniffing. The appearance was glorious as well. Lots of mocha, buttery toffee and glistening caramel in body. Could drink this every day and never tire of it.
(Bottle) Pours a dark drown color with a thick tan head.  Has a rich creamy malt flavor with hints of fruit and other spices. Great beer!

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2004 Right-o. Nothing like the 12. Calmer tastes, a better palate, bla bla bla. Yeasty aroma with some dark fruits. Think of this as a dark fruits champagne. I can taste huge amounts of fruit in the taste and finish. Very dry, like a champagne. is wear they used champagne yeast. finishes with bitterness as well. Top class belgian strong.
Dark brown, minimal tan head, and medium spicy malt finish.  Bottom line, if you enjoy Belgian ales, this is a must try (if you can find one, I had to go to Belgium).  Delicious.

Murky, rusty-brown body and a large, relentless, soft ripply beige head. Very rich, malty aroma - almost wortlike. Specific aroma notes include buttery roasted nuts, burnt caramel, barnyard and earth. Rich malty flavor followed by some very nice late bitterness. Also has a woody flavor and texture even. Mouthfeel struck me as a little chalky at first but that sensation subsided and gave way to a nice, big, smooth palate. Great stuff indeed.
Overall I was a little let down when I tried this one.  This wasn't as great as I had expected it to be.
Deep brown color with a slight thin but very nice beige head. The taste is a complex mix of fruits and spices. Slight notes of alcohol and yeast. Very nice beer, wish I had more of them

Deep dark cloudy pour. Very thin head. Caramel, raison, chocolaty head. Some vanilla as well. Lots of different flavors. Figs, yeast, chocolate, raisons...very complex. A little better than the 12...but I do need to try these side by side.

Slightly cloudy, copper colored, good head and lace, steady carbonation. Insane aroma of fat bready malt, raisins, berries, spices, toffee, vanilla and brown sugar. Medium-full bodied, bit fluffy and creamy. A multitude of flavors including grain, huge malts, figs, toffee, blackberry, raisons, musty yeast a hint of chocolate and what I think may be some goldings to finish it up. Its like a liquid nutrigrain bar. Alcohol is barely noticeable, hard to believe this is beer. Incredible aroma and flavor. I need to try the 12 again.
Pours copper with floaties and a perfect head. Nice earth aroma of fruit and carmel malt mixed with fresh air. Malty fruity enjoyable palate that lingers on the tongue. Perfectly made and delicious.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: Pours with a medium head that deflates quickly. Aroma is of dark fruit, cider, and tea. The aroma is very nice and perhaps my favorite part of the beer. The flavor is milder then the aroma suggests. However there is still a good deal of complexity and it is interesting to see this in a beer that is this mild. The flavor is very coheasive and it is hard to break apart the element but some of them are a very nice dark fruit with a cider/tea mix coming in behind. A very slight burnt caramel and chocolate mix with the dark fruit flavors in the aftertaste. It is medium to full bodied and the palate is fairly smooth and creamy.

UPDATED: OCT 3, 2004 Bottle Dated 31-01-06 This one poured cloudy and dark brown with a big frothy tan head and light lacing. The aroma is similar to the Westy12, spicy with fruit notes and a little yeast showing up as well. The mouthfeel here differs though and I found it to be more of a Tripel like mouthfeel. Very effervescent and crisp. Unfortunately this does not have the big flavors of the 12. Actually a bit bland in comparison. Still a decent ale with a good malty body and a subtle spiciness.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: Pours dark brown, huge light tan head. Nose is malty, slight hop bitterness. Spicy start, yeasty middle, a touch of hops in the finish. A slightly toned down version of its big brother.

My 600th rating and what a surprise Xmas present indeed from my significant other, thedm!! I was absolutely speechless when I read the bottle cap! Let the drinking and the rating of the beer begin! It poured a huge sized tan head that was frothy with fine sized bubbles that was mostly lasting. The body had some carbonation, it was opaque with a dark red hue. The nose consisted of malt, caramel, fruity, sweet and some alcohol. The flavor was delicious as it was sweet, spicy, fruity, and some notes of alcohol with a slight aftertaste. Oh soooo good! The mouthfeel was tingly, creamy, smooth and medium bodied. This beer had good lacing to it. What a good beer to end the day with and to start our vacation with. More please?? Thanks again, Matt! You are one in a million!!

Merry Christmas Hotstuff!  I got his for her for her 600th rating.  She had been wanting this for a long time.  Well hun, your time has come!  Enjoy!  It came in a plain brown bottle with no label and only a blue Westvleteren 8 cap.  As for me, this brew poured a very large head of finely sized foamy off-white colored mostly lasting bubbles that left behind a clining vine lacing and a hazy dark brown colored semi-opaque body with a fine sediment and soft carbonation.  The aroma could be smelled as soon as it was uncapped from about 2 feet away.  It has notes of mild caramel malt and dark malts.  The mouthfeel is smooth and finishes with an alcohol tingle.  The flavor is very nice, stong from the ABV and full of note of caramel, malt,  mollases and mild port.  This is just the way I like my brews. It is dark, has a high abv, is smooth and contains no bite.  A wonderful treat indeed!

Very dark beer with a very frothy and long lasting head.  Strong aroma, hints of chocolate and fruit.  The flavour has liquorice and aniseed elements mixed in with the strong alcohol flavour.  Overall a good beer especially in the winter months.

grate taste and looks
I duno why I would heva to elaborate on this 
more souplesse than it's big brother, but less lasting taste

Deep dark ruby body topped by a beautiful huge tan head. Lacing is excellent.  Aroma is very fruity, raisins, plums and pears. The flavor is remarkable. Very complex flavor profile is similar to its big brother the abt 12, but it still stands alone. Very strong pleasing finish. The alcohol is much more subdued then in the 12. The body is full and there is a slightly woody/raisiny aftertaste. Overal quite an excellent beer.

Nice deep dark red color,small head that faded fast and left little behind to show that it was even there at all.Sweet malty aroma with a bread like appearance and mild dried fruit,and spicey.the flavor is malty and spicey with a nice fruity presence,mild alcohol at first,that changes in the after taste to a fruity and malty taste with a bigger alcohol bite.This is a pretty good brew and one that i have been saving for some time until i could find a second,but what the hell i figured i might as well start rating some of these brews i've been sitting on because getting a second just isn't happening for me.
Aroma is of pears, bread & malt.  Flavor is dry, toasty, and peppery.  As soon as I swallow, I get a split second sweet alcohol flavor - very pleasing.  I only wish I had more of this beer to enjoy.

The darkest of reds, almost purple in colour. The aroma is malty and yeasty with some spices.  The flavour is complex yet subtle, sweet malty and fruity with a dried fruit mouthfeel that stays on the palate.  Very good.

Bottle pours a deep garnet color as seen with back light with a small head and some lace.  The aroma is of fresh bread and spices.  The flavor is malty sweet with a spicy finish that lingers.  The palate is a bit spritsy and rich.  Overall, no problems with this one.

Pours a dark red when held to the light. Aroma is bready, malty, with hints of sweet dark fruits.  Flavor is complex and sweet while being so well balanced.  Palate is perfect - very soft.  Simply outstanding and IMO, better than the 12.
This beer strikes me as being perfectly balanced.

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2004 Sampled March 2004A bready, yeasty aroma emanates from my glass as I pour this murky dark brown beer.  It is topped by a thin light brown head.  The aroma has a typically Belgian spicy (pepper), aroma with a hint of alcohol, and dark fruit (raisin being dominant).  There is a hint of rum in the nose as well.  The taste is dry, dusty and spicy.  The fruit character is almost non-existant.   As the beer warms up, a bit of sweetness becomes apparent.  This beer seems very musty and dusty, for some reason.  Quite complex, with some interesting spiciness that is all over the place; notes of pepper, clove, cummin, cardamom, and all spice.  I actually like this quite a bit, though it really needs to be served on the warm side of cool to really shined. Sampled Spring 2001The offering smelled of dark candied malt accompanied by an appropriately dark brown color.  It tasted quite good, sweetish with complex notes of malt and caramel.  There was an intricate aftertaste that was complemented by a bitterness that was not from hops, but coated all 360° of the back of my mouth.  The bottle, in a tasteful way that ran counter to modern commercial methods, was completely bare except for the bottle cap, which designated the brewery and the title 8°.

11.2 oz brown bottle, with label. Poured out a hazy dark brown, with a tan colored head on it. A humongus head, at that. It slowly settled down to a lacy island of yeast floating on the top. Aromas are of dried fruits, like cherries, papaya, mango, and some banana.
Yeasty, bready, and much more like a meal than any beer I know of. Aromas change as it warms up also. The monks got this beer right, as are all of their other offerings. A truly great beer in my book. Wish I could afford a case of it.

Medium brown color. Medium white head. Aroma is malty, bananas and bready yeasts. A medium bodied Belgian Strong Ale. Malts are fruity and complex; oranges, plums and banana flavors compete with bready yeasts. Rich complex flavor. Very smooth. The flavors improve and the beers mellow as it warms. It much better at 68 degrees that 58. This is a nice beer, very drinkable. But the 12 is much better. Very drinkable and worth trying. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

Aroma is wonderful.  Aromas of wood, fruit, and alcohol.  Appearance is dark brown with huge off white head that has an interesing cosistency.  Tons of lacing.  Flavor is comlex and multi-layered.  Hard to exract all of the flavors.  Excellent.

Great appearance, the pillowy head looks like it could support me if the glass was big enough.  Aroma of alcohol, dark dried fruit with slight bannana.  A woody, fruit, bitter taste, with the retaining head it gives this a soft feel but turns watery at the end.

hazy deep brown, well reatined lacy white head.  big doughy malty aroma with ripe berries, chocolate, mild bananas.  flavour starts out smooth and chocolate and moves to fresh baked raisin bread.  dark malt and fruity yeasty flavours in the finish.  absolutely wonderful

Sampled at Stockholm Beer Festival 2003.
A lot of dark, staedy head. A bit hazy.
Well, not much of an aroma at all.
Sweet, malty flavour and some apples too.

Cloudy brown with a sticky and foamy small head. Good lacing. Aroma of sweet coffee, spices, cherries and raisins. Sweet malty flavour of toffee with some sour notes of black currant and spices. Very nice spicy and warming finish. Very complex.
One of my favorite trappist ales. I wish it was more available. It has a nice flavor, and when you pour it you see a nice creamy head. Its a strong ale, but good,

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2005  Rerate! Approx. 1 year old bottle. 
Brown colour, big head. Aroma is very complex: Dried fruits, chocolate and an alchol touch. Flavour is yeasty with a salty profile plus some licorice. There is a late, vague bitterness. The mouthfeel is very smooth, and there is an apparent alcohol feel.

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2004 Rerate, I had this one early in my rating days, and its needs to be refreshed. 
Dark amber, creamy brownish head. Aroma from malts, banana, toffee, vanilla and some soursih notes. Flavor is malty with spicy touches and some vanilla and yeast. A great beer...

(Bottle) Rating #800 - Pours a nice, foamy biege head and a near opaque reddish-brown body. Much sediment. Nose of iodine, apples and malt. Strange but energetic and engaging - like a hospital emergency room. Flavours of matl, figs, cloves, vanilla and mild spices. Finish of a ever-so-slight alcohol burn makes this a rare delight. Many thanks to RadioMGB for making this happen...

Didn't exactly set my pants on fire. The two times I have had this it's been unbelievably different, first time was over the top peppery spiciness with nutmeg overtones, the second time was really soft with boiled pea/cabbage hints. The underlying beer is solidly malty with excellent mouthfeel but the subtler flavours have been inconsistent and a little bit weird for me.

Deep rich grape and raisin aroma with toasty creamy malt finish. Hazy almond mud color with head to the end and good lacing. Flavor has NO alcohol detectable, even at room temp. Very classic creamy toast and cinnamon qualities, mmm mmm mmm. Fruity finish with a light hop smoothness. Overall it's a great belgian, one of the bests, I love it!
UPDATED: JUL 14, 2014 The greatest thing about this beer is the flavor. It is malty with dark fruit at the first sips. Then it becomes more like dark bread.

I'm not going to rule out ever trying a Trappist again, but if this is any indication of what I have to look forward to, I'm at least going to be very reluctant. The smell is sorta yeasty and malty. Malty I like, but I'm coming to realize that yeasty turns me off; not so much the aromas but the flavors it imparts.
Every time I would take a sip of this I would wince and shake my head. I just could not enjoy it.

Call me a deviant. It's OK. I can understand why everybody loves this beer but it just didn't do it for me. I'm sure there are wonderful flavors and secondary flavors and hinted at complexities that I'll never get because I'll never drink it again. My Husband brews from time to time, beer and mead and his first attempt at a blackberry mead went south. He steeped the berries, skins, seeds and all in the the hot water and honey and left them in during fermantation. When we tried it a year later it was like someone had coated the inside fo my mouth with parafin wax. It was beyond nasty, and when i tasted this beer i tasted that all over again. It's got to be the tannins. Yargh and Yuck. Sorry guys, but enjoy.

Bottle conditioned. Young sample. Deep chestnut red, Excellent thick creamy off white rocky head and good condition. Bitter yeasty and mouldy aromas laced with alcohol. Soft, smooth and malty sweet with berries and yeast in the mouth. Finish is long and slightly bittersweet, tinged with yeast. Not as good as the Abt or an aged Extra but still good.
a yeasty dark chocolate scent, nice and dark with a tight fine head, nice mellow dark chocolate flavor,  nice amounts of malt and cream, kind of watery and slight bitterness
At In de Vrede. Dense creamy head. Spicy hops in aroma, as well as some candy and dark malt. Full body with some caramel and spicy hoppiness.

Aroma smells like children's vitamins, citrus, grain and cod liver oil.  Label is straightforward -- logo looks like Afrika corps emblem.  Dark, hazy beer with light sediment.  Flavor is well-balanced and mellow.  Cakey, nutty, somewhat tannic, lightly sweet and a little smokey.  Mild hops that build. Quick toffee finish.

Initial aroma of kid's multivitamins (sweet) mellowed as it warms to a nice ripe fruit aroma. Head is quite thick with a fair bit of lacing. Flavor - improves as it warms - very balanced. Note a hint of cloves and mint. Sweet maltiness pervades throughout and provides a pleasant drinking experience. Finishes strong - very good representation of the style - not experienced to note all of the subleties that this provides - but it is damn good.

Found this at The Biertiempel in Bruges-no label, just marked by a blue cap. Rich brown color with a  grayish head that lasts. Aroma is lightly fruity, with lemon, melon, and possibly grapefruit notes. Very smooth, with fruity, smokey malt flavors giving it lots of body. A hint of chocolate is also present. Peppery notes become apparent towards the finish, which is long and lightly malty. It is seemingly impossible to accurately describe a beer this complex; every little change in temperature, chemistry, and maybe even lighting would affect how you perceive this brew.  I thought it was a very complex, very enjoyable beer that lived up to my expectations.

UPDATED: JUN 14, 2004 This beer poured a dark reddish tan color with a light tan head that stayed around for a while and left beautiful lacing. Aroma of booze, dark fruits, caramel and dough.  Taste was very winish, raisins, slight nutty, some cinnamon, and malty flavor to it with light alcohol in the finish.  A very good brew.

Bottled at Monks Cafe in Philly. They were out of the #12, which I'm dieing to try. never has this on either. Very good beer. It's a little better the Rochefort #8 Had a little more malt flavor to it.

Splendid color.  A big beautiful head that you had to wait to dissipate before you could get a good whiff of the wonderful aroma, which was as complex as any I have had.  The taste was equally complex, from chocolate, roasted malt, coffee, and port wine, to fruit.  Rich, semi-sweet finish.  Saved this one for rating #100.  Think I'll make the 12 number 200.

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2003 had in a Rapscallion glass... damn, this is one amazing beer!  amazingly complex aromas assail and toy with my senses in a such a wonderful way and with every sip i sit and am blown away by the immense interchanges of flavors and hard to perceive nuances of flavors that combine and make me want more.  add any and every positive adjective in the description and you'll be right.  but don't take my word for it...get some for yourself.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2006 had slightly below room temperature in a westvleteren glass. wow. the mouthfeel is amazing. feels smooth and full with just the right amount of carbonation. this is my first westvleteren i have tried, and i can see now what sets it apart from other belgian strong ales: nothing is out of place in this beer. from start to finish the different complexities of the taste, the look, the feel, all come together at just the right time to form a lasting impression.

UPDATED: SEP 27, 2004 Beer pours (in Chimay glass) a very dark brown, almost black liquid with small amount (1/2 inch) head with smooth texture on top followed by larger bubbles on bottom.  Some sediment in the bottle, but all of it came out when swirled with the last few oz's of beer.  Aroma is citrus orange and grapefruit - and aged bannanas?  Hey, smells like my wooden fruitbowl.  Flavor is woody, barklike, slightly piney, dry, smooth, very drinkable.  Lace is complete and doesn't fall away.  Mmmm, slight alcohol aroma nearing the end, but alcohol completely hidden and never tasted throughout, ooo, apricot and date flavor came through in that latest mouthful.  Very good beer.  Will have again.  I have had this beer one other time - when chilled.  It is much better this time - sampled at 73 degrees Fahrenheit.

RERATED 09-25-04.  A special thanks to Jim Dorsch of Vienna, Virginia (Whole Foods Market) for supplying me a whole case of this fine beer.  This beer is dated "28.08.06" and pours (in Westvleteren glass) a dark, dark brown-red liquid with a generous 1.25 inch thick beige head that dissipates slowly leaving a thick film.  Aroma is so spicy and intense it burns my nose - includes fruit, berries, port wine, grapes, plum, malt, yeast.  Flavor is spicy with port wine, malt, etc.  Definitely worthy of its score.  As it warms, this beer also resembles St. Bernardus Abt 12 as Westy 12 did, just with less alcohol.
very havy brown body and a thick dense white head.  Nose of ripe fruits and alcohol.  Big and ripe.  Thick, leathery, fruity and very warm.  Dates, tobacco and spices

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2015 Dark brown, murky.  Tan head.  Dark berry, nuts, nutmeg, cinnamon in the nose.  Very carbonated, with a sharp ginger and pepper flavor.  Alcoholic bite, but still has a very earthy feel.  A festive, pine and grain flavor, and very satisfying.

This just like the "12" is an enormously complex beer.  Great looking beer with awesome frothy head.  This has oak, nuts, chocolate and fruit flavors present in the beer.  While it is great, compared to the 12 and others I must say that this is a little thinner and a touch dissapointing.

Outstanding dark copper hue with large fizzy head and great lacing, medium-bodied. Raisin, toffee, ruby port, molasses, and bittersweet chocolate aroma, very nice indeed. Spice malty sweet flavor with woody and coffee undertones, vinous. Finished with a slighty bitter twang. Creamy and lively mouthfeel. Lighty alcoholic on the finish. One world-class abbey ale, right near the 12, highly recommended!

Deep brown body with a frothy tan seemingly everlasting head. Cocoa, light licorice, figs, malt and molasses. The taste is divine! Light alcohol, spice, hint of chipped wood, and malt. Smooth as a baby's bottom! Sediment lines the bottom of my glass and there are a few floaties abound. Yes! I love it. Wonderful beer. Like a slightly lesser version of the 12 which is remarkable.

Vertical test: sample A: freshly bought, 8%, BBd: 21/02/06, points given as above; sample B: bought 10/87, no ABV, no sell-by date, points given between [brackets]in the text.
Colour: A: thick, beige head, slowly collapsing; dark brown beer with burgundy shine; B: yellow-brown head, fast gone, thick coke-like bubbling, including the jets escaping from surface tension; brown beer, hazy [4]. Nose: a: chocolate, roasted malts, ripe pears, mocca, some faint hops, summer haystacks and more malt or maltbar; B: sweeter, molasses, something lactic, vintage portwine, hazelnuts [9]. Taste: A: bitter at first! a little bit of hops and lots of roasted/burnt malt. Enormous amount of malt overall, but much less sweetness than expected. Aroma's of walnut peel, black coffee, chicory even; B:
bitter again, but now with a fine, spritzy, acid-like surrounding. Very fruity: dark wine-grapes, hazelnuts, dried plums, figs [9]. Mouthfeel & aftertaste: A: fairly chewy; little carbonation. Lots of lasting bitterness and a little restsugar; B: less dense, impact much more refined, would even be thirst-quenching. In the aftertaste, there is a sweetness in abundant, alcoholic tones [5] Overall: This is THE proof that truly decent beer ought to be aged. A well-made, dense beer is virtually indestructible, and will better and, like this, mellow with the years. The young 8° is a crude, uncut diamond; the old one is a shining brilliant. One thing the monks didn't get right: another five years and the cap would have rusted through. B: [18]
Great beer.  A nice dark brown with a sweet aroma.  Flavor was a wonderful fruit with a nice bitter finish.

Beautiful beer! The aroma gives you very little insight as to what the beer is all about, it's complexity is so very well refined it surprises the taste buds instead of the nose. This full bodied beer tends to beat up the palate so save it for last... or first if you plan on only drinking Westvleteren (jealous). This beer stands out on its own. Trying to compare it to others is futile. If any beer should be on your top 3 "must have" list this should. I only wish I could enjoy it regularly. Must enjoy at a mild temp, 50-55 or warmer to experience all the complexities.

Impressive thick and dense head that diminishes slowly and leaves a great lace. Dark brown, full body. Aroma; sweet, chocolate, raisins. Complex and great balance. Slightly bitter finish makes me crave for more. Overall it's just a little better than "12".

Aroma of raisins, figs, malt, molasses.  Gorgeous  appearance, deep ruby with exciting haze of yeast and a good, lasting head.  Flavor is of raisins, figs, touch of chocolate and toffee.  Complex, but still very drinkable.  Palate just the slightest bit on the rough side.  A superior beer.

Dark brown, nice tan head that stays with the beer. Aroma ranges from chocolate to raisins to dark bread. Enormously complex flavor, with the same as in aroma plus more fruit, cherries, brown sugar, merlot. Soft and smooth, a little bit of alcohol aftertaste, not bitter at all. Fantastic beer.

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2004 Sweet and sugary aroma. Cotton candy, figs and raisins. Chocolate and orange zest. Heavy, vapory, malty, musky. Sediment gives yeasty sweet component. Light particulate in dark orange-brown liquid. Off-white lacing head is foamy and creamy. Heavy watery body and medium-heavy carbonation. Taste of alcohol. Deep ripe fruits - raisins, plums followed by light chalky bitter. Buckwheat honey. Hint of dry hops character. Sweet overall. Finish is sweet with bit of hops and chocolate. After is dry bitter and nutty sweet. Great balance - a tasty offering.
What can I say this beer is very nice, chalky, chocolate, pudding, and candy sugar flavours, very tasty and farely light and soft for a beer with 8% alcohol, dangerously easy to drink.

I wrote way too much for the Rochefort 10, but this is Westy 8...a true honour to drink. I sampled this at 55.8 degrees Farenheit. I'm sure it will rise a bit during the course of this comment and the drink. Good pour, with only the final .5 to 1 ounce giving large sediment. Noticablely thick tan head with the smallest bubbles i've ever seen. Coffee Geeks call this 'microfoam', but we can call it 'microhead'. The colour is dark brown but when you stretch it on the sides, some lighter brown shows through. Where do I start with the smell. If Westy 12 had the best smell i've ever had from a beer, this ranks a close second. Sour apples, candy, tartness and sugar all arise somewhere in the complex aroma. If the aroma is this complex, where does it leave the taste? A mouthful of the beer brings tons of carbonation and a coating, which tastes full of malt. Still some sour fruity tastes caot the inside of the mouth, and the aftertaste is phenominal. The taste is a bit alcoholic, but really only if you think about it. I really liked the aroma, and the taste is just a little too malty to be perfect (for my taste), but the beer is still very well done. I'm glad I got to sample this one, and I definately prefer Westy to Rochefort, even though I've sampled two of the former and only one of the latter. Definately a great beer though! I paid $10 for the bottle in Rochester, New York at Beers of the World, if you are looking for it in upstate New York.

This beer pours the cloudy brown that I've become accustomed to with excellent Belgian beers.  This one has quite a bit more head than the Rocheforts and the Westy 12.  The aroma is great - smells of fruits with an undertone of alcohol.  The taste is wonderfully smooth - must like the Westy12, but the taste reminds me a lot of the Rochefort 8.  This is one of the best beers I've had along with the others mentioned above.  If you've not had this, it's worth the high price.  It leaves a great fruity taste on the palate after drinking.  I could drink this beer all night if it weren't so expensive.

Dark brown w/ a red/orange hue. Beige head. Sweet, fruity nose of molasses, caramel plums, brandy, and some bread dough. Smooth, very substantial feel. Very complex--new flavours came through with almost every sip: dark dried fruit, plums, brandy, caramel, molasses, bread, chocolate chip cookie dough, bubble gum & a little spiciness. Finish is mildly hoppy & quite dry.

Very dark orange with a uniform tiny bubbled head. Jammy, winey aroma. Alcohol and hop initial taste, then raisins and plums - maybe some pine bark, as well Perhaps some marzipan, too. Lacks the complexity of the 12, but thats to be expected.

Heavenly aroma, of dried fruit, also some bitters. Dark brown, small vanilla head with some floaties. Fruit cake flavours, plums, figs and fine port. Complex, wonderfully balanced. Marvellous. Thanks for bringing this along Joey_Capps!

Powerful fruity, notes of sweet dates ... Very rich and full-bodied, alcoholic mixture, well rounded. Creamy, refined and classy. I do melt in your mouths. One more sip, at front sometimes you can feel vegetables, end cocoa beans with coffee ... Great Classic!
Fantastic flavor with a good scent and head. Any of the westie beers are top notch.

Giant rocky beige head.  Sour apple, raison nose.  The perfect reddish brown colour, murky.  Big fruity palate, blackberry, currant, cherries.  Medium to full bodied, lively carbonation.  I love this monk concoction.  Very subtle in every corner, but assertive and in your face. # 500! WOOHOO!

Pours with a deep burgundy body topped by a thick natural head with a good amount of lace.  Sweet vinious aroma with nice fruity notes and a good malty background.  Sweet and fruity flavor with vinious notes and a malty background with a spicy finish.  Full bodied, smooth on the tongue with a tingle at the back of the throat and slightly warming.
This beer has a black body - hue with an sweet initial flavor and a light body.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2003 This reminded me a bit like a 3-4 year old Chimay Blue.. excellent beer. Slightly bitter, hints of malt, caramel and sweets.. awesome nightcap! re-rate : slightly warming, sweet taste of malt and cocoa.. slightly fruity with a bitter finish
Deep burgundy colour.  Large, rocky head.  Aroma of malts, plums.  Flavour is malty, some toffee, fruity, sweet.  Finishes creamy and dry.
Holy Cow.  Huge malt flavor, but very balanced.  Candied goodness.  Find this beer if you can.  It is absolutely Belgian-licious!

I had this one in store for a special occasion, and AC Milan's win over Inter saturday night was worth some celebrating. Poured a very dark amber color, with a tall, lasting  head. Aroma was inviting without being too strong; not too sweet, despite the honey and fruit traces. Taste was drier and more bitter than I expected. And, hey, where did the alcohol go? Extremely drinkable, with a slightly bitter, excellent aftertaste.
This beer gave all my sences a full workout. Cant wait to try the 12 but i hear it a bit hard to find.

Burned sugar and raisins, like dark chocolate icecream with rum-raisins.
Murky red, creamy head, some yeastclumps.
Aroma is again found in the tastenotes together with a lingering fruitynes (dates). Body is expectadly lighter than the 12 counterpart.

Very, very nice beer.
complex, fruity, sweet, and hints of chocolate.
Nice melow but a bity alcaholic aftertaste.

Brown colour, thin, but creamy head, with visible yeast traces. The flavour is complex, very delicate, initially sour, then fruity (Apricot and cherry), quite yeasty and sweet (light chocolate traces). The finish has some good strawberry traces, it's a bit alcoholic and has a well balanced bitterness with coffee hints. Delicious, even if not so perfect as the "abt 12".

Dark ruby color with a thick off-white head...nice lace. The aroma was of bubblegum, alcohol, malty sweetness, and yeast. The flavor was more malty with just a slight hint of alcohol in the finish. Very well crafted beer.

Mild yeasty dark bread aroma.Very dark brown appearance with a nearly overflowing head.Dry yeasty herbal country bread flavor with a hint of mild apple and chocolate.The driest of the dark brown Trappist.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2006 Interesting beer...much more subtle that I expected. The flavors slowly develop with continued sipping. RERATE, 12/12/04 - Pours a cloudy brown, with aromas of raisins, dark fruit, and spice. Flavors are raisins, malt, some spice and yeast.

(Best by 24/May/05) The beer was poured slowly and with caution, resulting in a pillowing head. The nose is dreadfully faint, with just a touch of spicy hops. The palate is smooth dry and straight forward. I do not find this beer to be over the top in flavor or complexity. The finish is relatively quick and spicy, but not outstanding. I do find the Westy 8 to be much better than the Westy 12; I feel the Westy beers are the Marzens of the Trapist beers, just middle of the road.

Almost neutral aroma, later on I get some fruit.  Disappointing comparing to the rochefort 8 I had right before.  Some fruitiness after a while.  Flavor -- I get straightforward belgian double flavor, maybe less sweet, and clean.  To me this is not a complex beer.  That doesn't mean it isn't enjoyable, just not quite as much as I wanted.

Had from bottle on March 6, 2003Wow.  My first shot at a Westy, and color me impressed.  Of course, I had high expectations coming in (the #1 and #3 beers on the site), and this one met them all.  Pours a very dark red/brown with a large head and tons of bubbles quickly inflating the head.  Also has a lot of sediment which adds to the mystique of this rare beer.  Aroma is extremely appealing with some fruits, almost wine-like and a hint of bread/dough.  The initial taste is extremely complex.  It started a bit too cold to fully enjoy the flavors, but after it warmed a bit, it was much more enjoyable.  There's so many different flavors, it's hard to isolate them for the rating.  There are, similar to the aroma, hints of fruit, toffee, nuts?, and many others.  Whereas I had a bit of trouble polishing off the Rochefort 10, the Westy 8 masks the alcohol perfectly and is just a gem to drink.  If you have not had this one, it is a must find!

Pours with a huge head, tons of active bubbles and fine lacing. Nose is a plethora of wonderfulness.....fresh bread dough, nuts, dark fruit, orange, toffee...Not sure I really need to DRINK this! Malty, dark fruit, slightly sweet, bitter, slight acidic...Can you say complex?! Finishes slightly sweet and then hop bitter. Tough call between this and the 12. Enjoy at room temp, I think its slightly better this way.

Intense fruit - much juicier than the 12. Shows the alcohol a little too much, and is surprisingly rougher than the 12. Sweet brown sugar malt. Attractive long lasting head but muddy body. Lacks the deep softness and magic of the 12. Stands on its own as a delicious brew. A damn fine ale, but not a world classic.
Bottled. (Off course) Not as dark as the Abt, but certainly as beautiful.  Sweet aroma.  Quite bitter and little bit spicy flavour.
More words on my second bottle.  For this one only some very high numbers and a big smile.  I just found out that it is possible to get these in the States.

Good looking in the glass, with a lot of yeast remaining.  The 11 oz. quantity foamed over in my 22 oz. tumbler.  Anyway, I detected a smoother and less intense version than the 12.  It had a winelike consistency with more subtle raisin and bready flavors than in the 12.  Hops were barely noticable, and the alcohol was very well hidden.  It is one of the best, and it goes down smooth.
user_location: Lake in the Hills, Illinois, USA

text: Beautifully rich, dark beer with a strong woody flavor.  Just made ya feel good all over.
Dark, brownish black with a large creamy head.  Average aroma, just strong maltiness.  Low hop presence but it has a nice roasty flavor with hints of caramel and raisins.  Friendly and complex.

Dark red color with a thick, lush head.  Many flavors abound, including strange fruits I may have never heard of before.  This is extremely complex, and a highly enjoyable BSA.  My only reservation is that the carbonation is a little much.

This is one hell of a unique beer.  The aroma is like a sweet wine or a mead, very fruity and sweet.  The body is a lovely burnt orange.  There are considerable amounts of floaties, but that's my fault from pouring it.  This has a very tingly, carbonated mouthfeel.  The flavor is mildly sweet, yeasty, with notes of grapes, cherries, spices, bread.....and pez?  The finish is creamy and dry at the same time, if that's possible, with a lingering, candy-like flavor.  This is wonderfully different, but I'm not sure if it's quite worth the 10 bucks for the 11.2 ounce bottle.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2006 (Rating Adjustment)  Holy CRAP man.  The aroma on this brew has to be the best aroma I have ever experienced in a beer.  Goes right to a 10.  Fruity (pear, prune, raisin) , malty and sweet, little alcohol, some caramel, absolutely fantastic.  Much less sedimant in this one as compared to my first go.  Molasses, sweet malts and grapes in the flavor.  Yummy.  A world class brew.



Wow, now I know why this brew is one of the best.  Awesome color of rich, dark orange/brown with great clarity.  Wonderful lingering head with excellent carbonation.  This is how a beer is supposed to look.  Everything was going great until I got to the bottom of the bottle and unsettled the 3/8 inch of sediment in the bottom.  Much more than my fancy.  Not small particles either but rather large chunks  which do not look appealing floating in the paper cup (just kidding).  This does not detract from the flavor, though, which is complex with plenty of malt and slight wine overtones and a tad of alcohol.  Aroma of roasted grain and yeast.  Creamy, smooth finish with a touch of alcohol.  Very smooth drinking and enjoyable.  A beer that ever person should be required to try at least once.

This one pours a dark cloudy brown color with a big, off-white, lingering head. It has a nice sweet aroma of spices, malts, and yeast, and just a tad bit of alcohol. Full bodied and rich, the flavor is spicy and malty sweet, bready and yeasty, with a mild alcohol warmth. Carbonation levels are perfect, I could drink this all the time. What a great beer, fantastic flavor and a high drinkability.

Copper colored brew. Well carbonated with a lacing hanging on till the final farewell.Winey, honey, grapey nose.Medium/light body.Honey,mead like flavors stand out.Probably a bit over carbonated, for me anyway.

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2004 Excellent brew!  Yeasty aroma and flavor.  Dark brown in color.  Average head.  Delicious blend of yeast and sweets.  No alcohol taste at all.  One of my favorite Belgium so far!
Complex fruit flavors makes this very drinkable and very addictive.  Now I need to find the 12.

Nowhere close to the 12, but still a fine beer. I hate having to pay $9 a bottle to try, but its one of those things thats hard to resist after you read all the hype.  If the choice is between the 8 and the 12, choose the later.  Fruit flavors, yeast, sweet, almost perfect balance of flavors.

I was expecting the 8 to be a lot more similar to its big brother, but I think this is far less fruity and a bit yeastier. There is a very apparent lingering bitter scootin around beneath the malt and loitering on the palate. I cant shake a somewhat funky barley taste though, but the grains in the malt are otherwise amazing.

Cap dated03.10.05: Murky brown with a med sized head.Chocolate covered fruit aromas.Musty yeast is underlying.Mouthfeel is dry and spritzy. Too carbonated.Flavors are sweet,rich,but hard to discern because of the carbonation.Finish is somewhat sweet and like daniwerks said"Cola-ish". Becomes extremely bready/biscuit as it warms.Fruity flavors become more noticable. The least amount of yeast in any Westy bottles I have ever seen. I was able to pour this without worrying. Never seen that before.

Very, very malty stuff.  Quite candyish, buckets full of interesting sugars.  Cola-ish, maltiness is very prevalent but still sweetly enjoyable.  Surprised at the sweetness of this one, very interesting stuff, but could use a bit more depth.
Whoa!  Its got it all.  Malty, but not cloyingly so.  A tad smoky.  Some coffee notes as well.
head fizzled when poured and quickly disspated.  slightly sour fruity aroma.  taste hinted of apricot?  lots of sediments floating around.  Great beer but not sure it deserves all its reputation.
Port, brady, and cedar aroma and taste. As it warms has a aroma of fine tobacco. Wonderful fine carbonation on the palate.  Not quite as complex as the 12 and therefore in my book not as good.
cherry aroma, perfect medium brown color, sticky fruity bitters, not that huge but still big!  I love this beer and sampling it out of a crystal glass made it even more spectacular

A lot of carbonation!  Good mahogany color and good head retention as well.  Alcohol is evident but not bothersome at all.  VERY bready, yeasty.  A palatable beer with pears and other fruity esters in the aftertaste.  I liked this better than Chimay Blue, and cant wait to try the Abt 12.

Very carbonated.  Creamy off-white head, mostly diminishing.  Translucent brown.  Tart acidic finish.  Lightly doughy flavor.  Easy drinking.  Alcohol apparent and warming, but not overwhelming.  Im going to have to give the 12 a try.
Similar to Rochefort 8, but the alcohol is much more apparent.  Super vinous.  Raisiny, plumy with a dry bitter finish.
No additional words needed, I was just glad I found it
This beer is def the wait, i enjoyed ever sec of this, i would def recomend this to anyone im shocked that the 12 coulb be better.
WOW!  This is absolutely superb.  Wonderful nose and mouthfeel.  Im not sure how the 12 could be better, but hopefully Ill get to try one.   This was surely worth the wait to find one.
Arrrrgggghhhh to be a Trappist Monk....seriously though the quality of the flavour and aroma is hard to match.  Try following this up with a Triple......heaven, thats why its brewed by monks!!!!!

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2006 Bottled on 11/28/02, sampled on 3/14/06: bottle had some strange black gunk on the inside of the bottle neck and cap, but it didnt seem to have affected the beer.  Beer pours a hazy dark mahogany with a frothy, nicely-lacing light-tan head.  Complex, bready, earthy, even bordering on musty at times, aroma has nice sweet caramel malt and dark fruity notes.  Body still has lots of carbonation and pleasant, sweet, earthy toasted malts with good yeasty balance and a drier finish than I remember.  Always a treat to try this.  Thanks to DaveCooks for the bottle!

2/19/2004: (bottled on 12/7/99) I think this version has aged much more than the previous rating.  Pours a dark ruby brown with a thick, well-lacing off-white head.  Slightly oxidized plum, caramel, and Belgian yeast aroma.  Body has much improved from before, yeilding layers of complexity and sweet toffee-like malt flavor.  Body is very smooth, yet has a good thickness and finishes semi-dry and bitter-sweet, without a hint of alcohol.  This is a truly great Trappist ale.  

12/10/2002: Sweet aroma of dates and grapefruit with a great yeast profile.  Pours a real dark brown with a thick appetizing head.  The body is not nearly as sweet as the head lets on, but there is a good deal of spice.  The palate is a bit too fizzy and carbonated.  It has a slightly oaky bitter finish and conceals its alcohol very well.  Fairly complex, but im surprised this is in the top five beers in the world (well, at least it was when I rated it).

i can smell the fruity nose and im six feet away.  Juicy fruit nose.  brown with redish hues, if I was shown an picture I would instantly assume it to be a trappist.  Lots of lace, warming finish, lots of spice, cinammon.  sharper flavors standing out much more then the Rochefort 6 I had earlier.  Thankyou Kaya

color is like a deep mahogany, head is absolutely huge-very very light beige..aroma is quite yeasty, with melon and nutmeg and perfumey. expected the flavor to be somewhat sweet, but it didnt pan out. big malty flavor with an intense warming sensation in the mouth. alcohol was detectable but not overwhelming. im sure there are some things im missing in there, but i never claimed to have the most sophisticated palate in the world!
Good stuff

Deep ruby red brown color. Huge compact head. Long stitches of lace work. Aroma of malt, fruit,(raisins, prunes) and burnt rubber. Malty flavors morph into a fruity dryness coupled with a soft nutiness. Oak and slight bitter finish. Not as complex as I anticipated.

"Temporarily unavailable. Are you sure you dont have any of the 12?" "Ill check... no"  "Alright... ill settle for the 8."   -- Well at least i got one of them , at didnt have to go pay 150 dollars for a case at the distributor like the barmaid suggested. The Westy 8 was good, and although i liked the Rochefort 10 better, this was filled with wonderful aromas and tastes of fruits, candies, and chocolate. Excellently balanced. ... Now if i can just find the 12..
Nice raison-grape aroma. Malty-sweet flavor with a perfect amount of bitterness.

Black, with a large thick head. Aroma is interesting, couldnt pick out any one scent to name. *taste* Sweet Mother of God! That is one awe-inspiring beer. It doesnt taste like any beer Ive had before. Its just barely sweet. Theres a lot going on in it, but the complexity doesnt distract like Ive found in many beers. It all just kind of blends together into one pleasant beer. That being said, at $7 a 12 oz bottle, Ill probably never buy this again. Its  just not worth that much.
Not as good as the 12 but still very good.

Aroma was vinous, with hints of chocolate, bread, and apricots, and something that reminded me of a salty sea breeze. 
Flavor was somewhat understated and bready at first, obscured a bit by strong effervescence. It possesses a decent hint of alcohol in the flavor, and a strong bitterness. Finishes with some nice notes of red wine and oak.

reddish brown with spuratic bubbles chasing each other around and settling in  frothy white soap suds on top..aroma was a squeeze of sour grapes, a pinch of white pepper, and chunks of peanut brittle..Juicy plums, puckery grapefruits, rubber brownies..Upon a second pouring, the peanut brittle aroma was more refined and also let out brown sugar cries..Rubbery texture..diluted chocolate..citric-membrane bitterness..all hiding the alcohol well..

Started plummy sweet, moved strongly into bubble gum territory, a hint of chocolate and anise and spices.  Started with a good head and left plenty of nearly invisible lacing.  Palate was good, but could be thicker.  Aftertaste is chewy and left me with a lot to contemplate.  Its complexity was there, but paled in comparison to the Rochefort 10.  On to Westy 12 next week!  (This bottle cap is stamped 24/05/05)
Nice brown color with a nice beige head.  Fruity and delicious, this brew is the best belgium ive tasted.  I cant wait to try the 12

UPDATED: APR 23, 2008 Bottle...This beer rocks!... I wanted to re-rate this beer, I think I scored it just a tad bit high during my first tasting. Its still a great beer, but is no longer my favorite Belgian. That honor now goes to the Westy 12. Thanks go out to hopsrus for my second tasting of this excellent ale.

Mouth watering aroma of enormous complexity. Very pretty head which lasts throughout, dissapting to a film. Served at cellar temperature, I found the flavor to be nice, but not much more.  Certainly some oak, plum and nuts, but on the whole rather restrained, if not a bid frigid.

I really dont get what all the hoopla is about.  Yeah, its a good belgian ale.  But its not a great belgian ale.  At least not good enough to warrent in the top 10 rated beers.  Hints of tannin, oak, a little syrup sweetness.  Hoped it would mature as it warmed and produce some more flavors, but I was dissapointed.  Bring on the Westy 12!

This is really good, but a bit weak for my tastes.  I adore the candy aromas and the butterscotch flavor but theres not too much else.  I prefer the 12.  Obviously Im being picky considering my rating!
Strong alcohol and bubblegum, lots of candy, feel and flavors are thin and spirited with alcohol fire, sweet and tasty but not a champ by any stretch.

tantalizing musky alcohol induced nose. murky brown color with a light head. Ive had the 12, and I must say that the 8 is great, but not quite as rich. incredibly complex flavor and finish. hints of grain, maybe even pecan in the beginning, perfect hop mix in the finish. yum yum.

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2007 Good head. Malty aroma with plums and orange. Full bodied. Very complex taste with plums, caramel, licorice, coffee, apple and pear. Alcohol present, but well hidden. A bit syrupy.
Is this a great beer? Absolutely! Is it a classic? Yes! Buy it whenever you can. But is it worth a top 5 spot? Im not sure...

Westvleteren 8 2005, tasted 06.03.07. Malty aroma, not too abundant. Caramelpudding. Malty, caramelly flavor with hints of cinnamon and clove. Fluid bread, extremely well balanced. (8 4 9 4 16 = 4.1).

Westvleteren 8 1993 or 1995, tasted 06.03.07. Malt, porto and a hint of coreander in the aroma. Malty flavor with milk chocolate and caramel. Has become thinner, but still a firm and well balanced beer. (8 4 9 3 16 = 4.0)

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2013 Bottle from Kihoskh, Copenhagen (cap date is 04.07.16). Head is initially average sized, frothy, light brown, mostly lasting. Body is hazy medium brown, bottle conditioned. Aroma is moderately malty (caramel, chocolate, nuts), lightly to moderately hoppy (herbs), lightly yeasty (cobwebs), with notes of cinnamon, raisin, honey, date, alcohol. Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter. Medium to full body, syrupy/watery texture, lively/fizzy carbonation, moderately alcoholic. I rated a 3-year-old bottle at Akkurat a week ago and it wasnt that great (3.4)...count me as one who prefers Westy fresh. This was apparently brewed only 5 months ago and is quite vibrant and balanced. Wonderful beer.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2003 Was lucky to have this as well as the 12 on the same night. Colour is dark brown with a huge chocolatewhite head. Aroma is full of spices. Flavour is a little more alcaholic than the 12, but again you are bombarded with tasteimpressions when this heavenly brew hits the mouth.
UPDATED: JUL 26, 2003 Dark brown w/ a huge head. Malty w/ flavors of raisin & warmth. Very sweet finish

The middle sampling in a visit to the Monastery bar this summer.  The rocky head filled my nose with a unqiue malt aroma and complex fruits.  Sweet raisins, coffee, chocolate and some berries combine with the warming alcohol to complete this special experience.

Huge, foamy head and great lace.  Deep, jewel-like garnet color.  Sweet, candied sugar nose with hints of yeast and faint must.  Complex combination of sweet tastes with wine and sherry tones.  A tantilizing cluster of flavors that leave a smile on your face.  Well balanced in the finish.  I liked it better than Westy 12.

Finally tracked this one down (at Monks in Philly) and enjoyed it immensely last night. Fizzy head subsides quickly to a lasting tannish film. Dark fruit in the nose, dates, figs, cherries. Chocolate, malt, plum, and a wonderful hint of sourness in the mouth. Spicy. Very long finish with flavors arriving after the beer is gone.

I opened the bottle and it started to fiz out of the top.  The carbonation was a little high.  Very yeasty. The yeasty aroma then took over. Very smooth flowing and tasty ale.  The alcohol was slightly noticeable, but it was a warm sensation as I was drinking this belgian brew.  I expected more from this one than it delivered.

I liked the 12 much better, even this is still great. Fruity aroma, like dates, plums and also cherries; hints of honey. Amber red body with a little layer of a head. Chocolate, alcohol, plums and malt taste. Very spicey. Warms you up because of the alcohol. Peppery fullmouth finish.

Yes! Starts with a fruity, molasses-like nose with hints of figs and dates. Dark amber-brown color. Low head on the sides of the glass. Big warm round sweet malt taste fills your mouth completely. Hints of spices accent the full body. The alcohol comes through and intensifies the flavor. There is a long subtle bitterness at the end. Perfect balance - smooth as hell. Classic brew - great all around.

Re-rate: Used to like this more than the 12, but on second inspection, i think i was wrong, this is still very nice though, chalky, chocolate, pudding, and candy sugar flavours, very tasty and farely light and soft for a beer with 8% alcohol, dangerously easy to drink.
Huge thick head lasts long.  Tan, copper color.  Similar to the 12 but not as strong.  Subtle textures of fruits, spices, and an underlying alcohol.  This is a great beer, I should have bought more!

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2007 Well Can it actually be better. I had this one before, a couple of  months ago in Cafe Belgie in Utrecht (just like eczmatic), but by then I wasnt familiar with this site. Westvleteren 12 was the first I rated, 8 is number 100!
When I just opened the bottle, the Dutch Soccer team made 2 goals in 3 minutes  against Belarus (tnx caesar). And with such a great palate and a well balanced, complex taste in my mouth this was one of the best moments in my life! ;)
What makes this beergood (and better than the Westy 12) is the great balance between hoppy bitterness and malty sweetness. Very uncommon.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2004 Very similar to the no. 12, although not as strong in aroma and not as intense in complexity. But very close. I even found this one more easy to drink which gave me a greater experience of the beer. The flavour is more creamy and the nutty tone is sharper in this one than the 12. I'll save some of theese too. RE-RATED -aged vintage '72; rating: 8 4 9 4 18=4,4: Very delicious! Nice malty notes and some liquorice in the aroma. Sweet malt and some fruit in the flavor. A lots of chunks in the bottom of both glass and bottle. Dark amber->brown color. Large lazy bubbles (sign of the fact it was an aged bottle). Low carbonation. Nice palate of liquorice and dry, burned brown sugar. White chocolate in the aftertaste. Thank you so much Joris for giving me the opportunity to try this one!

This was, if not, the best beer, of any style, I have ever had. The subtle flavors changed as the goblet was slowly drained away. Each sip was a new experience. I cannot wait to try the #12. This has officially replaced Chimay as my favorate in Belgum Ales.
This is one of the worlds greatest beer.  Maybe not the best, but pretty close.
UPDATED: JAN 19, 2004 MY 500TH RATING!!!  Awesome, very similar to the 12, almost black in color, great lacy head, very complex flavors & aromas, all around very excellent beer!!
Like the 12, but not so tasty!

A dark orange cloudy beer with a beutiful head. It has a fresh fruit aroma and tastest slightly acidic and sweet with notes of fruits. Definatly a great beer - but in my world not one of the best two beers - though still high on my list.

the bottle didnt have a label and this was disappointing; no wonder most beer shops dont sell this. tasted of stewed pears without the pears and had a hot chips with tomato sauce texture. hard to treat such a revered beer too seriously
Great ale. Complex favors but not overbearing  with a nice creamy smooth finish very drinkable. Recommended a must try.

Although I have to say I prefer the 12, this is my second favourite trappist beer - not a bad feat for one brewery.  I found the flavour quite similar to the last Chimay blue I had, but maybe thats just me.

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2011 Rerate Wow, this beer is not a beer to start an evening with. IMO this one exceeds the Westy 12, because of its better palate, not having the alcoholic taste. This one is softer, but therefore the mixture of great flavors is more present. Original rating: 4.4

This is probably as close to perfection in a bottle as its going to get. Wonderful vinous quality about it and a little spiciness.  It has a very appealing green apple tartness balanced by some candy sugar sweetness that makes this one of the most enjoyable beers Ive had the pleasure of tasting.

aha my first encounter with the "mythical" westvleteren, in cafe belgie in utrecht... since everyone else seems to be having a competition to see who can identify the most flavours in there, ill opt out and simply say that this is surprisingly smooth and light-textured, rounded and silky on the palate, and fruity without being overpowering. but its not THAT amazing.
Excellent.  Those wonderful monks.  Such a fine beer from a fine country...

Ahhh ... the mythical Westvleteren.  Lovely dark appearance.  Slightly burnt aroma.  The first taste was a bit metallic but over time came to remind me of the Orval.  A light sweetness that was bubbly.  A great beer.  The best?  Nope, but certainly great.  I yearn for the day I can sample the 12.
A lite version of the 12 with much of the same flavors.  Only tasted twice, once at the Abbaye.

Less alcohol burn than the 12, but that goes without saying.  Seems to have more carbonation which is a nice thing.  Complex, but the 12 might be a bit moreso which is one of its strong points and yet for the first tasting of these two I preferred this one over the 12.  Will try them both again soon.

NOTE:  Aroma and flavor are markedly improved when served at room temperature (rating based on room temperature).  The first part of the beer was consumed at ~60F, and it was nearly unpleasant.  There was a malty raisiny aroma.  The flavor was rich, but not very pleasant.  Sweetness was missing and astringency was present.  When it ultimately warmed up, I was drinking a much better beer.  Raisin aroma with rich brandy overtones.  The sweetness finally showed up, although I still might have preferred just a bit more.  Malty and rich, with raisin and caramel most noticeable.  Mild alcohol burn in the aftertaste, and the slightest astringency as well (a shadow of the previous amount).  Its a good beer, but I think Ill need to try it again now that I know how to serve it.  Might want an older beer as well (this was a brand new bottle).

Perhaps it goes without saying, but room temperature seems to be the only way to truly enjoy this beer.  When cold, it has a harsh aroma (Aaron says raisins, I say Play Doh -- its sweetly plastic-y with an acridness that I couldnt place but that seemed, to me, reminiscent of Play Doh).  When it warms, the whole thing warms -- the flavor, the aroma, everything.  Its infinitely more pleasant, and more worthy of the scores its gotten.  The color is a reddish-brown of wet terra cotta, and the head pours large and dissipates quickly.  The flavor is rich and smooth with some spiciness (cinnamon and ginger) in it.  It is what I imagine a cider wine or cider liqueuer might taste like (Ive never had anything of the sort).  Its smooth and balanced, gentle and sweet.  A lovely sipping beer.  I only wish that I were enjoying it during winter next to a crackling fire instead of on a nearly 100 degree day in August!
The aroma is like for its big brother, the 12. The taste is slightly less complex and less sweet. Do note that this gives it a more controlled character. This one really stands up to the 12.

Bottle brought to me from my Uncle John shipped back from Monks in Philadelphia.  A reddish brown murky color with an off-white laced patchy head. The aroma has a sparkling zest with red vinous fruits (ala Rodenbach), alcohol, lemon, citrus, and grapefruit, but these aromas do not carry over as much into the flavor which is darker and richer than the aroma would suggest.  The Westvleteren 8 is drier than the 12 and has more discernable peppery, banana, and malty flavors in addition to the dark fruits.  I like the aroma of the 8 better than the 12 but everything else is a notch down (but still exceptional).  Medium body and somewhat edgier than the 12 with more carbonation.

When you pour it, it sounds like a cola with its fizzy, lively head. Bubbles steam up the sides, again much like a coke, but with this beer, the head stays, but forms an odd concave surface as the middle starts to fade, but the outside stay much the same, reinforced by the constant bubbling. Head lacks the creaminess of the 12. Initial flavor is surprisingly realistic cocoa. There was some complexity, but that was the big flavor. Not as complex or as balanced as its big brother.

Strong flavours of chocolate, mollasses and  cardboard. Aromas of sherry and chalk, long finish in the palate. Delicately balanced sweetness, smooth and rounded. An absolute masterpiece of brewing. Millions of thanks to Duff, he is a legend.

UPDATED: OCT 19, 2003 My first Westy, but certainly not my last. Full thick foamy head to begin, I let it warm up, and blossom slowly.Complex flavors, More frothy than a Quad Shot Latte from Starbucks.Rich complex flavors that fill your palate with flavors of chocolate and wine. World class beer here, my other bottles will be saved for special occasions. 100% Recommended.This One is a WINNER!!!

This beer pours up with a boisterous head comprised of unusually large bubbles, and the lightly tanned foam lingers over the ruby/brown body for what seems like ages, never quite disappearing.  The aroma is not so spicy and yeasty as its big brother, the Westy12.  The flavor, however, is just as spicy, if not quite so full.  The alcohol does not seem to be masked as well as could be desired, though it is far from overpowering.  It does not cause the entire palate to dance and tingle, but it at least gives it a good whirl.  The head sheets the glass as one progresses, leaving behind an intricate tracework.  As it warms, more of the fruits (predominantly raisin and perhaps plum) assert themselves, helping to balance the spices.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2015 Good beer, quite bitter considered the style. Fantastic ageing in the first few years. Still, its inferior to the Westvleteren 12, its bigger, more complex and sweeter brother. Like the other Westvleteren brews i think it is overrated because of the scarcity, but i cant deny this is a nice brew.

Belgian offering; no label.  Root, vine, cardboard, concord grape, wood, perfumey hop aroma.  Extremely earthy, as if I were digging a hole to plant hops in fresh soil.  Chocolate was not the main theme here.  Schwarzbier-like aroma, also, with subtle hints at raisin.  Although the chocolate cream pie, crust and all, was faintly evident.  Smooth chocolatey mouthfeel and warming alcohol.  Perfectly displayed velvety malts are dominant before blasts of alcohol wipe out the spicy and dry finish.  Finishes very warming, not as sweet as I would have liked, and moderately bitter.  Most comparable to St. Bernardus Abt 12.  Why no vintage date on such an extraordinary and classy beer?
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: No beer is perfect, but this is as close as Ive found--I really preferred this to the 12, actually.  I approached this beer with skepticism, wondering perhaps if the reputation was artificially inflating its standing.  Initially my beer was too cold and, with a suppressed aroma and slightly less chewy texture (than the 12) I thought this was going to disappoint.  But NO!  Once it hit optimum temperature, this was a world beater.  The head, first off, was great fun--something I wish the 12 was capable of producing.  Then, warmer, the palate came to life, being both smooth and lively (and oh so easy to drink!).  The aroma and flavor complexity came to life as well.  It has to be said, it probably isnt as complex or unique as the 12.  In the 8 you can compare this to a lot of doubles/doppels in its flavor components.  The saving grace here over and above those beers (and doppels, I admit, are my favorite style anyway) is that this one perfectly balanced sweetness with bitterness.  There were traces of bitterness and certainly plenty of sweetness.  Just as I thought, if this warms up much more, the bitterness and/or sweetness is going to become too much, it pulled back and never pushed it over the edge.  What a wonderful beer.
Excellent brew, smooth, fruity, with a good kick.
Closely resembles its bigger brother.  Fruit, chocolate, caramel.  A bit less complex, but I dont want to take anything away from it.  Truly marvelous.
Oh babe!

UPDATED: MAR 12, 2009 Dark candi sugar in everlasting but subtle raisinsRich grape and black currant juice covers the pie crust...Bready yeast develops into a nourishing finish...The sweet grapiness gets to be too much for my tastes at times, but it doesnt appear in every bottle...I find this doesnt age too gracefully by the way; oxidation creeps in very early...

I find the 8 to be a better beer than the 12, and certainly the more appropriate for a greater range of applications.  Dont get me wrong, the 12 is magnificent- bolder and more concentrated than the 8.  However, the 12 has a medicinal component that is disconcerting.  I still enjoy it, but only for dessert.  The 8, with its malty, bready nose and lovely dried fruit is almost perfect.
UPDATED: MAR 28, 2004 Reminds you very much of the 12, but if you put them up together the 12 is slightly better and more powerful. However, this is still a world class beer.
Nice aroma, beautiful caramel color, incredible flavor. This was my first Westvleteren thanks to austinpowers and I see this as being my next favorite ale. Beautiful. Now, on to the 12.
Great malty nose with a hint of chocolate.  Body tastes like a double yeast chocolate sweet bread.  Finishes slightly sweet.  Another great beer from a great brewery.
I think those monks really know there stuff. One thing was a very large amount of yeast in the ale. More than Im used to. Still deserving of the ranking. World class, very pricey beer.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2011   6/20/02: Very soft nose, slight chocolate malt...as with the 12, what separates this beer from pretty much the rest of the world is the perfect finish. Flavor lingers, and alcohol seems to not even be present. 2nd in the world on my list, behind only the 12. 
 4/4/11: Tasting an Extra 8 from 5/03, this has developed complex raisin and prune fruit notes above its chocolatey malt flavor. FInish is soft and long.

Only second to its big brother the 12. Very dark with a big head. Soft malty nose of ripe fruit. Flavor is sharp, chocolatey with just a bit of soft fruit and finishes with the classic westy smoothnes.
One hell of a beer!!!!! Need I need to say more?
2nd best ever ...

Prelude: A pair of Westys, gifted to us by the inestimable PsychProf, a fine summer evening, our balcony, and Carolyns wonderful eggplant pasta in our bellies.  Could it be any better?

Appearance: Even more obviously bottle conditioned than the 12, with a big frothy flash head and a great deal of sediment a swirl in the bottom.  Even more fascinaingly live than its cousin, the body electric here.  

Aroma: Resembles another alcoholic beverage more than most beers - I alternate between port and whiskey as I inhale.  Not the rich treasure of the 12 aroma, but close.

Flavor:  A wild climb through flavors with good hazelnut at the base and some hoplike bitters accompanying spices as you go.  Gets sweeter, brown sugary, eventually as the bittering smooths out.

Palate:  Considerably rockier than the 12, though it smooths into a rich, full body.

Overall: Somewhat edgier than its more lauded brother beer, the darker sheep of the Westy flock, perhaps, but still a damn fine brew.

Very appetizing, complex and perfumed flowery, slightly sweet, malty, bready & fruity (black cherry?, raisin) aroma.  Thats for starters, anyway.  Whiff of alcohol.  The beer is the color of old rust, deep reddish brown.  Looks very similar to many barleywines Ive had, definitely very murky (I swirled and poured).  Fine-bubbled but strong head with impressive lacing.  Here we go...  Wow.  Malt flavors are dominant here, and mouthfeel is surprisingly lively.  I can find dark brown sugar, chocolate, apple butter, raisin, and spices here.  This would make a perfect dessert!  There is a spicy, very slightly nutty and nougaty quality to the finish, and there are some hops here at the end, too, albeit not strongly.  Very complex flavor.  Incredibly smooth palate and long malty finish.  Slight warming sensation in my chest from this.  Oohh, this is good beer.  I may have to mail order 12 or so of these and have my friends try it.  I feel this is a beer to be shared, if possible.  Undergoes intriguing changes as it warms.  This is seriously good stuff.  I want it to be fall already, it would make this beer even better, somehow, I think.

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2003 Pours a cloudy reddish-brown color, huge thick foamy head. Sweet sugary candy aroma, flavors of caremel toffee and butter, perfect thick and creamy mouthfeel, smooth and silky, It don't get any better than this, well maybe the 12.

Rated at the same time as a Westy 12. For intro blurb see my rating for the 12.
Appearance is the same as the 12 altough the 8 for me had the slightly bigger longer lasting head. Awsome aromas very similar to the 12 but possibly a bit more delicate and a little less aromatic. Body and feel is fractionally smaller than the 12 also its not quite as smooth. Great finish and aftertaste. An awsome beer that has to rate up there with the best.
Good. but not comparible to any of the Chmay line. The fruity taste is way too strong but it does hide the alcohol well.

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2003 The sampled bottle was from 1994. Redbrown hue. Aroma is full with lots of chocolate. The flavor is not really what you expect from an eight year old trapist. It is sharp with minerals and chocolate tones. The sharpness is reminiscent of ground pepper and it lasts forever, but still a top brew. In a fresh bottle sampled last week  there were dry malty tones in the aroma. 
The flavour was fruity with some sweetness an tones of plums. Dry finish. So, the rating stands and I like better fresh.

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2008 I like it at least as much as the 12...but it fulfills a different purpose. It is more focused somehow. Aubreys comments from today are telling...there is a yeastiness in the aroma that works well. The velvety feel in the mouth is absolutely there, but slightly diminished from the 12, and more effervescence is in its place. Sharper when cold, and when warmed. Not as full, slightly less fruity, still truly excellent. If one had mucho money, you could have several of these, but the 12 is too much of a meal within itself for the same comment.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: Sampled the 1994 version in 2002: Burgundy coloured. Coffee, berries and dark chocolate in the nose. Malty, complex and mature with toffee flavours. Rich sweet finish. Wonderful!

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2007 Bottled, 2 years old: Not a very strong aroma but theres caramel and clove. Dark reddish brown color,  beige head, good lace. Light sweet, very very malty. Full, liquid bread, solid. Bottled, May 2002, 4.1: Raisin, plum, nutty aroma. Brown/redish, off-white frothy head, nice lace. Light sweet, fruity, rainsin, complex flavors. Long lasting finish.
a very dark red brown color and has a fruity flavor

All I have to say is wow.  Brow in color, smooth and silky in flavor.    Absolutely superb stuff.  One of the finest I have yet to sample.
