The one thing that eludes me is the touch of dankness in flavor.  Its intriguing to me.  At $8 per bottle, I dont know if I will be testing it out again any time soon.

UPDATED: NOV 10, 2016 2016-11-08, vintage 2010, bb 19.11.13, 6 years old, 6-4-7-3-13=33A lot of chestnut honey and hazelnut, the body is obviously thinning, and there is no bitterness; interesting cask hints in the final.Old but drinkable.2013-03-08, vintage 2001, 12 years old, 7-4-8-3-16=38bb 03.04.04, purchased at the abbey in 2001The bottle is slowly gushing; it pours a cloudy brown color with big lumps; small and persistent creamy head. Nice aroma of caramel, with a hint of oxidization. It has a good flavor of malt and caramel with a touch of honey; light residual sweetness; the bitterness level is low; the oxidization is minimal.Although lacking a bit in the bitterness, its still a quintessential Belgian ale, with a good harmony.2011-01-28, vintage 2001, 10 years old, 7-4-8-4-16=39bb 2004The color is dark chestnut, almost black; it has a thin creamy cap. The aroma is mild, with malt, caramel and light signs of oxidisation; later, some honey too. In the beginning it reminds me of a Chimay Blue, but luckily the fears have no foundation, it has instead a good body, still some respectable sweetness, caramel and malt flavor, with clear notes of chestnut honey; maybe a tad too much of sweet liquorice in the end; the signs of age are very well hidden; the alcohol warmth is a pleasant complement, and the bitterness is very low. Excellent..2010-04-15, vintage 2001, 9 years old 7-4-7-3-14=35bb 2004Gushing bottle, it pours a dark brown color with big fizzy and frothy head, that reduces to a small layer, persistent. Caramel and chocolate aroma, chestnut honey; partially oxidized. Medium bodied (thinner than other Belgian Ales with similar strength), caramel, dark caramel and chocolate flavor, with a slice of oxidation, some roasted malts and nuts in the end, and light liquorice too. The bitterness from the hop is gone, there is just some from the roasted malts; the final is a mix of caramel and liquorice. Beyond its prime, its just an exercise for passionates. Suboptimal.2002-05-14, vintage 2001, 1 year old, 7-5-9-5-18=44Ruby amber ale, thick head. Nice malt and hop aroma.Smooth, well balanced; strong malt taste, caramel, hop, candi sugar.

I too was expecting Westy-12 light, but it was quite different.  The first thing I noticed was the yeastiness, which I actually thought was kind of cool.  Same incredible smoothness as 12, didnt taste noticeably weaker, though slightly less full-bodied.  Still a top-notch beer.  I only had a small sample, will have to re-rate somewhere down the line.

Very good beer, not what I expected though...it didnt taste as much like the 12 as I thought it would.  I liked the smooth fruity taste and milk chocolate goodness.  It had a slight yeasty characteristic that kept me from rating it higher though.  A definite winner though.

I know this is irreverent, but this did more for me than the 12, probably because I let the yeast settle better than I did with my 12 and kept most of it in the bottle. Its amazing how the flavors of these beers change from sip to sip. I got more chocolate from this than from the 12 - not the bitter-sweet chocolate of a stout, but a smooth milk chocolate, alternating with the fruit and the wine. My oh my this is good.

Unbelievable! Almost garnate in color with a creamy tan head and a few floaters roaming around (mmmm floaters). Aroma of cookies and orange peels and a slightly bready nose as well. Smooth as silk with flavors of cocoa, nuts, plums and dates. A deliciously smooth beer that even my wife loves! Guess Ill have to put a lock on the hutch in the cellar now!
For someone who has yet to try the Abt 12 these are high marks but I really enjoyed this beer. It has an amazing complexity with a great not too intense finish.

It is because I have tried Abt 12 already that I cant give this beer a perfect 5. The main differences between this one and the Abt 12 are the intensity and duration of the aftertaste . The aftertaste is not as long as with the Abt 12. This beer is less intense than its big brother but has a similar complexity. Other than that this is one of my favorite beers.

Dark, dark reddish brown color -- maybe the darkest thickest Belgian Ive had, with a soft creamy medium-diminishing head.  Nose is fabulous, bananas uppermost, but also plums, raisins, brandy; in short, a Christmas treat of a nose!  The flavor matches the nose almost perfectly, with a luscious velvety body, warming silky feel from the moment it hits the tongue to the settling in your innards.  Flavor nearly as intense as the nose, with a nice subtle peaty smoky undertone supporting bittersweet chocolate, caramel, figs and other dried fruits.

UPDATED: MAR 13, 2004 Very richly colored deep brown, reddish. Large medium density tan head which exudes an exceptional aroma of berries, malt, and caramel. Velvety smooth palate with a moderate to high level of carbonation. One of the most full flavored specimens I have tried. A perfect melding of components leaving no hint of wateriness whatsoever. Very rich in chocolate and yeast flavors contrasted perfectly by the slightly fruity/(cherry) and sour components. Finish is unbelievably crisp. Absolutely no off flavors developing in the finish.

Deep black cherry in color, cloudy, frothy beige head and tons of lace, also a Bazillion tiny bubbles, sliding their little butts up the glass. Not many beers have a better nose, malt, banana, slight yeasty bread dough, over ripe fruit, just makes your mouth water smelling these wonderful beers. Sweet, light to the top, finish is hop bitter, but only mildly so, dry, acidic, light to moderate carbonation. A fine cousin to the 12, 10 damn well worth the try!

Amazing meringue like head, cloudy brown color. Yeasty aroma, with fruity grainy elements. Great mouthfeel, coffee-chocolate, also odd taste of corn or unroasted barley. Opened up as it warmed. Too much alcohol taste. I rerated this side by side w. Rochefort 8 and I thought this one came up short.
I dont see what the big deal is with this beer.  It doesnt taste nearly as good as the Westy 12.  Wouldnt seek this one out again.

Mostly brown color with perhaps a touch of red, a very pronounced head, perhaps a little too frothy, that lingers after you pour, a terrific medium to full-bodied malted flavor and a terrific balance, but while I believe there are better Belgium beers out there, this is among the best, as the flavor improves with each sip, always a sign of a first rate beer, personally, I prefer the Westmalle Dubbel for the perfect flavor

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2004 I treated myself to this as my 50th rated beer, and I'm glad I did. It was nearly perfect in all aspects. The flavors were aplenty (big globe grapes, caramel, walnut) and the alcohol was just present enough to enjoy. I'll surely go out of my way to have another!

tremendous stuff. dark  brown color, very murky, lots of particles floating around here.
pours a big firm head.
unique taste , combination of sweet malt, indistinct fruit  and a slight bitter almond-like flavor.
the taste intensifies as the beer warms.
only flaw if the availability (or lack thereof)
Impressive, amazing head on this brew. Great winey aroma and the taste of dark grapes and nuts. Slight hints at dark chocolate. One of the greats.
Fruity aroma, very dark reddish, large initial head. I liked this brew more than apt 12, didnt have as much of an alcohol character.

UPDATED: MAY 12, 2016 Hazy deep copper to umber in color. tallish, stable, creamy light tan head. Aromas, of light tropical fruit, plums, caramel, marzipan and hints of mint. Light and soft across the palate. Light sweet start. Mild fruit and malts in the middle. Some oak and wood in the finish and linger. Hickory nuts in the finish. A really good brew. My score might be a bit high. But Ill have another in a few years to confirm. 
2/26/02 Great complex aroma, flavor, and finish.
Plum wine, brandy, dark fruits, with a great nutty finish.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2013 Bottle purchased in Brussels: Murky brown with a healthy beige head and intricate lace patterns. Mouthfeel is smooth, soft, velvety, thick and rich. Alcohol slowly warms the throat. Complex notes of dark fruit (raisins and figs mainly), chocolate, toasted bread crust, spices and sweet toffee. Fresh yeast flavors and aromas from start to finish. Balanced bitterness.

These monks know how to do things right.  The blue cap (8) is only exceeded by the yellow cap (12).  The alcohol is not a prevalent here as in the 12, but all the malt and balancing hops are right on the mark.  If you are luckky enough to find this outside of Belgium, youd better snatch it up, before I do!  You cant go wrong with Westvleteren!
UPDATED: JAN 6, 2004 Wood/wine aroma, dark fruit taste.  That describes about 1% of it.  To learn about the rest, try it yourself.

This was a good beer, but nothing in comparison to its rep.  Not close to as good as the 12.  Nice brown color, some yeast, good head.  Great aroma of alcohol and grapes.  Very hoppy for a belgian ale.  Some dark fruit tastes, little woodiness.  Very nicely balanced.

A deep, deep brown color; Head was dense but seemed to fade a bit quickly for the style; Aromas are just too varied to get my puny mind around. Round and fluffy. Heavy raisin followed by hints of anise. Toffee and small bits of caramel. The alcohol is well-hidden. Thick and full mouthfeel. Wonderful palate. A real joy to drink and a pleasure. Havent had the 12 yet, but this was outstanding.
To try to describe the aromas and flavor of this bear would require a harddrive bigger than mine. A multiplicity of aromas and flavors to deal with. Heck, it is just a great beer to have as have can!

I must begin by saying that I was not blown away by this beer as I expected I would be.  That being said, I can appreciate the complexities within.  The aroma is hoppy, astringent and slightly metallic.  The flavor has a million different things going on including butterscotch, roasted malt, yeast, chocolate, dark fruits, and hop bitterness.  The beginning and middle are dominated by malt, chocolate and dark fruits and the finish is hoppy and bitter.  The aftertaste is extrordinarily long butterscotch.  The palate is good, but the flavors have some trouble converging in some instances.  For example, the bitter finish does not blend well at all with the long butterscotch aftertaste.  This is a beautiful beer to say the least.  Very deep ruby-brown color with a bone colored head.
A very impressive dark beer. It has a round and full taste. Very Good!!

Very good, but not as amazing as I expected given the reviews here.  I have yet to try the 12, which I hear is noticeably better.  Please excuse my lack of description, as I tried this about a week before my review.  Still recommended, despite a slight disappointment after reading the commentary here.

Creamy and firm eggshell-brown and persistant foam.  Dark-brown opaque brew, with fine bubbles visible only by holding the abbey trappist glass against a full sunshine background!
At first, subdued aroma, opening to very subtle and fine plum and malt aromas, and ..alcohol.
Intense and balanced malty-licorice flavors, complex and full-bodied but quite dry (not overly alcohol-driven).
Very fine and long in the mouth, with excellent balance, with a slightly bitter ending leaving a long lingering aftertaste.
Top class beer, now lets age some and come back!
Very nice creamy head, beautiful brown colour. Aroma: hazelnut, caramel, chocolate, very nice ! Full-bodied with a very pleasant, strong aftertaste.

Love this beer.  The aroma is bread-like with yeast and a little malt in the background.  The fruit flavors of plum, raison and apricot appear with caramel.  Great mouthfeel.  Hard to find sometimes in Jersey, but a must-have when I spot it.

Great copper hue, with a fleating lacy head. Malty, yeasty aroma, with a hint of fruity alcohol. Full or flavor and very robust body. Great malty notes accompanied by fruit and grains, most noticable were plums, oats and wheat. Fizzy on the tongue and yeasty at the finish. Overall an excellent brew.

Dark, cloudy brown and full of yeast, with a lush apple, yeast, and malty plum nose.  Following is a a full-bodied, smooth but slightly fizzy body, consisting of malted plum and oat flavors, with an unfortunate amount of yeast flavor in the finish.  Relative to 12 this is disappointing; but then again nothing compares to 12.

If I could rate this on a scale of 1-5, this would be a 10. I would leave all my other ratings (forgive me Abbey de Scourmont) where they are. This beer maybe even a bit sexier than the Abt 12 Godfather version. Full of so much passion and decadence, this beer blows every other beer to wayside.  This is the Pax Roman of beers gentlemen and ladies. If you can get it, get as much as you can!!!!!!

Possibly my favorite beer.  Great head retention, pleasing copper hue, and extreme taste all contribute to the experience of drinking this fine beer.  Hints of spices, fruits, even a chocolate malt flavor make this one of the most complex brews I have yet to try.

Bravo!  les moines ont une recette unique et original...
une vraie bière Trapiste!

If I were more reverent I would go to this monestery and make bier my life. this brew is fantastic. Scrumcious is the word for this one. The mouth feel is one of a kind...explosive. It is not 10 or 12 but I will gladly spend the $6 a bottle. Every time. All those fruit and dried fruit combinations that the seniors have, on a session level. Great.

UPDATED: JUN 19, 2009 An ale that lives up to its Trappist image.  Big burnt fruit flavors, mainly plums and grapes.  A strong beer at around 9%, but still deceptively drinkable.  Not as good as the 12, but still one of the best beers Ive ever had.  God bless those monks!
Again, I have to agree with Shadallion on this one.
Full, complex malt palate.  Mildly spicy/yeasty, with subtle fruits (pear?  raisin,nutty?) and just a hint of alcohol.  Nice deep reddish brown color and full rocky head.
Has a rocky head, a rich aroma of malt, plums, and raisins and a tremendous palate - huge malt, warming alcohol, some burnt fruit. The finish is a little astringent.

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2004 2000 vintage, sampled 03/2004 - dark brown colour, nice creamy head and a wonderful lacing, gingerbread and chocolaty aroma, notes of raisins, sweet, very creamy and malty, robust bitterness, very long dry aftertaste of bread, malt, dried fruits and warming alcohol - incredibly complex and deeply balanced
